reviewText: Great movie watch it
Stinker

It's my opinion that Kurt Russell must be desperate for money to have signed on for this completely awful movie.  He's been in so many entertaining movies that he, obviously, can read a script and see if it has a fair chance of justifying the audience's purchase of a ticket or if it's nothing but a rip-off.  He must have known this idiotic sham was going to be nothing but a fraud on those who would pay to watch it.  Kurt, you've put my money in your pocket for the last time.

Watch immediately if you're a fan of Kurt Russell or original horror movies. The writer/director does not disappoint in crafting a very original, entertaining Western that approaches a gory conclusion ominously and with very well-crafted dialogue. The acting is mostly very good. Russell, as always, is a badass. Richard Jenkins delivers an outstanding performance and Patrick Wilson shines as well. Prepare yourself for a slow burn that doesn't rely on cheap scares or predictable action sequences.

This movie is interesting. Dialogue is inviting and sometimes amusing. It does drag out a bit in the first half but worth the wait for the second half.
Not your typical movie, not your typical western, and not your typical ending. I applaud the makers for something a little different.
Long and drawn out .. has it's moments .. I would wait until it's a .99 cent movie
Slow action and frustrating to watch.

If you are over 50ish, you probably know and love the Westerns. This movie brings that nostalgic feel to a great western along with real dialog and real characters that interact like normal people. The ending part of the movie takes you to where NO western has ever gone, but you were ready for the ride. Have not enjoyed a movie this much in a long while. Please make more like this and I will keep buying !!!
WOAAAAH!!!! Kurt Russell!
Slow and dragged. too little action
Different than what I exspected.  Goy

I am befuddled by the reviews on here, you can't possibly see anything entertaining about this piece of cinematic crap, seriously?  How embarrassing for Russell and quite frankly the entire cast.
I want my 90+ minutes back!~

To get this out of the way, I love slow burn westerns (like Unforgiven). I enjoy good horror (both good and so bad it's good). I couldn't stand this movie. The characters are blandly written (a true waste of Kurt Russell) or irritating. The dialogue was mumbled. Too many scenes of telling the audience what's happening instead of showing them (it's almost like film is a visual medium and plot, characters, and mood should be communicated visually). I'm not a particular gore fan, but the gore was super boring and middle of the road. So many instances where the film maker made the lazy decision rather than the smart or interesting decision.

Truth be told, I would honestly give this maybe 3 stars, but who bothers reading those lukewarm rational opinions? I enjoyed the actors and the situations and even the envelope that was pushed to limits commonly found only in comic books.
For the sake of decency and in an effort to warn parents and honor the Founding Fathers I give one star because it might be read and people will not only say "Hell to the disgusting no! We don't want our precious little impressionable gifts from heaven, Bobby, Bobbie, and Whatev's, to be sucker-punched by the weird freakshow horror that is Bone Tomahawk." This is not a family show, unless maybe its that family from The House of a 1000 Corpses. Now that was a fine horror flick.
This adults-only diversion spectacular needs a particular code warning viewers of the few minutes towards the movie's conclusion of a repulsive and potentially traumatic depiction of a person being drawn and quartered and the body parts thrown on the barby to be eaten by the desert cave-dwellers as they stomp about grunting and threatening, remarkably identical to Hillary. It reminds of a Sunday meal at the kids' table with giddy efforts at comedy waving chicken legs in the air and sporting black olives on our finger tips. Yes, we were blessed. However, the scary heathens need two hands to carry around a human leg while chewing on it. At this point in the show, I might have looked like the ultra violent criminal Alex from Clockwork Orange in his close-up during his reprogramming treatment, but that I was doing it because I wanted to and I need to "see it through" someday and prove to myself that "I have what it takes" in the self-confidence category as an amateur movie critic and foot dragger. Even though the moment of frozen horror was relatively brief, the effect was similar to the one I experienced when I saw Jaws at the afternoon cheap matinee. I went whole hog and purchased a large bucket of popcorn which I put under my seat as the movie was already starting and there's no "How do you do?" with Jaws on the big screen. No light comments humorously delivered about something in current events that everybody can relate to so you can laugh at the same thing a hundred unseen strangers are laughing at. Just the air not being inhaled like normal because many are holding their breath, sceaming inside and out, and getting a natural buzz from not breathing. Finally, after the shark exploded and the lights came up, I went "whoosh" and kicked my big popcorn with my heel and realized it was a shameful squander I had committed, but the magical power of Jaws had removed me from common humdrum life and I wasn't really at fault. Maybe I should give this Indy show more than one star. Was Jaws so much more righteous than this fine twisted western? Jaws was a great movie.
The truth is that I enjoyed the show, watched it by myself in the air conditioned comfort of my basement theater, and didn't need to worry about the impact that the extreme depictions might have on the impressionable.
I've been around the block and I'm not too afraid of "the wild side", and could easily be labelled as "jaded" like many others.
Another positive is the absence of the too-common moralizing hidden in the narrative by naive pagan college students trying to teach me what they learned in school, how to "get along with weird perversions of every kind" and that "there is no such thing as weird perversions" and  the rest of that squirrelly rehashed "enlightened" jive talk.
I'll stick with my Romans 1: 16- 32, thank you very much. Good movies are hard to find.
Shave and a haircut...!
great mobie

I wish there were 0 stars. I am shocked that Kurt Russell put his name on this movie. He must have been hard up for a paycheck! Weird plot. I had to turn my head when the cannibals hung a man upside down and split him from the crotch with the "bone tomahawk". Stupid, stupid, stupid.  Even the closing song was terrible.

68 years young.
I have always loved good westerns, but there are few recent movies which approach The Searchers, Red River, Liberty Valance, the James Stewart classics, Shane, the Eastwood/Leone collaborations, Once Upon a Time in the West, etc.. Unforgiven is a modern classic, the 1st Lonesome Dove is great, and I enjoyed Open Range and the Kurt Russell version of Tombstone.
Bone Tomahawk has an A-list cast, the requisite weathered authentic look in both town and people, beautiful filming and dramatic lighting, solid writing, humor, intriguing plot.
But late in the goings there is a scene of complete and utterly depraved brutality which, to be honest, I wish I had not seen, and wish that I could "unsee". This graphic butchery never would have been shown if this had been filmed in the 50's, 60's, 70's...probably even up to 2000!
Now, practically anything goes. Audiences of today seem unbothered by, and perhaps even relish, seeing this brutality. Certainly one can become inured to it; is it possible to become addicted to it?
Is that progress?

I'm not surprised to see so many 1 star ratings for this film.. classic westerns tend to be a much slower pace than people are used to, and this film honors the genre impeccably. Of course, this also requires great acting, great dialogue, and great story-telling... which Bone Tomahawk has in spades. That being said, classic westerns aren't for everyone.. so if you can allow yourself to be absorbed by the creeping and careful development of this film, the payoff is horror at it's most terrifying.  What an incredible blending of genres.

Nope not for me.  There are scenes in this movie that are burnt into my brain!  I thought this movie was going to be a good western, and I was wrong.  This should have been classified as horror/gore.  Disappointed to say the least.  This is not your Tombstone type of movie.
cheap production, bad acting, almost a comedy but not funny.
Worst movie ever, incredibly poor acting and premise
I loved the movie. You cannot make me squeamish. Kurt & Wilson were great.

gritty.. grabs you from the start.. no cutting corners,, its brutal.. its edge of your seat, its hard to watch.. its savagery..

omg... its a truly unique western tale of incredible drama, almost bordering on a western horror flick  if only for what could be termed
"accurate portrayals " of true savagery.

Kurt and cast do an incredible job..
not giving anything away. you just have to watch it for yourself..

Someone on Facebook told me about the movie "Bone Tomahawk" and referred to it as a horror film.  After looking at the movie poster, I ASSUMED it was just another western but was intrigued by the photo of one of my favorite actors Kurt Russell. IT IS A HORROR FLICK and a damn good one if you want to see a whole new spin on this genre.  We've seen a ton of films with vampires, zombies and creepy crawling outer space creatures, but how many of you have seen films about cannibals?  Yep...cannibals.  This film will make your flesh crawl and it's been a long time since I had to close my eyes or turn my head so I couldn't see the next horrific scene. Russell is terrific along with his supporting cast of Patrick Wilson, Matthew Fox and Richard Jenkins.  The critics said, "A most violent delight."  "...great dialogue, strong characters and imaginative and memorable kills." Whomever that FB contact was that referred me to this film...THANK YOU...A HUGE THANK YOU.  All 5 stars.
Badass Movie!! Kurt Russell and supporting actors were great. Nice story line and Quentin Tarantino style gore.  I give it two thumbs up ! "Say goodbye to my wife, I'll say hello to yours."

Very telling that all the one star ratings are accompanied by single syllable words forming a one sentence review.  I've watched this movie several times now, and found it as suspenseful the last time as the first.  It's a great story with great actors, and will ultimately become a cult favorite once the dust settles.  This movie takes a little patience, yes, but it's easy to relate to and care about the characters, and what they're up against is truly frightening every step of the way.  I've also badly broken my tibia/fibula, so I was able to relate well to one of the lead characters and the excruciating pain he had to deal with throughout the trek.  I found myself cringing every step of the way.  The climax is brutal, but believable, and terrifying.  Highly recommend, but the definitely not for everyone.  My wife, for example, would hate it.
good movie, a bit gory but i personally like gore, the characters weren't very fleshed out but the acting made up for that. If you like this movie you should give "The ballad of Lefty Brown" a watch.
Eeesh. Not for the squeamish. Scenes of heinous things you usually do not see. But, Kurt Russell, though.

This movie is not boring, at least not on first watch: its a 'quest' or 'mission' story and actually quite bare-bones.  It is not full of gratuitous music (where the hell do they hide the orchestra in these modern movies??  They just seem so silly . . . Two characters walk into a woods and suddenly there is a huge violin section playing . . . I hate it!) but it does most unusual sound effects  -  and those odd sounds are actually one of the down points: not the weird screeching, that is great!  but the sounds of large people walking on the ground.  Their foley people have made them sound like a large hollow bass drum in some places, perhaps by accident (?).  It should be a dead thump, not a 'hollow' one.  Some of the outdoor dialogue also has a fake bottom.
The sets and make-up and filming are all professional.
It's a good yarn, and shown in a way to hold the viewer's interest - at least for the first watch.  Maybe not too much after that because, as others have noted, the middle part (on the trail) is rather lengthy.  This is not a defect because enough 'weirdness' has  already happened at the start of the film to make the slow tracking of the antagonists not boring but rather suspenseful  -  and also because, in this throw-away culture which has hundreds of films trying to get our attention at any given time, the movie maker can't assume that anyone would watch the film more than once.
thanks

An excellent blend of horror and Old West showmanship. This is not all glamour and is rather gory, but if you didn't know that going in then you would be foolish. Its certainly a horror story in and old west setting, not your typical cowboys and Indians which was refreshing. Some scenes are truly horrifying and will retch your gut, however the character and dialogue is excellent. Everyone seemed true to life and the period dialogue was really nice to see (rather than modern slag). Most def worth watching.
Wow this movie was really good.
good movie

Extremely realistic, if you don't count the part about having little water on the last part of the journey.  Not one bit cookie cutter.  Very unexpected, to the point I almost regret watching it home alone!  A long time Kurt Russell fan, he didn't fail to disappoint.  Although gory, I like how it was not sugar coated (much) and really did show something relatively realistic.  The only thing I'd change about this choice is when I chose to watch it!

Wow what a movie! It was excellent but it had it's moments that made you cringe and I felt a combination of Horror & Sadness from the gruesome killings that basically came as real as it gets. I would not wish this to happen to my worst enemy & I'm sure no one would with the basic human compassion and respect for life. It felt like what I was watching was really happening that's how real this film got and it was shocking and hard to watch at times. But I recommend this movie because I felt like this is something that could of very of happened back in the day or maybe even today in some parts of the world today, it really makes you wonder about the craziness that happens in the world.

Ive watched Bone Tomahawk 5-6 times and I continue to be amazed at how exhilarated each viewing leaves me. Though the national critics praised the film across the board, I've read my share of public opinions (including ones on Amazon) declaring how "appalling" and "unnecessary" the gruesome horror elements are to the story, as well as a few ignorant comments about slow pacing. Well, as a member of the viewing public, I just want to share my opinion on how terrific ALL elements of this film truly are.

Starting with the screenplay, the banter between the four main characters is some of the finest in Western cinematic history. One particular exchange between Sheriff Hunt (Kurt Russell) and Chicory (Richard Jenkins) actually causes me to tear up EVERY time I see it... a pretty good testimony as to just how well a film can make one "feel" towards its characters amidst serving up some of the most terrifyingly shocking events a Western mash-up has to offer. The gruesome elements do not detract from the story one bit, but actually serve to heighten the sense of dread and despair surrounding these characters. And, it makes you feel for them.

The sparsely used score also hits just the right notes at just the right times to convey the notion that these men are riding into a potential suicide mission. In my repeat viewings, I always find myself thinking, "these poor, poor men ... they have no idea what awaits them," and I experience the impending dread all over again as the horror unfolds. Absolute kudos to S. Craig Zahler for writing/directing something so unique that this powerful of a response could take place in repeated viewings... another testimony of how stellar storytelling and perfect tone can combine with truly horrifying circumstances to create the perfect visceral experience.

Lastly, I absolutely loved all four main actors... Russell, Jenkins, Patrick Wilson, and especially Matthew Fox in his role! Foxs character unexpectedly saddened me for reasons I cant really list without giving away too many plot points. Ill just say I was most interested in seeing how his spoken bravado and cock-sure aura would play out in the end.

In conclusion, Bone Tomahawk is a truly great film for the ages. Its not for everyone, especially the squeamish. But if you want to experience an uncompromising look at the Old West and what happens when (what we think to be) a typical Cowboys and Indians story turns into an absolute hellish nightmare, this might just be right up your alley. Its Russells best film in years and puts the other western he did in the same year to shame!

Westerns aren't really my thing but I watched this because it kept showing up as 'horror' and I like a good, scary movie. Sadly, this tips the scales as slasher and torture porn more than psychological horror and I'm not into gore.  I'm not squeamish but I don't really find it scary or interesting.

I would imagine the audience for this is a rather small crossover of Western + torture porn + Kurt Russell fans.

If you like Westerns, this is worth watching.
 Kurt Russell does a good job, pretty gorey  towards the end though

i really don't understand why people think this is a good movie. the whole premise that native americans would mutilate their throats to make a whistling sound is ridiculous. and the sound that was made by them was even more ridiculous. don't waste your time with this one. an utterly useless movie.
gruesome, gritty, humorous, weird, some parts unwatchable, but a good movie.
gritty realism, fantastic storyline. One of the best movies I've seen in awhile

Great movie. The story was amazing, and it answers all the questions you'll have without any extensive back story for any one character or at the cost of submersion. The movie is gruesome at parts, but it's okay because it's never needless violence. If a character gets injured or worried, you feel like you're there with them. One scene in particular is gag worthy, and the middle 30-45 minutes is very slow which is why I gave it four stars rather than five, but the action hits with little to no warning.
NC
Its a shame to see someone like Kurt Russell reduced to taking part in lovies like this. Doesn't have not a single redeeming quality.  Nothing but senseless violence, and porn.
Violence porn - with multiple graphic mutilation scenes, not a western, but a "Saw" movie set in the old west.  Awful!!!
LOVE THIS MOVIE. So scary
Nothing more to say.
Well done and really interesting twist on a western.
a surprising movie reminds me of ravenous 1999

So many lames one and two starring this great Western. Definitely not for the weak-hearted, but if you love a good slow boil, gunslinging, revenge flick, this is it. Likable protagonists, scary bad guys, and men being men. This has all the elements you want in a Western.
Too graphic, slow story, yawner, however Kurt was a bright spot.

I liked it. I've watched the movie about three times now and have decided it is a good movie. Slow burn is correct (as stated in other reviews). Kurt Russell is fantastic as the town Sherriff with a dialog I really enjoyed. All the other main characters do a superb job as well.  Give it a try and you might be surprised.

Make no mistakethis is a very good western.  A lot of westerns are known for slow pacing at times, so that shouldnt be a surprise.  It actually wasn't as slow as some have said.  Great character development.  Great decision of when/when not to use a musical score.  The lack of score was brilliant.
I have only one complaint.  Ive seen brutality in movies before.  The death scene at the end was over the top.  That could have been edited and made less disturbing.  Im usually not squeamish, but for whatever reason, this bothered me.  Maybe it was because I knew what could potentially happen to the characters we grew to know during the previous 2 hours.
It is a fresh blend of western and horror.  It reminded me of The Green Inferno toward the end though, which is why I didn't give it five stars.
Great movie and a great western movie.

WARNING: Contains shocking gore, adult situations - not for the squeamish or easily offended!

SPOILERS AHEAD:

Interesting modern exploitation hybrid of Western, Horror, and Revenge genres.

Pokes around at lots of politically-incorrect topics in a self-aware way (while carefully balancing so as not to go over the acceptable edge).

Kurt Russell and Richard Jenkins are wonderful in this; they're the glue that holds it all together. Fans of The Thing (1982) will most likely love this movie.

Things that bugged me:

How did Patrick Wilson's character climb up the cliff and into the cave at the end? Or was there another entrance (as Kurt Russell conveniently hints at). The movie has lots of filler and moves at a very slow pace - much of it could've been trimmed to allow for a visual explanation of how he got inside the cave (and out for that matter).

Why the overly complicated (and silly) anatomy of the Troglodytes (cave dwellers) to explain their vocalizations? It would've been cheaper and more logical to show them using some type of human or animal bone instrument to make their vocal calls. This is part of the aforementioned "careful balancing" regarding politically-incorrect topics. The director went to great lengths to prove the Troglodytes weren't simply humans. They're literally Orc like monsters with ridiculous anatomical features; this lessened the impact of the film.

Lili Simmons's character is a bit of an annoying Mary Sue. After being imprisoned by the Troglodytes and witnessing their depraved acts, she is mentally and physically untarnished except for a bit of grime on her dress. Her self-righteous snark goes into over-drive as she berates her rescuers with a ridiculous rant (more careful balancing). She even refuses to kiss her heroic husband at the end because there is "something gross on his mouth"  *eye roll*

How it should have ended:

Arthur O'Dwyer dies after the horses are stolen.

While burying Mr. O'Dwyer, Brooder finds the love letter Mr. O'Dwyer wrote to Mrs. O'Dwyer and takes it with him.

Chicory dies heroically after they encounter some Trogs.

Brooder is captured and Sheriff Hunt escapes.

Trogs find the bottle of opium on Chicory's body and drink it.

Sheriff Hunt takes out the sleeping Trogs who drank the opium and discovers the device they use to make calls.

Brooder reads Mr. O'Dwyer's love letter to Mrs. O'Dwyer inside the cave and informs her of her husband's passing.

Sheriff Hunt lures a group of Trogs out of the cave with the Trog whistle and blasts them with dynamite.

Sheriff Hunt enters the cave and frees Brooder and Mrs. O'Dwyer.

They begin to descend the rope from the cave to the ground (Brooder and Mrs. O'Dwyer first).

Trog calls are heard during the descent - they grow louder heightening the tension.

While beginning his descent, Sheriff Hunt is pulled back into the cave by two Trogs.

In a heroic act  of self-sacrifice, Sheriff Hunt uses dynamite to blow himself up with the Trogs inside the cave.

The explosion seals the cave entrance.

Brooder and Mrs. O'Dwyer are bathed in the light of a glorious sunrise as they begin their journey home.
Boringggggggg
Good movie.

YOU WAITED FOR THIS = THE SPOILER OF MOVIE:  They scalp a dude in a cave, put his scalp in his mouth and jam it in with a bone, then grab him and hold him upside down with legs spread like a hog, while he has no clothes and chop him several times from nether-regions to chest and guts fall out.  It's awful.  Then Kurt dies with a flask shoved into a cut in his stomach.  Good guys win.  You wait an hour and 45 of a decent albeit a little slow western, for a shock horror moment.  I mean I guess it tells a possibly true story....it's just so slow to wait for a 30 second scene that seems like that's all you were waiting for.

A tedious, grim exercise in Western tropes is highjacked by Eli Roth style gore and misogyny. The cast did a marvelous job with what they had but I felt that the obstacles of the wild, human fragility and personality conflicts were drama enough before the discordant third act.

I was not expecting a Kurt Russell joint to be nearly this bloody, but this manages to raise itself above mere "torture porn." There are moments of pure beauty and genuinely hilarious parts as well. It's also "problematic," as the kids say nowadays. Put this one on the top of your watchlist and be prepared for some truly intense scenes as well. Definitely not for the faint of heart, that's for sure.
Original and kept me glued to the screen.  I'm a huge fan of Kurt Russell and this is one of his best works.  If I could give it 6 stars, i would.
If you'e into gore, go for it.
This is effectively a horror/western. Russell was the perfect choice for the role. There is no messing around in this movie. The savages truly are savage.

This movie can be disturbing. It is a twist. I enjoyed the back-up deputy. He was odd but there. The cave dwellers use a jaw bone that had been honed to a very sharp edge and it was deadly. This was a good but dark western.
I really enjoyed the movie. Glad I bought it to watch a few times.
A slightly slow burning drama which takes a sharp turn into effective horror in the last act. Its very atmospheric.
Seemed a bit long, but a thriller of a movie. Worth the watch.

The risk for Bone Tomahawk was becoming too dark, too violent, too light, too vapid, and generally too pulpy. Instead it is a perfectly balanced stew of savage menace, sharp dialogue, solid acting by well-cast players, canny cinematography, and well-developed characters roasting over the open campfire of Southern California's desert. The tight focus on just four characters is played out against the wide vistas of the West.

If you are expecting Gunsmoke, Unforgiven, or True Grit, this is not your film (althought the dialogue does call to mind the wry wit of the Coen Brothers). Bone Tomahawk takes its time to get where it is going, so that when it gets there you know the characters intimately. Make no mistake:  this is a character-driven film. There are no gunfights. When a character draws a firearm it is a spastic and lethal affair. The weapons have a weight to them that action movies eschew because it cuts shootouts short. Here, whe someone draws a gun, it is life or death in 5 seconds or less.

The plot is not terribly inventive, nor does it need to be. While that may be a fault to some I think it serves well here. There are no loose ends or convoluted work-arounds to make a character's appearance logical. It is a no-nonsense and straightforward narrative that feels refreshing in a cinemascape choked with plot twists and contrivances that make following the action a chore. Here, the stakes are set, and the players are off, and victory & failure are clearly defined.

Bone Tomahawk was made with $1.8 million and puts movies 150 times larger to shame. This is what tight writing an well-executed cinema looks like.

I'm glad I didn't take the negative reviews to heart and watched it anyway. Some parts are hard to watch because it seemed real. Some people can't take that. I don't know about the technical elements of the movie that the snobs rave about. I just know it is a really good movie and the struggle was real.
great, thanks.

One of the better action westerns with a twist that I loved.  When I saw this coming out I paid little to no attention thinking it was just another western and since the commercials reminded me of the "Hateful Eight" which I had already seen I did not want a retread.
However I am so glad I gave this another look... with a great supporting cast Kurt Russell leads a group on a rescue mission against some cannibalistic Indians and to really say much more would spoil it for anyone who has not seen it.
I will say hats off to the great Richard Jenkins who as his role as the "old man deputy" was so good and his dialogue was so sharp it made me smile during a movie when there were not any real laughs.
See this movie if you like slow churning action with old west mentalities thats part horror movie and a little love story tossed in.
A completely stupid movve--stupid premise, and a stupid plod through a stupid plot--too many "holes" to count...
Oh my, this is a realistic cowboy movie.  This is how it was.

great movie for children to watch.  the sound effects to the opening scene are A+

kurt russell, won't you tug on my love muscle?

loved this movie so much i bought it! Best (or worst) death scene i have EVER SEEN! YIKES!!!! The cast is fabulous, you care for every single one of 'em. And you know that's all i really ever ask of a film, is that i am made to care and am invested in the lives of these characters. Great ensemble, love how you learn more and more about what motivates all these characters as they get deeper in to the horror ahead of them. This film pulls no punches and is SUCH an interesting mix of western genre and true horror, kind of like Dead Birds, or The Burrowers, but MUCH MUCH better. Also LOVED LOVED LOVED the true to historical period dialog, which is almost as good as Ride With The Devil! GREAT FILM, Bone Tomahawk, go into it with no expectations or being forewarned and it will take you on a tremendously entertaining, if grisly ride.
Didn't finish it :(
I can't believe they got Kurt Russell to be in this POS B movie.  Not worth watching.

I have always been a Kurt Russell fan, since he was a child actor, BUT this is possibly the WORST movie I have ever seen.  I thought it was going to be a western but it is really a gross, extremely violent, sick/twisted story that just happens to be in the time period of a western.  This is in no way entertaining. It gave me nightmares and I don't get nightmares. Yikes!

Summary of the movie: old Western meets Predator-like Indian people who barely wear clothes.

The actors did well. The movie was interesting at first but little could save this movie. Long and tedious, bad script, and unnecessarily gross at times. I wonder if it could have been better if they tightened the script and changed the antagonists. Kurt Russell was the star who gave this movie some credibility. Otherwise a real waste. Yikes. Even watched this for free and I still say stay far away. Give two stars simply because it's not the worst movie I've ever seen--just not good.
Wasn't what I expected and turns out that's a good thing.  Good cast, good movie - worth watching.
Slow moving discussting violance

I like westerns and love Kurt Russell in anything, but this was a strange piece of art. Anything but a typical cowboy story, it made the truth of educated men in the west come to life and the bravery and compassion something tactile. These were real people with all their high and low points and the storyline was unique but very believable. I have spent my entire life in the southwest and from the stories told by my old third generation Arizonan in-laws who settled this desert, this was entirely possible. The only possible discrepancies were the large size of the rooms, a minor point.

A bloody buddy cop western takes a dark turn as four unlikely rescuers mark their slow sojourn with eloquent reflection, ultimately reminding the viewer that US education standards are little improved since the days of the early prairie settlers.
As the heroine damsel in distress correctly observes about her cohorts, it's not the hard life or the Indians that kill you, it's the idiots.

Brutally brilliant. Its a movie where "once upon a time in the west" meets "hills have eyes". A western HORROR! with a tinch of adventure and humor.
If theres going to any adventure/horror with a hostage situation surrounded with paranoia "Kurt russel" will be remembered, he has already did some memorable movies in this genre like"The Thing","The Hateful Eight" and "Bone Tomahawk".
Not sure how this tarantino styled horror didn't create any buzz during its release and forgotten by the audience. Not an easy watch for the people who r sensitive to violence/gore.

Great slow-burn storyline, and marvelous performances by all involved. Doesn't shy away from the gore, but the blood is used sporadically and to great effect. Astounding use of color, and a minimalist score enhances an overall tremendous movie.
good movie stick with it it gets really good towards the end

Not your normal good guy cowboy stuff. Russel was really good.
Without giving anything away I'll say I think some of the neg reviews are because of a particularly inhuman piece of savagery that can't be removed from your mind once seen. It gets the message across of the gravity of the situation but maybe a bit less could have done the job also.

Very good character building if not a bit obvious.
Proof that death when put in perspective is all relative.
Awesome!
I thought it was well done and very thought provoking.  All the main actors did an outstanding job with their characters.  On the edge of your seat script.

This was great! I loved the characters and the horror. One scene was SO horrific that I had to stop watching it and wait for a time when I was better able to handle it. Kurt Russell (AND his epic facial hair?!) in a Western?! Hell, you can't go wrong! It's a pitch perfect period piece (sorry for the alliteration and I promise it won't happen again) in which the spot-on costuming, set decoration, locations and intriguing characters and dialogue add up to far more than the sum of the parts. (along with one more unforeseen little twist) I can't add much else about the film that hasn't already been said here in the MANY other reviews except for one thing. PLEASE do not read any further if you don't want to discover a MAJOR point that, while it may not exactly give away any of the story line or ending per se, it does disclose what others have only alluded to here, none of whom gave anything specific away. Im not certain whether or not I even possess the verbal wherewithal to do justice to this scene in attempting to describe it to you, but here goes nothing:

********SPOILER ALERT********

********SPOILER ALERT********

At one point, two bad men strip a third man, our victim, naked and support him by his feet, legs held high, while his head and shoulders remain aground. Thanking heaven for small favors, this is all seen from the rear. Okay. Here's where it goes beyond anything I've ever seen on any screen large or small and I am not squeamish by any stretch of the imagination. It brought me bolt upright quite literally on the edge of my seat while softly and slowly exclaiming oh my God over and over as it transpired. A third bad man hacks down at the victim's exposed crotch area, repeatedly raising up high overhead and then swinging down hard a crude axe-like cutting device. (the aforementioned, primitive and vicious bone tomahawk, I believe, but I haven't yet brought myself to watch the scene again for clarity) As the cutting tool repeatedly hammers into, and eventually through, the poor guy's nether region, the two leg-holding bad men continue to spread the victim's legs further and further apart to the accompanying and disturbing sounds of crunching hip bones and tearing viscera. After a few too many wince-inducing strikes, the poor victim splits wide open and his entrails and guts exit in a splashing cascade; a hot, bloody-wet mess from the now clearly exposed abdominal cavity. OH - EM - EFFING - G! Ive never seen anything like it before and I may not want to see it again. (although I probably will watch at least once more as, um, research. Yeah, thats it, simply as research!) Normally I would never reveal details of a scene from a movie such as this in a review but believe you me, there has never before BEEN a scene in a movie such as this. On that you have my word. And my warning.

I loved everything about the movie. A western horror. Great character development. It is a journey western. One of the most graphic deaths scenes I ever seen of film. It you haven't seen this movie. Go watch it now. It is awesome. Kurt Russel's stache needs its own IMBD page.

They were completely unexpected - we thought we were watching a classic western - and we couldn't fast forward it quick enough to prevent seeing the horrible images of a man being tortured and then axed into two pieces. I can't believe Kurt Russell would be a part of such a disturbing movie. It's a sad statement about the direction in which our culture has gone. I only hope that my review will prevent others from making the mistake of watching this movie. PLEASE do not let your children watch this movie.

The film is compelling enough to hold my attention. There is a segue from classic western to horror about 3/5ths of the way in, which is interesting. Some of the gore seems gratuitous, one scene in particular, but no more so than your typical slasher flick. Some of the dialog fell flat. This ain't Tarantino. But Kurt Russell performs well in this role as avenging sheriff..

One character who intrigued me was "The Professor" - a minor role whose screen time lasts for a single scene. But his character provides an ironic framework within which the story develops. In the midst of the horrors visited by  Native and European populations upon each other, there lurks something far more horrific. The Professor sees it as an almost transcendent evil. He is the only one who can name it. I wish that his character had been developed further.

I decided to watch this movie after hearing Jenkins talk about his dialogue in the film.  I heard the brief clip in an interview with him and thought I'd give it a whirl.  Initially, I was put off by how long it is.  It's very good.  The plot is simple and predictably western in some ways, but with variations.  The woman who is kidnapped is smart and hardly helpless, though clearly overcome as anyone would be by the vicious attackers.  The dialogue is spare and rich; the action is surprisingly graphic but necessary to drive the menacing "reality" of the situation.  It's a parable, and if you see it that way, it's a pleasure to watch.  Jenkins said he chose the film because of the writing, which is an excellent reason to watch it.

Add to that a splash of comedy (albeit dry) and a few surprisingly gruesome scenes and you have a heck of a ride. Watch it...if you like Kurt Russel you won't be disappointed.

Richard Jenkins was a guest on Fresh Air, and this film, Bone Tomahawk was discussed. Jenkins discussed how much he loved making this film. The cast was excellent, the storyline a little bizarre, but what fun they had making it.

Kurt Russell plays the Sherriff Of a small western town, Richard Jenkins his deputy assistant.  One night a stranger comes to town suspicious looking and acting according to the deputy. Sheriff goes to the local bar to have a gander and has to shoot him.  Lili Simmons plays Samantha, the intelligent medical person in the community who comes to care for the injured man. in the morning Samanthas husband played by Patrick Wilson, sees she is missing. He has hurt his leg and is recovering. In. The meant8me Sheriff is notified an assistant in the bar has been murdered. Horses are missing, and Samantha has been abducted. Off go the Sheriff, the deputy, an Indian crazed crack shooter, and thebhusband all go to search for Samantha.

It seems a weird zombie like Indian group is to blame for the abduction, and we enter the eerie zone. Come aboard for the outstanding actors, storyline and excellent written material. Not a fun time, but into the realm of the unexpected. An old time western gone astray, but you won't be disappointed.

Just when you might have thought the Western genre had been pretty thoroughly worked over, along comes "Bone Tomahawk".  The little town of Bright Hope is a peaceful enough cow town, until a thief wanders in, on the run from something bad.  That something bad follows him into Bright Hope, and comes away with the thief, a deputy, and a local medical person, who happens to be a woman.  The local sheriff will mount a rescue mission, one that takes the posse into darkness...

Kurt Russell leads a loaded coast as the sheriff of Bright Hope, duty-bound to track down the kidnappers.  The posse will include the sheriff's aging deputy (Richard Jenkins), a cowboy with a broken leg (Patrick Wilson), and an Indian fighter with much blood on his hands (Matthew Fox).  Together, they will track the kidnappers to a remote valley, avoided even by the local Indians.

The storyline is a Western with a twist, with great dialogue and solid acting.  The movie is gory and extremely gruesome in its violence, and definitely not for kids.  Well-recommended as a Western with a twist.  The DVD has a few extra features.

Bone Tomahawk is the perfect hybrid for those who love Western/Frontier and horror films. No cliche western music, great acting, great story line, and a terrifying encounter with a humanoid clan of beasts. Plus, Kurt Russell is just a bonus.

Bone Tomahawk manages to skirt it's genre schizophrenia by employing the best of every aesthetic.  S. Craig Zahler's warped vision of The Searchers that meets The Road has a self-awareness about it that reveals a sense of pride in not knowing what kind of movie it wants to be. Bone Tomahawk is a rather simple rescue adventure tale that that stays fresh by avoiding the usual bullet-stopped-by-badge clichés and going with nuanced character studies, subtle humor and deft banter. Grizzled sheriff (played by Kurt Russell) recruits a disparate group of men bound by the objective of rescuing a group of villagers abducted by vicious troglodytes. The fact that these savage beings terrorize the town give the film an apocAlyptic tone. As if there is nothing civilized beyond the remote village the characters reside in. Once the four men venture out into the wasteland, a horrific sojourn ensues that gives Deliverance a run for its money.

  Most of the attention given to this movie is over the intense balance of horror and Western, yet the dramatic interaction between the characters is what make it unique. What is so refreshing and lovable about this film is how four men with clashing personalities can come together with such a realistic chemistry.  Every performance in this film is worthy of praise. Russell is his usual one-liner spitting bad ass self ( "I'll slap you til you turn red") while his aging sycophantic deputy (brilliantly portrayed by Richard Jenkins) offers rambling diatribes to ease tensions. Alongside them is the sociopathic, trigger happy alpha male John Brooder (Matthew Fox), who kills without remorse or reflection. His presence is offset by the good boy Christian cowboy Arthur, whose wife is among the kidnapped, played by Patrick Wilson. Arthur tries to recalibrate the moral compass after every perilous situation. What makes Wilson's performance especially good is how physically demanding the role is. He spends the entire film disabled and in excruciating pain.

All in all, Bone Tomahawk is a peculiar film that delivers something for everyone. Taut drama, brutally fun horror and tongue in cheek comedy. Recommended big time!

Bone Tomahawk is well acted.  It has many of the elements of a typical western with the somewhat more recently added moral quandaries  (essentially survival vs. good manners and being a nice guy generally isn't the way to survive the frontier).  The antagonists in this action/horror/thriller are an interesting twist (not even the Native Americans like them so it's okay to fight them without triggering a ton of complaints and griping).  It gets gory (definitely mature content) which will no doubt turn off some, but I don't think they could tell the same story to as good an effect without it.  The gore has purpose and is not, strictly speaking, gratuitous.  Even with the moral quandaries, the new "bad guys", and all, it is, at heart, a gritty western and I found it rather enjoyable.

A nice addition to the western canon. Tomahawk chooses characterization over stylized plots and I enjoyed taking the trip with them. The gruesome action at the end and Kurt Russell beard and performance, as well as Richard Jenkins performance, make this a must-see.

I watched this on Amazon Prime last night and was surprised at the level horrific violence. The acting was terrific, with Kurt Russell and Richard Jenkins stealing the show. Now for a spoiler alert and a critique of some of the elements:
Patrick Wilson's character has a broken tibia (the larger bone of the lower leg.) Apparently, it was a compound fracture, and his wife--an experienced assistant to the town doctor who is never seen since he is also a drunk and indisposed through the events of the film--has been changing his dressing and caring for him back to health while employing a splint that might suffice for transporting a fracture patient a short distance, but certainly not for walking or riding horseback for miles. Anybody with the smallest knowledge of orthopedics would need to suspend disbelief as the film progresses. On the trail to rescue the captives, he suffers a displacement of his fracture, and it is decided by the assistant deputy--played by Richard Jenkins, who served as an Army Medic apparently--to reset this fracture and leave the man to live or die. Gangrene of the open wound fracture site was at one point considered by the medic, but a reset and re-splinting appears to allow the man to walk over rough territory with a crutch for miles, climb into an enemy stronghold and prevail.
The so-called Troglodytes appear to be a band of self-mutilating throwbacks who the local Indian population regard with fear and
loathing. These mud covered warriors carve holes in their cheeks where bore tusks protrude, and have engineered tracheotomies in which they insert animal bones to allow them to produce fearsome calls to one another, and of course, to frighten their enemies. Once again, in a pre-antibiotic world, this would have certainly been a selection process for the strongest immune system.
There is very little evidence that North American Indians, even the poorest of the Great Basin peoples, practiced cannibalism.

Such a good movie even though the the violence is quite disturbing. Messed me up for days. Sorry Quentin, you are not the only sick puppy in town. Gross violence aside, it was great. Kurt Russell....there is a reason my sister named her son Russell.... Jack Burton.

For me, the turning point happened when the setting changed in the third Act, and isolated cave-dwellers were shown using jail cells to hold their prisoners, whom they had kidnapped from a jail cell. It lost all meaning when the Sheriff coaxed the cave-dwellers to take his opium, and they all take turns drinking from his flask, leading to a rescue attempt - making me feel like I had wasted my time watching the movie up to that point.

Movies these days have such potential, but they fall short of being something I'll ever watch again because they have no real substance. This one is a perfect example.  Things happened, and then the movie was over.  That's it.  I will forget the majority of this movie, but I'll remember I've seen it and never feel inclined to watch it again because there was no real depth to it.  There was struggle, and a good enemy to fight. The odds favored the enemy, and there was personal struggle.  Great.  But there's a depth to the old movies that isn't seen anymore, and that's why this movie will be forgotten soon after you watch it.  The acting was good, the story was decent, the struggles seemed real, and the gnarly parts were believable.  BUT, it didn't draw anything out of you like a well written movie does.  I didn't want to see the indians die.  I didn't WANT them to be punished for what they did.  I didn't fear for the ones who were abducted.  I just sat, mostly bored, and saw things happen.  Then it ended.

Not a fan of Westerns but I do like variations on the genre. Despite the title and picture on the preview, there is little that is formulaic about this Western. A small town encounters a rogue Indian tribe that engages is cannibalism and makes eerie growling noises. Sounds weird, right? It could be a totally cheesy, tropey movie. But instead there is gradual character development, suspense, desperation, unexpected gore, and an ending that leaves questions unanswered. Definitely leaves room for a sequel wide open. I liked Matthew Fox as the gunslinger (thought Timothy Oliphant, their first choice, would've worked better in that part). I thought Zahn McClarnon (Talltrees the Indian) could've played a bigger role and added a dimension to the plot. For example, what if the cannibal tribe chief was his cursed brother, exiled from the tribe and forced to live with his family and friends for engaging in cannibalism? Instead of men distanced from their own humanity (as a cannibal). the tribe is made into something akin to horror movie monsters, complete with growls, covered faces, and no discernable speech. Pretty good as a weekend movie night thriller, but definitely not for kids.
I really liked this movie. Interesting plot. Not politically correct. Do not expect to see any 'Noble Savages' in this film.

There's a lot of surprise to be had with this film, found in the interesting genre blend and the surprising amount of character depth.

With the blood and gore advertised as being over-the-top (it is actually tolerable until one, horrifying moment), I did not expect the pace to be what it was. The scenes dawdle, the conversations last longer than the shootouts, and the dialogue felt period appropriate and exceptionally well written. A 'slow' movie can be a bad one if not done properly, and Bone Tomahawk is a prime example of a film that makes each scene feel necessary and, more importantly, interesting to watch.

The characters and the performances make it so. While their titles are expected given the genre (sheriff, deputy, gentleman, town doctor, etc.), each one is fill out well by the writing and the actors portraying them. Kurt Russell is great, but every actor is worth noting in terms of the quality of their performance.

The first scene sets the stage, but it wasn't exactly the greatest first impression. The gore and horror, while not nearly as much as I expected, was effective and nauseating when certain scenes transpire.

I highly recommend this film!

I was surprised to see so many negative reviews on amazon. I have to say this really was a movie which told a story (shocking in this day of age) as opposed to most modern movies that use the format to simply dangle sex, explosions and cheap thrills in front of a slack jawed audience. I don't understand why so many people consider this movie to be slow-paced, as the entire time I was enthralled by the characters' emotions, interactions, and what was an obvious well developed lead up to a shocking and horrible climax. This movie took the time to actually develop the characters. Four men go on a long and dangerous journey to rescue a woman and deputy from a clan of cave dwelling natives, knowing that they have little chance to succeed. On the way they battle the elements in an uncharted and unmapped western frontier, are attacked by bandits only to lose their horses and supplies, and yet bravely continue on foot through the unforgiving landscape. Meanwhile, one of the men (the young woman's husband) is fighting a dangerous infection from a previous injury. The movie contains humor, adventure, drama, romance, and yes, horrific violence for those who are squeamish. In fact, the scene most reviewers are talking about is pretty difficult to watch and for those of you that have a hard time with that kind of thing should definitely avoid this movie, as it is shocking and graphic. But it is certainly horrifying and spine tingling, which is apparently what the director was going for. I watch a lot of foreign and independent films which carry no real ratings, at least, not the kind we have in the United States, and many times I see shocking things, but this still bothered me. So no kids or faint hearted in the room when this movie is on!

Maybe Lili Simmons and Sean Young were a little weak, but everyone else was on fire. Re-watchability is sky-high - James Tolkan from "Back to the Future" tears up his 30 seconds of piano player screen time and never plays a note!!! - and you'll love the characters and the subtle interactions even more. A slow burn western that reminds every man what honor is. I cried several times while simultaneously being so full of rage that I cried for my own redemption. If anyone out there watching is a Stephen king reader and has read the dark tower; whenever Roland refers to the face of his father that is what every man in this movie strives to remember. Its a western it moves slow and the dialogue is meaningful. Its a beautiful bloody tale of revenge and redemption. What you have to remember is its not how you live its really how you die that matters. And every single character dies with honor. I salute them and what they poured into this movie. Well done. What a hauntingly beautiful narrative. It is Kurt Russel at his best, and it is a bloody, violent ride start to finish. Enjoy on a light stomach a movie that is not for the light hearted.

Just a train wreck. For a while I thought it might just be campy, but then you could tell even the actors began reading their lines not campily, but disdainfully. At times I thought they must have just been overwhelmed by the stupidity of the director. In some ways, the script is reminiscent of 13th Warrior, in that the heroes confront a very primitive group of flesh eaters. Some of the gore in this is top-notch. When the cannibals split the deputy, I just had to look away. But all-in-all, the film is just awful. How did they get these well-regarded...some iconic even...actors to do this one? The thing also feels edited to a conclusion that was the best the editors could do..as if a bunch of the story wasn't filmed. And this is 1891. There was no frontier, anymore. There were no savage Injuns left. Even Geronimo was a ghost of the past. So this film just feels unintelligently placed in time.

The one I read did actually mentioned something about "savage cannibalism".  Should the director always leave the gruesome stuff to your imagination. Excellent combination of the western genre and horror similar to the Hills Have Eyes. It is a very contained story and short, but the characters are very well played and grounded. The initial build-up is powerful, generating much suspense over what the true horrific nature of the savages they face. It culminates with shocking, brutal violence that isn't a gorefest, but manages to drive home the disgusting reality of the situation. Perhaps this is why it works so well for me. Over the top gore is not scary, it's comical. But here it's realistic, the sound design carries it even if you only get a shadowy glimpse of the actual acts carried out. Very impressive work that makes me surprised seeing the ratings on Amazon are relatively low. Upon reading them it appears to be mainly from squeamish folks that expected a typical western shoot em up or dreary cowboy drama. Not a lot of decent low reviews that give more than a single sentence for their reasoning. It's too bad those fools can't appreciate this movie for how good it is. Slow and tense is how horror should be, and subverting expectations from a fast paced cowboy action movie is why is works so well.

An entertaining blend of western and horror, with probably about 80% of the screentime being western, and 20% being horror.  Much of the film feels like a traditional man-on-a-mission western, but the horror scenes, while limited, are quite intense and gory.  The plot is a solid B-movie tale, where an inbred clan of cannibal Indians, feared by the local tribes for centuries, attacks a village and kidnaps a man's wife.  The husband (Wilson), the sheriff (Russell), and old Indian fighter with an axe to grind (Fox), and an elderly deputy (Jenkins) go in pursuit and things get intense.  If you appreciate well-done pulp tales or B-movies, you'll probably like this.  Russell owns the screen as a middle-aged sheriff, the man can act.  Richard Jenkins also does a great job portraying a tired, grieving deputy who only has his job because he's friends with the sheriff, but is willing to do his best at it all-the-same.  The interplay between Jenkins and Russell gives depth to their characters you don't expect in this type of movie.  Wilson did well as a determined husband, though his character was a little one-note.  Fox's character is meant to be somewhat unlikeable, but still has some depth and even a spark of decency to him in the end.  Not a film for the squeamish, but still an entertaining blend of horror and western.

Oh my God this was such a good movie, if you're a fan of westerns or cannibals or old man Curt Russell being a strait bad ass you need to see this film. 10/10. The whole movie you're on the edge of your seat, its tense as you expect the worst to happen to characters that you are introduced to and in turn feel concern for because of the fine dialog and acting on display here. I cannot believe it took me so long to see this film I cannot recommend this enough as a fan of horror, westerns and dramas I feel this movie kills it mixing all of these in a potent package.

The movie is savage.  I read one review that gave it a low rating.  The person claimed he/she loves westerns, but thought this movie was too savage.  Grow up, I say!  So, in other words he/she likes it when people get shot, but there's not blood, and they just conveniently fall to the ground peacefully dead.  Well, real killing isn't like that, and this film captures the true gore involved such affairs.

Basically, this movie does for westerns, what Saving Private Ryan did for war movies.  Saying you like westerns, but don't like this movie - because it's too gorey, is like saying you like war movies, but don't like "Saving Private Ryan" because the Omaha Beach scene is just too bloody!

Now, having said that ... this movie will stick with you.  Don't let your kids watch it.  There are scenes in this movie you will never forget, so if you can't stomach that level of gore, then - fine - don't watch it, but I think you should anyhow.  I think everyone should force themselves to watch it.  It reminds what you what it means to be human.  I'll let you ponder that thought.  ;)

And why Shane and Lonesome Dove are 2 of the best...This movie really dragged on in places and the list of "stupidity" the characters exhibited was startling. Who wrote this script? Four seasoned cowboys yet they make several obviously avoidable mistakes - the life and death kind. Not very realistic. The gore at the end was the most memorable moment. The movie is very indie in its production and its abrupt narrative. No introductions, no character backgrounds, no obligatory romantic subplot, just very terse dialogue and some tense scenes that invoke real fear. Has a similar feel to other indie westerns like Ravenous and The Proposition.  Very unconventional and authentic and lean.  Every scene is perfectly to the point.  The abrupt ending makes you realize the film was never trying to tell a story or tie up any loose ends. The gore is purposeful and appropriate for the subject matter.  If you are going to use a weapon in a movie, have the integrity to show exactly what kind of damage it can do to a real person.  We could use a little more reality and a little less Hollywood in our perception of violence.  It may make some of us less apt to be violent.

An incredibly well-paced film that also has the highest quantity of gore wile still remaining tasteful. This will not please anyone looking for a standard western, nor will it please anyone looking for a hack-and-slash gore fest. But this will please the discriminating film-goer looking for a thoughtful and manly story about a group of flawed but lovable characters trying to succeed against a savage and evil opponent. A few terrible bit-part players jeopardize this film which relies so heavily on the credibility it builds, but a fantastic lead and supporting cast (Chicory is simply the best!) do more than simply save the day; they make it one to cherish. Rarely has a movie convinced me to care as much as this. If you have patience and a love for realistic, brutal encounters, you will love this film.

PS: This might be Kurt Russel's best performance since The Thing.

Once upon a time, horror movies were supposed to be merely bone-chillingly frightening. But The Master changed that with "Psycho". (He got away with it because the Shower Scene is a work of genius (two geniuses, actually).) Nowadays, if a horror film doesn't induce vomiting, it's no good.

Craig Zahler apparently decided that a horror Western was just what the world needed ("Ravenous" is the only other example I can think of), * and came up with "Bone Tomahawk". Besides having no discernible historical or mythological point, it suffers from two major problems. One is the perennially drab Kurt Russell. The other is Zahler's failure to understand pacing. The entire film is deliberate (and arguably mannered), to no point. Too many scenes run on too long (Zahler is in love with his admittedly smart dialog), and the "chase" sequence -- running nearly an hour -- is so devoid of tension or urgency, it's no surprise some viewers (myself included) nearly fall asleep.

Mr Zahler should study the first act of "Die Walkure", He'll learn a lot about directing.

You are warned. The horror scenes are indeed horrifying. The worst of these is ridiculously unbelievable, but not in a comic or cathartic way. Had I sat on the ratings board, I would likely have pressed for NC-17.

* Some of John Meston's "Gunsmoke" scripts are arguably horror stories, especially "No Hands".

This film is excellent for anyone who grew up with Westerns, but enjoys modern film elements. The majority of the film follows amazing western tropes like a ragtag group of men from different walks of life adventuring together towards a common goal. The dry humor of Westerns is definitely present throughout the entirety of the film with great lines like, "I am far too vain to ever live as a cripple."

The other part of the film has an uneasy horror feel that becomes cringeworthy at times. All in all, the film hits all the right notes to be a great western and a great horror film. If one starts this film with the feeling that they are watching a spaghetti western, they will likely not enjoy this film. It does deal with the true terrors of life out in the old west. Fear being a major hurdle for many. As a character says, stupidity of some being the hardest part of living out west. I love the performances of the characters and the little details that drive home the gritty feel of this film.

This movie is a strange one.  When it first starts out it is unique in its old western qualities, all of which have great detail and authenticity.  This includes the actors and their dialogue, set, buildings, location.  Next are the characters.  They are well done and interesting.  Strange, but interesting, almost endearing.  The story didn't seem to fit exactly but no harm, lets go along with it as I like the old west and these characters.  The story then unfolds and we have moral issues, leadership dynamics, struggle, pain, perseverance, etc.  Story continues good albeit slow but with purpose. I want to know what is going to happen and curious how they will succeed.  Then we get to the meat of the conflict, pun intended.  This is where things got very gory, violent and out of place.  The story was a let down at this point.  Unrealistic.  It pulled me out of what was good about this movie and into a grade B horror flick.  I finished regardless but was essentially disappointed.

I'm not going to go into a lot of detail because there isn't a lot to talk about.  There wasn't much of a story, nor was it unpredictable.  The 'good'?  The cast.  For what appeared to be a fairly low-budget production (...not implying that is a negative), this must be where they spent their money.  The main cast was more than competent.  Kurt is always a solid performer and never disappoints (...not unlike Jeff Bridges!).  That is probably the only reason I gave it a watch....plus it has a decent title (which is very important, imo).

The 'bad':  There's two things in particular, I found distracting or downright annoying.  First, there's no music in the move...none whatsoever...as in no musical score.  While this isn't automatically a bad thing, I found it distracting because it is so uncommon in cinema, that I noticed it right away.  It could have been a stylistic choice (which I applaud if it somehow edifies the proceedings) or it could have been because the filmmakers couldn't afford it (haha).  Who knows!?  The other thing....the thing that just didn't make good sense, yet, seemed to be the centerpiece of the entire film....was the lame husband (yes, literally lame) who's wife is kidnapped by "troglodytes" and must be rescued - which is also the entire plot of the movie.

So, this guy, apparently has a broken leg - which is barely explained - and we (the viewers) have to watch this poor bastard hobbling around with ONE crutch, on a 5-day journey, pursuing his wife's kidnappers (the cavemen).  This is portrayed in excruciating detail - particularly after the posse's horses are stolen halfway through their journey and they have to walk the remaining miles.  Of course this was only minutes of the movie but I swear to the gods, it felt like I was watching this guy (and he was alone for much of it, so all attention was on him) crossing a desert in REAL TIME.  Yes, it was that painfully dull.

What was the significance of this?  Why did this character HAVE to have a broken leg?  I don't know!  I failed to see how the story was either changed or enhanced, as a result.  At any rate, I found it pointless and annoying.  They could have had the character doing more interesting activities, instead of scene after scene of him struggling and grimacing and falling down and crawling and on and on.  gd.

If you are a tremendous fan of Kurt Russell, you probably won't be disappointed.  However, I recommend "Hateful Eight" over this title - both of which came out around the same time.  The two characters and subsequent fates are eerily similar.  And I almost forgot to mention, the goofy song that you hear during the credits 'crawl' is probably the best thing about the movie.  The lyrics and the vocals are indeed unexpectedly humorous.

I think some of the negative ratings for this movie are because people failed to read that it is not a true western movie, it is a thriller/horror set in the time of a classic western. The film keeps you on edge and in suspense even during scenes shot in daylight. Though I enjoyed the movie and would recommend it to others who are interested in the thriller/horror genre, the ending felt quite rushed. There was significant and enjoyable buildup but it seemed to be wrapped up in 5 minutes which was quite disappointing.

Kurt Russell as a Sherriff was very fitting and the whole cast was amazing. Patrick Wilson was great as the husband who will go through hell and back to rescue his wife. Matthew Fox was great and had his moments where you couldn't tell whether he was a good guy but he has a defining moment. The Backup Deputy was a great character. I feared for him throughout the whole movie because he was an older man, and I was scared something was going to happen to him every moment! The ending was amazing and very realistic and didn't end as a typical Hollywood movie. I highly recommend this movie!

You've got better things to do. No, really, I don't know you but you certainly have something better to do. You will never regain the lost time you will spend watching this. You may have some thoughts, and I'll address each in turn:

1. This might be one of those movies that is so bad, it's good, right? False. While I can appreciate the so bad it's good type of movie, this just left me sad.

2. Kurt Russell is in this, so it HAS to be good, right? I mean he was in Big Trouble in Little China after all...  False. Even the great Kurt Russell could not save this film.

3. At least I'll find out what the heck a 'Bone Tomahawk' is, right? False. That's what I thought too, but I'm still vague on the topic.

4. I'm in the mood for a Western.  False - You are thinking, how can I say false to an emphatic statement? Trust me. False.

5. At least we'll get to hear some great slasher / horror film music and composition, right? False. This is a strange one, as that would be the low hanging fruit of the genre, but this music is almost completely devoid of ambient sounds or a soundtrack. I'm thinking they either forgot about music, or ran out of money hiring Mr. Russell, and had to make sacrifices.

I have to admit this was a great western. The acting was superb. Russell, Jenkins, Fox, Wilson were all excellent and the supporting cast were all great, too. Cinematography was outstanding, dialogue, direction, everything was what you would hope for and the story was mesmerizing, as well. However, I have to say that I will not recommend this movie to anyone. There is a scene near the end of the film that's so horrific, I'm sure it will haunt me for quite a long time. My personal opinion is that it didn't absolutely need to be there, or at least be so graphically presented. So, be forewarned, you'll love this flick, if you like great westerns, but be prepared to be sickened by the graphic violence of at least one scene.

I am a sucker for modern Westerns. I love them all, including Kurt Russell in Tombstone. But Bone Tomahawk is terrible on every level. Bad acting, dialogue, script, pace, length, premise. Instead of a more realistic reaction of horror referencing decades of psychotherapy to follow. Finally, if cannibals ever lock me in a cage to eat me later, I will immediately kill myself, not wait to be rescued. Zero stars.

Good acting, mediocre plot, but the concept of the "enemy" is way off and points in the direction of the "other" that is hostile, misunderstood, without morality, and foreign. The story has a crew of "western" town folk retaliating against a perceived enemy that is unknown, even by the token town Native American, and must be brought to justice and eliminated. This is a movie that treats the "other" as an assumed threat without regard for the difference expressed throughout all cultures of humanity. Gratuitous acts of violence do not convince a public of moral outcomes, but rather exhibit a lack of respect and understanding of difference that exist throughout a world of cultures and practices that are not based in Christianity.  This is a plot with a shallow story line that presents an enemy as an alien who is not of the earth, without regard for humanity, and who is completely foreign as a biological being (not unlike a harmful bacterium or virus).  Good line up of actors, but incredibly poor story line. Why did these actor sign up for an ill-conceived movie is beyond me, especially given the low budget for its production. The screen writer needs to find another line of work...

I won't spoil the movie. Just to say that I wondered where the title came from before I bought this one on blu ray.  It wasn't Kurt Russell's character's nick name. It wasn't how hard indians drove a tomahawk into flesh.  It was actually never mentioned in the entire movie. The only hint was watching other characters using a tomahawk made of bone late in the story.  That's all I'll say except that I thought this movie was really good. Unusual. The story was great. The acting was too.  And the filming was super.  So, if you want a good and intense movie to watch, ignore any bone - headed bad ratings. I have no idea what those ratings are about. I read several reviews and frankly it boggles my mind, the ability of some folks to suspend their disbelief with regard to the connection between the plot and the dialogue.  I'm sorry, but just for one example, if a person has been kidnapped and held in a cave for several days by bizarre inhuman cannibalistic savages who don't even have a language but instead perform some sort of bizarre surgery on their vocal cords in order to make horrific sounds (the overt PC move to make us root for the white guys and not feel bad about them slaughtering indians btw), and, rather than being severely traumatized by an experience beyond most people's worst nightmares, she is almost casually conversant enough when her would-be rescuers arrive to insult them for being stupid in their tactics, well, I'm out at that point. I really tried. I hung in there for a while.  But this movie went full on stupid at that point and had nothing really to redeem it in terms of earlier character development, cinematography, acting, scriptwriting...nope.  Two stars are for being a western and I want hollywood types to keep trying as I love westerns when they're good; otherwise, it would have been one star.  I should have just watched Lonesome Dove for the 10th time. Oh well.

All around a very good cast that made the most of a very strange story.  I always like Kurt Russel's work. Richard Jenkins is always very good, Patrick Wilson is always very good. I am not as familiar with Matthew Fox, but he was very effective, as well. Zahn McLarnon was terribly underused, though, and he was not a main character in the story anyway. I just like him. He is superb in Longmire and Fargo. A horror influenced Western that never quite got over the improbability of its antagonists. Be that as it may, the acting was spot on, the mood was really ominous and I was caught up in the climactic scenes. Though the denouement felt a tad empty because I began to wonder about plausibility of the situation itself. If I tell too much about the antagonists, it may spoil the story. Their mysterious nature is both a plus in the film as well as a drawback.  These bad guys are definitely creepy and interesting. A really were a scary bunch. There was very little information about them outside of the fact that they were not civilized, or moral. Where they came from and what might influence them was never articulated, which made them seem implausible to me. I am nitpicking a touch, but the lack of detail about the antagonists, while supporting the horror aspects (what are they, how far will they go, will they be defeated!!??) it kept me a little outside of  the action. However, the Western setting, the genre crossover, and the acting were well put together, very well done.  All in all, a good movie.

From the beginning you know real bad things are going to happen.  Stumbling into an Indian graveyard results in bad things.  We've all seen it in western movies.  Stumble into an Indian troglodyte graveyard, see your buddy get slaughtered, travel on foot for a week, get shot by the sheriff in a small frontier town and get thrown in jail is nothing compared to getting eaten by Indian troglodytes who followed and kidnapped him, as well as taking the local female doctor who was tending to his wounds, and the deputy.  The doctor's husband with a broken leg, the sheriff, his over the hill deputy, and a self professed Indian killer were the posse that went to save the doctor and deputy.  Half of the movie was their multi-day trek to rescue these people with the kind of talk you might expect from a frontier cowboy, a gunslinger, and sheriff and his aging deputy on a camping trip with a mission such as this.  One such conversation was when they were bedding down for the night and the deputy asked the sheriff if he ever reads while taking a bath.  The sheriff takes his time to formulate and answer and says he doesn't read in the bathtub.  The deputy says he tried it a few times but the book gets wet from his fingers turning the pages and sometimes he drops it in the water and ruins the book.  After a rather lengthy pause, the sheriff suggests he get a music stand to put the book on, close to the tub.  You can order one from the local store if they don't have one.  You should have a towel on the side of the tub to dry your fingers to turn the pages.  This was a satisfactory solution for the deputy and they went to sleep.  That whole camping trip was filled with little quips like that mixed with the kind of conversation you might expect from a mix of people like that.  It was slow paced for a number of reasons.  For one, it turned out to be an interesting character study, a genre seldom used in modern movies because of the time it takes for proper character development.  Two, it gave a sense of authenticity.  These are small town frontier folks who never experience anything more raucous than rowdy cowboys or the occasional drifter, who the sheriff shoots in the leg if they try to get away, which seems to be what the lady doctor fixes most.  Three, this slow pace sets you up for the extreme horror these guys get to experience that they are totally unprepared for.  It lulls you into a sense that these guys might actually have a chance to kills some Indians and save the girl.  You, as the audience, know better because you saw lots of horror movies and you know what Jason or Leatherface can do.  Let me tell ya, Jason is a punk compared to these Indian troglodytes and they'd have Leatherface for dinner, literally.  I mean, these guys walk into a real horror show they never expected.  The execution scene is particularly cringe-worthy and forced me to reevaluate my least favorite way to die.  I gave it five stars because it felt like Zane Grey on some really bad acid.

I thoroughly enjoyed it!  I hold a BS in Physical Anthropology, which may explain why I really like movies that explore the idea of what happens when you have an isolated human population that heads off on a different evolutionary trajectory.  Other movies that looked at this were The Descent and Pandorum.  It does require some suspension of disbelief as the time scale for evolutionary change is really much longer than would have to be the case in this movie or The Descent (understanding the migration patterns into the new world occured only around 15,000 years ago).  Pandorum does cleverly account for rapid evolution and for that it is definitely my favorite (I won't spoil it for you).  Nevertheless, this is a very respectable addition to this sub-genre and worth a watch if you aren't opposed to a small amount of pretty explicit gore.
