This film would have made  a bad 30 minute TV series episode, but because the public and the critics must love to have plenty of garbage hurled at their eyeballs simply because " we like Kurt Russell" this sad tale went on and on. Lili Simmons performance was dreadful, but to be fair she and her fellow actors had to regurgitate the dialog written by S. Craig Zahler who also directed this film. To drag this film into a toilet a big as the wild west itself  we get to meet the "troglodytes" who are the villains in this train wreck. So Sci-fi meets western?...try again. How this movie earned the ratings it received on R.T. should open up  congressional hearings on the decline of American taste. I hated this movie..but you may like it if you think farts don't smell "that bad".

A friend of mine asked if I liked westerns and suggested I watch this movie. I really don't remember watching a movie this bad in a very long time. In my opinion, acting was not good at all; In many scenes, I felt as if I was watching a play at my son's school. Also, there were many gory and graphic scenes that belong in a horror movie (a guy being cut in half by a machete and then eaten etc...). Pretty disgusting. I cannot believe Kurt Russell agreed to be in this movie.

Combine good wardrobe and set design, decent acting and dialogue, and absolutely ham-fisted writing, and you get a moderately watchable horror/western that's probably better than nothing if you've got some time to kill. I have to say, however, that I feel like an actor of Kurt Russell's talent is wasted on this film. Without giving away too much of the plot, there are too many wildly unrealistic events, unexplained details, and minor plot lines going absolutely nowhere. Most characters are profoundly one-dimensional and development is weak at best. If all you're looking for is a few cheap thrills and some gratuitous violence/gore, Bone Tomahawk should get the job done. But if you're looking for much more than that, I suggest you keep looking.

No time for a lengthy review now, but  I found this movie to be an interesting commentary about  life (and death) in the history of the American west.  Much of the script and talented acting was devoted to the enchanting dialogue between people at different levels of the hierarchy of a small town in the old west, and, particularly, the struggles of a small party of four men who form a rescue party for victims of an Indian raid and kidnapping.  BUT, make no mistake, if a potential viewer is at all sensitive about seeing human brutality and body mutilation, DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE.  This is not a western filmed in the tradition of a classic John Wayne or similar family movie.  The journey taken by the four heroes who strive to rescue the helpless victims leads them to a prehistoric savage commune where animal-like humans intimidate, torture and consume their prisoners; and the film depicts much of these activities in gruesome detail.  The story is actually believable, but shows a side of man's transition from wild beasts to civilized souls that most
people today would not care to think about.

Hollywood regurgitates the same tropes year after year with dazzling special effects, car chases, and explosions. There are many Indie films which promise much, but are not big screen fare and often disappointing. Most movies I have seen over the years are easily forgettable. Perhaps it is true that Hollywood is more concerned with churning out product for the lucrative international market.
On rare occasion there is a project shot outside the "system" on a shoestring budget that TRULY DELIVERS. Because Kurt Russell believed in the director, he was able to deliver a stellar performance in a really good albeit haunting movie. Bone Tomahawk has exceptional production value. The dialogue fits the characters and the period. This movie is proof positive that it doesn't take a gazillion dollars to make an entertaining and provocative film. It may disturb some viewers as there is a horror element, but not in the Freddy Kruger or Jason vein that launched so many weak franchises.
I am trying to wrap my head around the negative reviews for Bone Tomahawk and came up with a list of objections,
1) perhaps westerns are not for everybody
2) maybe an intriguing plot and period accurate characterization are not to some people's liking
3) realism and violence are not everyone's cup of tea
4) the viewing public is jaded by the Marvel Universe
5) America is becoming a nation of juvenile sheep unable to accept originality
Whatever a person's reservation, Bone Tomahawk is a cut above normal Hollywood fare. Thank you Amazon for making this a Prime offering. I just hope Zahler gets to make another movie, I would go see it in a heartbeat.
A word of caution:
My older brother let me tag along to the drive-in to see the b&w version of Night of the Living Dead, which gave me nightmares for the next decade. S. Craig Zahler could leave a similar indelible impression as George Romero, so I would caution against consumption by younger viewers.

I don't watch a lot of movies but my wife and I sat down to watch this one the other night. I picked it for being a western and having Kurt Russell in it. It had a lot of hand held camera work that makes you seem like you are there. A little different to me. I thought they exaggerated some of the sounds such as horses galloping. It made me want to duck for cover. Turned out to be a different kind of western I wasn't expecting. Actually a pleasant surprise.

While I tend to hate gore -- this movie truly kept me captivated because of the real-life-like dialogs between each characters -- I almost felt like I was eavesdropping a "real situation" - loved their colorful language "I'll slap you red!" quoted from the sheriff (Kurt Russell) who did real well considering that he wasn't too set in his typical 80's movies he made. I couldn't trace any hints of Kurt Russell - I really saw just the "sheriff".  I thought the ending would be tragic but (spoiler alert) it was a relief that it actually had a good ending but I wished it lasted a little longer.  There were few surprises as I'm usually really good at predicting what happens to each characters but I was thrown off a few time which is refreshing. So well done to the director/writer.

Absolutely brilliant movie reminiscent of character driven thrillers of the 1970s: slow paced, superbly acted, intelligent and calculated writing--loved the dialog. I found it refreshing next to the now common high-octain-ADHD-edited shallow format of most movies in this genre today. I was surprised by the the impact of this story and still remain haunted. I agree it is not for the faint of heart. The gruesome nature of one scene made "The Walking Dead" look tame. I have been a fan of horror since the early 1970s and this was the first time I actually gagged. I don't, however, consider this violence gratuitous much in the same way with the Walking Dead. It succeeds in grabbing your empathy by the throat and reminding you how extremely outraged to feel the next time you hear of a beheading in the news. Let's hope there's not a next time of course.

I'm trying to avoid spoilers here so I'll sum it up by saying Bone Tomahawk does start with quite a bit of early intrigue which pulls you in for the first quarter of the movie. The middle half of the movie, however, is painfully dragged out.  The early intrigue is completely spent as the heroes travel a dull and predictable journey to their final conflict. Any suspense during their travels seems forced and unconvincing.  It left my wife and I, die hard fans of the Western genre, checking the clock wondering when they were going to wrap things up.  The movie ends with a fairly brutal and disgusting climax for our protagonists. We found ourselves wanting to care for the survivors, but those that did were some of the least inspiring characters throughout the movie.  Would not watch it again, and we rewatch many Westerns.  If you are into the genre, it may be worth giving it a try.  Otherwise, I think you may be disappointed.

This is a unique film that kept me drawn in the whole way through.  My wife agreed that it was slow, but it was compelling nonetheless.  It's kind of a western, kind of a horror film, kind of a journey film--not exactly any of these but with elements of all of them that when put together almost is like a stage play.  Yes, there is a lot of dialogue--often very simple day to day talk--but that was something I liked.  The dialogue is often smart, witty, and something that made me think.  The actors deliver well on all accounts.

If you're looking for action or gore, you'll get small doses but probably not enough to satisfy the hard core fans of those genres.  This is a more cerebral film that provides insight into the characters and the nature of the pioneer stock that forged the United States of America.  What we get is just basically regular folk in a harsh land where often not much of note happens, but when bad things come upon them they just had to deal with things the best they can.

This is a great commentary on the spirit of the American West with a talk softly and carry a stick--a big one if you have it--but anything you got will do.  Patient western fans should find this film at least moderately enjoyable.  This is a film that will stick with me for a while.

This movie is fantastic! I thought I was in for a dramatic western, then when I started watching it there was a lighthearted comedic feel to it. The humor in this film is priceless and the acting is great. It was nothing that I was expecting and I couldn't have loved it more. There isn't much violence in the movie, but when it happens it is BRUTAL! I'm serious, if you are at all disturbed by violence then beware. The violence is hardcore and the cannibals are scary! This movie has everything as far as I'm concerned. Great writing, great actors, great character development, great story, and great horror elements. I will be watching this movie over and over again for sure. Maybe my sense of humor is twisted, but I love, love, loved it. To get a sense of what you're in for, there is a scene near the end where a few of the characters have been taken captive by the cannibal tribe, and one of them starts talking about a flea circus that came through town and whether or not it was real or a scam. I mean...I can't imagine anyone not loving this movie, so you should definitely watch it and find out!

Sometimes I find myself scratching my head in wonderment when I think a movie is downright awesome in every respect and I read other mediocre or low rated reviews. I guess I wonder how people fail to recognize great acting, authentic sets and costumes, terrific musical scores and an original story-line, all of which Bone Tomahawk has in spades. Maybe others aren't as critical as I am, especially when it comes to Westerns set in the 1800s. Maybe others don't appreciate how rare it is for a director and producers to pay attention to so many fine details...and get them right.
As good as I think Bone Tomahawk comes off, it does come with a distinct gore-warning in one scene. You may have to look away. One of the characters is split in two pieces by cannibles while he is still alive. I'm pretty hardened off to gore but had to squeeze my eyes shut during that sequence and wish it had been left on the cutting room floor during editing. Other than that one scene, if you like Westerns put this one on your watch list.

Kurt Russell stars in this action packed return to the western movie genre. It's about time Hollywood got back to this. IGN says this film has "great dialogue, strong characters, and imaginative and memorable kills." Cannibals kidnap some homesteaders and the local sheriff does not like that at all! You guessed it! It turns into a very violent feud that will please the inner animal in all of us. Stars from Tombstone, Lost, Hateful Eight, Insidious, and Cabin in the Woods are all featured in this star-studded brutality fest! This movie is rated 13+ for violence, meaning about PG-13 to R. Enjoy!

If I had to use one word to describe the film, Bone Tomahawk, it would be rare. Few films have the ability to make you think about them days after viewing. Even fewer have the ability to successful blend genres in the way this one did. The more I thought about it later, the more I appreciated what the filmmakers were attempting to accomplish. The number one criticism many people have today of Hollywood is a lack of originality and fresh ideas. This film appears to start out as a typical Western, but changes into something else. Many reviewers have called it a Western/Horror, yet I don't believe the intention was to simply shock or terrify viewers in a gratuitous way. This film took several familiar forms to structure itself, yet ended up creating something entirely unique. I loved that about it.
This film also made me go back and analyze the details in it. The dialogue should be textbook for anyone who wants to understand how to best use it. There are very few wasted lines, and the cast could not have been better. Kurt Russell is great in almost everything, and this is no exception. The cast is portrayed in a way that perfectly balances the group and adds a sense of realism to what you're watching. The emotional connections are spot on. The rancher's blind determination to seek out his wife, who represents his entire world. The small town sheriff who approaches his tasks with equal measure of pragmatism and grit. The simple minded back-up deputy who blissfully finds purpose in his duty and everyday insights. The bachelor gunslinger who is devoid of emotional bonds due to a lifetime of empty vengeance. When the actions and dialogue of the characters remains as true as in this film, it makes for seamless storytelling.
I would be remiss if I did not mention the violence in the film. It certainly sets it apart from both Westerns and Horror movies. Westerns are never this honest with violence and horror movies are never so precise. I found this combination to be hugely effective. We are set up for a Western movie and would never expect the level of violence which occurs in the final third of the film. The characters in the story who lived their lives in the peaceful town of 'Bright Hope' would never expect to have to endure what they end up witnessing. This is why it was so much more effective to me. The western frontier was not some idyllic, picturesque wilderness speckled with quaint wooden towns. Most people died in the spaces between those towns attempting to cross a dangerous, unpredictable, and unforgiving landscape. The Troglobytes were a personification of this realistic savagery, which made them all the more horrific and impactful.
If you enjoy realistic movies which live a bit outside the box, Bone Tomahawk is worth the watch.

This film shocked me. And I mean that in the the most complimentary of ways. With a budget of less than two million dollars, director and writer, S. Craig Zahler, created what was, in my opinion, the best film of 2015. The writing was taut, realistic and gritty. The acting phenomenal, and the bad guys disturbing as hell. Shockingly good! Mr. Zahler, you've made me love Westerns again. I recommend this film regularly to friends and acquaintances, and have no intention of stopping. More please!

This movie was recommended by a close friend and was all she claimed it to be.  Chilling, mystifying, and humorous in a few spots when comic relief was needed.  That does not happen often but welcomed when it came.  We have watched it only once and, as also recommended, will do so again very soon.  As often happens, we are sure we will gain more from the second viewing than the overall shocking "Did that just happen or did I imagine it?" feeling.  This is a keeper and one we recommend to anyone liking this genre.

It was tough to watch, but it is probably the most realistic cowboy and Indian movie I've ever seen. Mutilation was common among all Indian tribes, but even the most violent tribes were scared of the cannibal tribes. They were spoken of, but avoided. Kurt Russell gave an excellent performance, as well as the other actors. The only one who didn't pull her weight, was the woman they went to rescue. She could use a couple more acting lessons, before doing another film (which is why I only gave it 4 stars). A good level of suspense is kept throughout the film. I was disappointed in the ending, until I heard the gunshots. You go, Kurt Russell! Well done.

[Bone Tomahawk is one of those films that apparently go way over some people's heads. If you don't like movies that deliberately take viewers into deep water, challenging them with a Neo-Western-Horror that tosses no lines or floatation devices, forcing them to swim... don't watch it. If you didn't like it, fine. But these barely literate 'reviews' with less than 50 words don't help anyone. If you can't throw together a couple paragraphs to explain your rating, what you liked or disliked -- don't bother posting at all. Ignore that 3.2 out of 5.0 Star rating. The problem with customer rating systems like this is that any dolt can chime in with a 1-star review after the first 15-minutes.*(See Footnotes)]

Those poor, unfairly maligned troglodytes. Think of all the famous and influential Troglodytes that have shaped our world. Hmmm. I guess Bin Laden counts... and Saddam Hussein spent some productive months in a 'spider hole', which is a respectably troglodytic abode. Good enough; I guess my point is made. But even if this film is clearly troglophobic, it's too awesome to boycott... or even dock it a star. I love dark, twisted Westerns with profoundly existential moments. 'Blood Meridian' is my favorite novel; 'Unforgiven' and 'True Grit' and 'No Country For Old Men' are the films I'll list if you ask for my top 3. That doesn't happen often enough though, so I come to Amazon and write reviews. It's sad, no? No? Not really, no. 'Bone Tomahawk' is the directorial debut of novelist, screenwriter and musician S. Craig Zahler, but I knew he had a proclivity for telling very grim 'n' grisly stories from unusual perspectives, some of them set in the American West of the 19th century. So I knew this would be my kind of film, and fairly sure he'd pull it off, based on the strength of 'Asylum Blackout' a criminally over-looked film, and the first of Zahler's many optioned screenplays to make it to the big screen. Not many people watched 'AB', and almost no one gave it the credit it deserved.

The slow-burning tension and sense of foreboding that builds throughout the first two acts had my guts starting to knot up with legitimate anxiety. It's a sign of the writer-director's skill and confidence that he chose to discard the Western and Horror clichs that make audiences comfortable; he tossed out the 'ready-to-pour' character molds, and ignored the boring three-act formulas that are encouraged in film-school, the cinematic equivalent of comfort food... or a full-frontal lobotomy. The writing is deep and subtle, with smart, realistic dialogue, and the cinematography captures the stark, somber grandeur of the landscape; it's a place of empty beauty, where atrocities happen in the light of day. and dry riverbeds become streams of blood.

Then there's the soundtrack: absolutely perfect, weighed down with an ominous tension that builds gradually to an intense crescendo. The pieces lock together, and the seams disappear, combining to make an artistic vision in the same class as Nicolas Winding Rifn's 'Valhalla Rising' or Gaspar Noe's 'Irreversible'. The classic Western clichs start unravelling immediately, leaving viewers in Terra Incognita.
The film announces its dark intentions in the opening scene, with two murderous thieves finishing off their prey. They get distracted by an unsettling noise, an eerie mix of scream and whistle that they try to follow, stumbling into a tribal gravesite unlike any Native American rituals the surprisingly knowledgeable elder man has seen. It's closer to Paleolithic, a cultural anomaly**(See Footnotes). After the elder thief is killed, the younger man, played by David Arquette, flees for the closest town. Having poisoned sacred ground with his presence, he brings a special kind of hell to this little town with him.

Sheriff Franklin Hunt -- a flawless performance by Kurt Russell -- knows there's something wrong and sick about the thief as soon as he lays eyes on him. After a couple friendly questions, the interrogation becomes a shooting, and they uncover the stolen property he was seen trying to hide, in a hasty burial just outside the town limits. That night, while the Sheriff is home, something about the thief's arrival nagging at him, the Paleolithic nightmares who followed the interloper into town brazenly and silently strike. They butcher a stable-boy, and take Purvis the desecrator-thief, Deputy Nick, and Samantha O'Dwyer as captives... and livestock.

When Sherriff Hunt sets out to recover the taken captives, he is joined by his likable, dependable, but somewhat addle-brained Deputy, Chickory; Richard Jenkins invests the character with a comic charm that helps offset some of the relentlessly grim atmosphere. The missing woman's husband, Arthur O'Dwyer (played by the very busy Patrick Wilson, who is excellent), is determined to join the search party as well, despite a broken leg. Matthew Fox is excellent as John Brooder, an enigmatic combination of surface confidence and impressive shooting abilities, but who hides inner doubts and uncertainties that the actor conveys with the slightest of gestures and tones. His motivations are a mystery to characters and audience alike, but he seems to be compelled to prove himself. The well-mannered but arrogant gunslinger joins the under-manned posse, even when the Sheriff's Native American scout refuses to do anything beyond point out their destination on a map... and warn them they'll never return. They aren't Indians. They're an evolutionary offshoot of humanity, cave-dwelling Troglodytes with weapons of stone and bone, who butcher their human cousins like livestock. But macho pride being what it is and was, they're not about to be deterred by savages with rocks. Things start going wrong early on, with bandits, internal conflict, and the frantic husband's leg getting worse every second he's on the saddle. The subtle details and realistic dialogue, combined with the restrained foreboding of the soundtrack, all suggest that things will not go well. There will be no miracles, no lucky breaks to count on for salvation.

Just how bad it gets when they reach the land of the troglodytes, however, was impossible to imagine, though the title kept repeating itself in my head. That titular bone tomahawk does get to play its gory part, in one of the most authentically horrifying and intense third acts in recent memory. I love the clichd Westerns of old, and the dark revisionist Western films of the Coen Brothers, and Quentin Tarantino. But I consider 'Bone Tomahawk' to be one of the best films of the last decade, a thoroughly brilliant debut from an important new talent. Zahler has created a profoundly disturbing masterpiece that fuses Western and Horror genres without succumbing to the clichd tropes of either. But it's not for everyone, and if cinematic violence bothers you, stay far away. I loved the 'Hateful Eight', so I won't bother saying that 'Bone Tomahawk' is superior; both movies had me dwelling on them for days. It is superior to 'The Burrowers', however, another Western-Horror fusion with a plot virtually identical to 'Bone Tomahawk'... Hollywood's full of copycats, and I think Zahler's script ended up in the hands of the writer-director of 'The Burrowers' at some point, since it was written several years ago. Or maybe not. It's actually quite different in a lot of ways, and I loved it. It's just not the same species of awesome that 'Bone Tomahawk' belongs to.

FOOTNOTES:
*(From Wikipedia: 'Bone Tomahawk received critical acclaim by critics and at festivals for its acting (particularly for Kurt Russell, Richard Jenkins and Matthew Fox), realism, Zahler's direction, and the dialogue of his screenplay. Film review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes reports that 89% of critics gave the film a "Certified Fresh" rating, based on 71 reviews with an average score of 7.1/10, with the site's consensus stating, "Bone Tomahawk's peculiar genre blend won't be for everyone, but its gripping performances and a slow-burning story should satisfy those in search of something different." [15] Metacritic, another review aggregator, assigned the film a weighted average score of 72 (out of 100) based on 17 reviews from mainstream critics, considered to be "generally favorable".'
ALSO: Bone Tomahawk was a festival and Award show hit: it was nominated for 2 'Independent Spirit Awards', one for Zahler and Best Screenplay, one for Richard Jenkins for Best Supporting Actor; Kurt Russell won the 'Fangoria Award' for Best Actor, Jenkins was nominated again in the same category, and Hugo Villasenor was nominated for Best Makeup/FX.
Most impressive, perhaps: at the Sitges Awards (From Wikipedia: 'The Sitges Film Festival (Catalan: Festival Internacional de Cinema Fantstic de Catalunya) is a Spanish film festival and is one of the most recognizable film festivals held in Europe. It is considered the world's foremost international festival specializing in fantasy and horror films.'), Zahler won for 'Best Director', and the film itself won the prestigious 'Jos Luis Guarner' Prize for Best Picture, chosen by the Catalan Association of Film Critics and Writers.)

**{The Troglodytes are loosely based on the mysterious Anasazi tribe, who lived in caves inside a perilous cliff-face in the American Southwest; they remain an enigma; their language and cultural relics mark them as unrelated to any of the closest Native American tribes, and much, much older. What happened to them is yet another mystery.}

Fans of "spaghetti westerns" and Italian cannibal films a la Rugerro Deodato (remember 1980's "Cannibal Holocaust," the self-proclaimed most controversial film ever?) will be intrigued by this mash-up of two seemingly disparate genres. Clearly influenced by John Ford's classic 1954 western "The Searchers," Kurt Russell's crusty yet polite character, Sheriff Hunt, leads an ad hoc posse of western-film stereotypes including an old duffer deputy, Chickory (Richard Jenkins), a dandy gunslinger (Matthew Fox) and a hapless cowboy foreman with a broken leg, Arthur (Patrick Wilson) whose wife, a young doctor names Samantha (Lili Simmons) has been kidnapped by a band  of "troglodytes" along with Deputy Nick (Evan Jonigkeit) and a wounded, suspicious drifter named Purvis (David Arquette).  Much of the film is dedicated to the arduous journey west these four men must take to find the missing trio, an aspect of the film that many viewers elsewhere have complained vociferously about, but in fact, it is this part of the film is probably the most important, providing the insights into the characters of each individual (yes, actual character development).  Once the lair of the mysterious cave dwellers is found, the film morphs into a gruesome cannibal drama strongly reminiscent of the above referenced Deodato gory schlock-fest, only here it is mud-slathered mutated giants with bone inserts in their vocal chords to allow them to produce a bone-chilling, bestial roar that eat people instead of mud-slathered Amazonian Indians without bone inserts who eat people.  The transition is sudden and shocking, particularly the over-the-top fate of poor Deputy Nick in his preparation for dinner (with him as the main course).  Again, like Deodato, no graphic detail of the torture, scalping, or human bisection is spared, but in spite of the horror, it seems less gratuitous, almost being done with a wink and a nod to a genre of Italian cinema in the early 1980s that most typical viewers of Westerns might be completely unaware of, which I believe is the whole point.

It is clear that the budget for this film was virtually non-existent (one source quoted under $2 million), and must have been a labor of love for actors of Russell's and Jenkin's caliber.  In fact, it is these two actors' skill at their craft that holds the film together.  Russell returns to a type of role he has not tasted since "Tombstone" and it is prescient of that of the bounty hunter he plays in Quentin Tarantino's "The Hateful Eight" which was released not long after "Bone Tomahawk."  David Arquette is appropriately slimy as Purvis, as is Sid Haig as "Buddy",  the latter being the first to taste the wrath of the "troglodytes" at the film's beginning.

One interesting aspect of this film is its political correctness regarding the subject of the "savages" portrayed in this film that in earlier, less culturally conscious times would have been relegated to a particularly naughty group of Indians. However, we are told with great authority that the cannibals are not Native Americans by the only educated man in the small Texas town of Bright Hope (the small town where this saga unfolds), a man who is referred to as "the Professor," clearly a Native American himself who, after studying an arrow recovered from a stash of items hidden by Purvis, claims that the kidnappers are actually "troglodytes" (a term for cave dwellers derived from the Greek word for "hole"), non-Indian mutants who have been eschewed by his people for millennia.  Bright Hope was clearly one of the most progressive social communities in the Wild West!

"Bone Tomahawk" is one of those films people will either love for its quirky, dark-humored mash-up of low-budget Italian pulp Westerns (with a touch of John Ford)-meets-late 1980's-cannibal films, or hate it for its somewhat plodding pace and horrific ending with one particularly unsettling death scene (not for young children, please).  I liked this odd first-time writer/director S. Craig Zahler's twisted homage to two film genres that we would never expect to see intersect with one another.  One thing I would change about the film would be its locations ( it was clearly shot in the foothills north of Los Angeles where it would be cheapest), where ground supposedly unexplored has obviously been recently plowed and graded by heavy equipment (complete with spoil pile mounds evident).  A more appropriate and visually pleasing filming locale would have been in and around Red Rock Canyon State Park, only two hours north of Los Angeles; maybe it would not have been Monument Valley, but it would have provided a more convincing landscape.

A crippled husband, a bigoted aristocrat, an old man that can't stop delivering bad jokes, and an incompetent sheriff  that delegates every action to someone else, head out on a bloody quest of vengeance. Hilarity ensues as dice check rolls result in a critical failure over and over and over! The over the top gore and seriousness in which the characters portray themselves in this out of the ordinary fantasy western make this film fairly bizarre. I really wanted to like it, as I am quite a fan of Kurt Russell. However, the movie lacks a genuine plot and the characters are fairly static. The outrageous amount of gore is distracting and unbelievable. The actors gave it their best and delivered a good performance, but the bottom line is that the plot was predictable. Less of a "Western," Leaning more towards the "Horror" genre. Watch it if you're bored, but don't expect much. Probably, not worth the time invested.

I will say, having grown up in the days of classic horror movies like Friday the 13th, Halloween, Night of the Living Dead, Hellraiser, etc...the cannibalism cave scene left a mark like no other.  Someone commented that the gory scene didn't bring anything to the film...BS!  That scene alone capitalized the gravity of the situation they were all in and ensured the audience understood it as well.  If you are a fan of westerns or any of the leading actors, this is definitely a movie worth watching.

Who knew!  Excellent cast in this little known movie. Definitely has some hardcore violence, but just a few bursts of it. I'm not really much into westerns, as I think they are often just the same old schtick, but this was a cool slow burn of a movie.

Possible spoilers. I seemed to recall that when this movie first came out, there was an emphasis on cannibalism in the press. Well, there is but you can put away the emphasis. First time director, S. Craig Zahler, best known forwell nothing, has assembled a terrific cast, and in a period of 3 weeks created what feels like an authentic western set in the dusty Western United States (shot in California) at the turn of the 20th century.

Kurt Russell plays Sheriff Hunt, a man who has experienced a lot and has little regard for anyone who questions his authority. When he questions why a drifter (David Arquette) is in town, a disrespectful answer results in a bullet to the leg. You get the feeling he has found this effective in the past. Hunt asks for the services of Samantha (Lili Simmons) who appears to be the town nurse. Shes been busy tending to her husband, Arthur (Patrick Wilson), a cowboy who is on the mend from a broken leg.

The next morning the sheriff discovers that Samantha, the drifter and Deputy Nick (Evan Jonigkeit) are all missing. Based on some evidence left behind, it is determined by The Professor, the resident Native American (Zahn McClarnon, you might remember from TVs Fargo), that it is the work of a small, cannibalistic tribe of cave dwellers known as Troglodytes. The sheriff, with certainly a sense of guilt combined with job responsibility, is determined to rescue the kidnapped residents. Against his better judgement, Hunt allows Arthur to come along, bad leg and all. He is also accompanied by a former military officer and noted "Killer named Brooder (Matthew Fox) and his back-up deputy, Chicory (Richard Jenkins).

Zahler, who also penned the script, fleshes out all of the characters, even some minor ones. Jenkins, in particular is at the top of his game. We especially get to known the quartet on the rescue mission. I couldn't help think that this life of constant hardship shaped the characters in the story. In fact, none would seem to be bad or evil. Even the racist, Brooder has his reasons which come out late in the film. The Troglodytes, with various bones protruding from their body and covered in a white mud are extremely fearsome and repellent. Yes, it seems that humans are high on their preferred dinner shopping list. But aside from some gory violence commonly seen on TV, there is only one scene that would qualify as a stomach turner.

I will also mention a couple of other unrecognizable cameos I missed until seeing the credits. Sean Young (Blade Runner) plays the domineering wife of the towns mayor. Michael Pare (Eddie and the Cruisers) plays a stable owner and businessman. Filmed on a budget of less than $2 million, the film has a place on a list of cult classics at the very least. An odd, violent and satisfying western. Highly recommended, but not for everyone.

I'm not a big fan of the horror movie genre so I was very skeptical to watch this film as it was labeled as such. However, this film was basically your typical Western with gruesome killing that can lead to adults nightmares  to that purpose I guess you could consider it a Western/Horror film. At any rate, Kurt Russell plays the law-man in the film, Sheriff Franklin of the quaint town on Bright Hope   where your moral and "civilized" people live. Things get going at a brisk pace when we have a band of cannibalistic savages enter the town at night and kidnap a prisoner, the deputy and theg wife of a gritty but injured townsman played by Patrick Wilson. The men form a search party to rescue the kidnapped victims and are on their way to rescue them. The only problem is that the savages they're looking are no dummies and are excellent at two things: killing humans and eating humans. This is a slow burner but like most good things that take time  worth the wait

A gory mess of a "horror" Western about a posse led by Sheriff Russell in search of a mysterious, ancient tribe of Native American "Troglodytes" cave dwellers who just so happen to be cannibals feasting on the local settlers. "Bone Tomahawk" tries to be authentic by using the colloquial language and look of the time with realistic sounding gun shots etc. etc. It does gets points for that, but the plodding plot and over the top cannibalistic gore sink what few good moments this movie has. Doomed to cult status, and perfect for a "bad movie night" party.  If you are a Kurt Russell fan, stick to Tarantino's "The Hateful Eight".

Bone Tomahawk is the best western cannibal horror movie ever. I loved it and once again I must address those who say it's boring: their impatient stupidity is what is boring. A slow burn buildup is what makes the movie so effective and if you pay attention, there are significant clues along the way, in those "boring" parts, that deepen the pleasure of the experience. If you can't immediately recognize a great cult movie after having watched it with both eyes and a supposed brain, then you are cinematically hopeless. The acting is accomplished (and some of it is even great), the horror is nightmarish, the comedy is clever and the script is tight and well written and best of all, it's a surprise. When it starts, you'll never guess where it ends up. 5 stars indeed.

Very uneven film. The actors make due with not much to work with as the mish mash of genres is almost laughable at times. The filmmakers were too concerned with breaking barriers in story telling that they forgot the most important rule-have a good story to tell. The plot line of innocents being taken away by savage/menacing types while an unlikely cast of characters chase after them has been done for generations.  George Miller thrived doing this in MAD MAX: FURY ROAD giving a genre busting film along with "slow burns" and highly empathetic characters. This film did not, but kudos to Kurt Russell, Richard Jenkins,  and Patrick Wilson for trying.

This is by far my favorite film of 2015. Kurt Russell is the perfect niche actor to play the part of the tough as nails town sheriff who is adamant on derailing from his word and lawful duties. He is paired up with Patrick Wilson, Richard Jenner and Matthew Fox on a suicide mission to rescue Wilson's wife in the barren hills of the west, who was earlier usurped along with the sheriffs deputy. Who would commit this unexpecting crime, you ask? Mountain cannibals!! Yes, this movie is an overly abundant mesh of the spaghetti western and horror genres with some great performances, time accurate dialogue and perfect intro to ending climatic build.. seeing Sid Haig and David Arquette in the opening scene indicated something good was stirring up and the camera definitely delivered an ominous cloud of suspense midway through the film

Bone Tomahawk is an okay mixture of old-west shoot-'em-up and creepy horror that almost but doesn't quite succeed in its ambitious genre bending effort.
A prologue introduces a pair of murderous highwaymen (David Arquette, Sid Haig) who are confronted with an eerie, unseen threat after slaughtering and robbing a party of travelers. Cut to the sleepy frontier town of Bright Hope later that evening, where law and order is enforced by no-nonsense sheriff Kurt Russell and deputy/sidekicks Richard Jenkins and Evan Jonigkeit.
A report of a suspicious stranger in town (Arquette) seen burying something in the dark brings Russell and Jenkins to where the stranger was last seen, the local saloon, The Learned Goat. Still there, the stranger only gets dodgier under questioning by Russell and attempts to flee after it's revealed that he was burying stolen loot, causing Russell to shoot him in the leg. That brings out Lili Simmons, as a nurse and wife of local rancher Patrick Wilson. She is brought to the jail to repair Arquette while being guarded by Jonigkeit. Unfortunately, the same baddies Arquette encountered earlier have followed him to Bright Hope, where, overnight, they horribly murder a stable hand, steal some prized horses and carry off Jonigkeit, Arquette and Simmons for purposes that you don't even want to think about. In the morning Russell assembles an intrepid posse to bring them back consisting of Jenkins, Wilson, hobbled by a broken leg, and a dapper Indian fighter and gunslinger (Matthew Fox) who feels responsible for having brought out Simmons instead going to the trouble of rousing the drunk town doctor to attend to Arquette.
Suffice to say that they get much more than they bargained for once they catch up with their quarry.
The entertaining cast of veterans and newcomers is the main reason to see Bone Tomahawk. (Stay alert and you'll also spot Fred Melamed, Kathryn Morris, James Tolkan and Sean Young in brief cameo roles.) Debuting writer/director S. Craig Zahler has cooked up interesting characters for them to play and supplied them with tasty, authentic-sounding dialog to wrap their talents around. It would be enough to make you overlook the somewhat derivative plot--a sort of crossbreeding of The Searchers with The 13th Warrior--if Tomahawk didn't take over two hours to get to its tense and grisly climax. Instead, it tends to wander when it should barrel ahead while unfolding the kind of offbeat frontier yarn a Budd Boetticher or an Anthony Mann might have torn off in a brisk 85 minutes in their heyday.
Still, along with sounding great  (Stick around during the end credits for the creepy exit song co-written by Zahler and Jeff Herriott, who also performed it.), Tomahawk also looks great befitting Zahler's movie background as a cinematographer. As a result, Tomahawk may not be a great movie, but it's still pretty good, if definitely not for the squeamish.

Once upon a time in the west, Kurt Russell and his pals went in search of the Indians who kidnapped his friend's wife. Surprise, surprise, the Indians aren't really Indians. They are mutant zombies with strange voice boxes. They don't communicate with words; they communicate with shrill howling that sounds like a diesel train engine with a broken horn. If you want to spend ninety minutes and then say, "What the Bleep was that," then you'll enjoy Bone Tomahawk.

For being filmed in only 21 days, this was a fairly good movie. I really liked the backup deputy Chicory (Richard Jenkins) making his editorial comments and joking gestures. A long time Kurt Russel fan (he plays Sheriff Franklin Hunt) the movie flowed well and was eerie in parts, which kept my interest. I could've done without the sex scene between Arthur O'Dwyer (Patrick Wilson) and his wife/doctor's assistant, Samantha (Lili Simmons). Without giving anything away, something else you may want to be prepared for is a fairly grisly and graphic scene of Deputy Nick (Evan Jonigkeit) being slaughtered by the cannibals....very gruesome.
The one thing I found that detracted from the 'rescue' scene was how the lame Patrick Wilson reached the cave....I mean, the man could barely walk, he has a broken leg! Other than that, the characters were good and the plot was good. This movie was better than many 2+ hour movies I've seen, on a huge budget that took a year to film.....

When a group of cannibal savages kidnaps settlers from the small town of Bright Hope, an unlikely team of gunslingers, led by Sheriff Franklin Hunt (Kurt Russell), sets out to bring them home. Kurt Russell (The Hateful Eight, Tombstone) leads an all-star cast, including Patrick Wilson (Insidious), Matthew Fox (Lost) and Richard Jenkins (The Visitor) in this gritty, action-packed thriller chronicling a terrifying rescue mission in the Old West. This is the description given by the Amazon box. Now for mine....WOW! what a terrific combination of horror and suspense and a Western. I even have to say that even though I am not a fan of Patrick Wilson (personal reason) he did a great job as did Matthew Fox and Kurt Russell and Richard Jenkins. Even though some parts walking or riding to the destination seemed drawn out, it wasn't and it made perfect sense. The direction and the scenery are outstanding. I was anticipating each minute of the next frame of this movie. Excellent. Not for the faint of heart, though. Some very nasty scenes.

I agree completely with Rotten Tomatoes assessment:  "Bone Tomahawk's peculiar genre blend won't be for everyone, but its gripping performances and a slow-burning story should satisfy those in search of something different." It starts dull and talky and takes its time to build to something straightforwardly brutal. It's a hard watch if you're used to tightly plotted setpiece-heavy big-budget exercises, but if you can get past how it takes its time to get to where it's going, it's worth a watch.

A forgettable gory Western, Bone Tomahawk, was guilty of some of the major horror tropes regarding race. First, the young, black stablehand is cannon fodder, whose death means nothing but the movement of plot. This is the only African-American in the film, that I could tell. Second, the Native Americans are so alien and unknowable as to be literally monsters. The main characters openly discuss the number of Indians theyve killed. While on their journey across a standard Western landscape, two Mexicans approach the camp in the night and are summarily executed. There is a religious subtext, as well, wherein the character that survives the whole affair is constantly praying. The monstrous troglodytes emerge from the valley of starving men because some murderous bandits kicked over rocks at a site sacred to the monsters.

Lets set aside the horror tropes and talk about cannibalism. It happened. It was part of the cultures of North America. It still happens in parts of the world remote from modern theories of germs and disease. Let us first begin by letting that concept go. The divide between what is food and what is disgusting is inextricably linked to the identification of groups and cultures. Let us begin by placing that concept aside. The actions of the tribe appear monstrous, just as Grendel appears monstrous, just as fire ants appear monstrous. But, white men came to the country and decimated native populations. Should they not fight back? Should they not defend their sacred places? Much of the drama of the film revolves around the good people caught in the crossfire of the vengeance of the sacred. The unwitting good people caught up in the fight are going to die.

This is the race war, idea, though. This is the manifest destiny at the heart of the genre of the western. The unknowable place full of savagery and terror is laid down by the gun of the good, white man. The town is protected against the wild. The railroad runs through, and will always come through whether by force of might and banditry, or by love and desire. And, in every Western Ive seen, the different races are kept apart from each other, pushed against each other, played off as representatives of the idea of their own cultures and ways of life. Even among the best-intentioned Westerns, its hard to escape the specter of the larger world in the time. The white man was coming. The black man was under his heel. The Hispanic man was a foreign world, an Other, that was to be pushed away from decent Americans, or a race of ignorant children to be protected by decent Americans. The red man was a monster and was to be feared and fought and never trusted. The best of the savages could, perhaps, integrate into the town, but never keep their own way of life. The idea of the west is, at heart, a race war where a whole continent was placed under the heel of the white American, and all other cultures and ways of life are pushed down and away.

Even the best Westerns, the smartest and bravest and most interesting, walk across this face of history. The town is the place of order and civilization, and it is a place of Whiteness. The wilderness is the place of danger and the unknown. It is the place of the native Americans, who were, actually, as civilized in their way as any European-style township. The heart of the genre carries a race war. What do we do about it? What do we write about it? What do we make movies about it?

I watched this on 4/29/16 via my Prime subscription using my Roku device.  Frankly I would have been upset if I had paid to rent this movie.  The quality of the video was excellent  and without any technical difficulties.  I would give this aspect of the feature 5 stars.  However, the movie itself was B-movie quality.  Kurt Russell's performance was pretty good especially given the lack luster script.  The actress from the series "Banshee" didn't show anymore acting ability here than she did in the Cine Max Series.  The plot was mediocre and contained several plot holes.  Matthew Fox also co-stared and did a pretty good job despite his character being pitifully one dimensional.  The storyline actually had the potential to have been much better but it seemed the writer was in too much of a hurry to simply get a script done so that a movie could be made.  However, there was quite a bit of action and some pretty spin tingling gory and gruesome scenes that I rater enjoyed.  The latter makes the movie inappropriate for children.  I really wished that the screenplay had contained more depth and avoided the scenes and moments that defied even my ability to suspend disbelief.  This story, though not  all that original, really did have the potential to have been much better.

An absolutely chilling movie.  At times it was so painfully real I covered my eyes.  I didn't sleep for days.  One of  Kurt Russell's best performances in years as the calm, dedicated, sensible sheriff who summoned the courage to undertake the rescue of a woman in an absolutely horrifying journey  to his fate.  You could feel the excruciating pain of the woman's husband as he soldiered on to rescue his wife.  A great cast of characters.  I had nightmares for a week after I watched the movie -- realistic  depiction of a sect of cannibals living in early 20th century America.

Bone Tomahawk has all the elements we loved from the golden era westerns.  A duty bound sheriff sets out on an impossible mission because it's the right thing to do.  A hero on a journey to rescue his damsel in distress.  An ornery old coot who steels the show.  Oh and bad, bad savages.  Despite being a true Western fans of John Wayne will love, Bone Tomahawk will not disappoint modern audiences.  There is darkness here Cormac McCarthy would appreciate.  The dialogue is worthy of the Cohen brothers, and at times, even rings of Sorkin.  This movie is both brutal and fantastic without departing too much from reality.  For all you busy dads out there who have very little time to watch "your" shows, this one is worth 2 precious hours.

I love Kurt Russell and Westerns (remember how great he was in Tombstone?) and I 'get' the attempt to blend a Western & a horror film in one from a modern film makers POV. But the VIOLENCE IN THIS FILM IS SO GRAPHIC, it could/should have gotten an NC-17 rating in my view. And I share this warning to anyone who plans to watch it, not as a spoiler, but as a direction, do not let your kids watch this film.
It starts off as another 'weird Western', (like the other new film "Slow West"; can't anybody make a 'normal', interesting, satisfying Western alla Unforgiven these days?). The opening scene is VERY GRAPHIC with 2 cowboys killing folks and fleeing into the hills with their loot. The film then shifts to the Town where Kurt Russell is Sheriff and becomes a kidnap/chase film which I actually thought was 'ok'. Matthew Fox is interesting as a 'gunslinger' who likes to kill Indians & goes along for the quest to find Patrick Wilson's Wife taken by Indians unlike any you've seen in a Western before. The film moves very slow, has way too much dialogue for a Western. Those issues could be 'overlooked' but the "in your face violence" ruined the film for me.

The movie has good acting and a decent, if unimaginative script. It is difficult to swallow that the hero of the story is able to walk miles through a desert on a broken and severely infected leg and then kill 4 or 5 cannibalistic savages. At times the movie is too slow for its own good but it does compensate with some good dialogue, most of it coming from the elderly deputy. The unique twist is that this elderly deputy, who seems to be the most expendable, survives. I would recommend this movie, especially taking into account the mostly pathetic films we have to choose from, but don not expect a great film; instead be ready for a decent, at times entertaining film with overall good acting.

I'm a big fan of Kurt Russel and have always loved to watch a good western, so I was happy to see Bone Tomahawk available on Amazon. My husband and I watched it and we were so let down and disappointed! I don't want to spoil it for anyone else but to me it was a lot more like a horror movie and less like a western. The story is so far fetched that it is totally unrealistic, totally unbelievable that anything like this could have ever happened in the American West! I wasn't expecting it to be a true story but thought it might portray life in the American western frontier. Parts of it were ok but I have never watched anything like this and hope I never waste my time like this again.

I love Kurt Russell and will see any movie with him in it. Bone Tomahawk is not for casual viewers. It is horrifically violent, occasionally painfully slow-moving, but ultimately a decent tale of good versus evil. This movie is not fun in any way. It is dark and the future is bleak as you slog your way through a very depressing story. It's worth watching because the acting is good and the drama high but only for brave folks who can handle graphic violence (atrocities that are beyond description), and can sit through 2 hours of one of the most emotionally draining dramas I've seen in a while.

I was quite excited to see a new western, and with Kurt Russell.  He is a great actor and I always enjoy his work.  However Bone Tomahawk was a bit disappointing. I don't think the actors were the problem, but the whole movie seemed to be sluggish in its timing.  I think it may have been poorly directed.  The dialogue didn't seem natural, though I appreciated the lack of exaggerated accents and colloquialisms, as well as other stereotypical language peculiarities that plaque some westerns.  Through much of the first half of the movie I thought I was watching a drama or horror film.  By the time the "Troglodytes" and the cowboys started interacting in the wilderness, the action seemed to morph into dramatic comedy.  The "Troglodytes" were not horrific in the way they were portrayed.  Their screams were unnaturally loud and resonant.  The cage bars they constructed to hold the captives had no way of being secured to the rock walls, and their behaviors were cartoonish.  While I can appreciate a movie that is quirky and comedic intentionally, this one just didn't come off as that until midway through it.  Bone Tomahawk had great potential but lost its focus, and lacked for good dialogue and direction.  Wish Kurt had not don this film.;

Anytime a movie has a running time of over 2 hours, I am a little wary.  This movie is so brilliantly written, directed and acted, the time passes without any notice.  Kurt Russell is wonderfully calm and steady as the sheriff; Matthew Fox as the intellectual snob is great, Patrick Wilson as the overemotional but loving "cowboy" husband (is there anything this man can't do?) and Richard Jenkins, who is unrecognizable as the under-sheriff, as many reviews have already stated, steals the show with his wandering and comical musings, are the rescue party when a group of "troglodyte" Indians kidnap 3 members of the town.  What happens next is horrific and stomach turning, but oh, what a movie.  This passed under everyone's radar and it is the best movie I have seen in ages.  "Say goodbye to my wife and I'll say hello to yours."  Cannot praise this movie enough.

This ambitiously scripted western/horror amalgamation has much to recommend it.  It also suffers from serious flaws which prevent a higher rating from me.  Or the public.  This one brought in less than $2,000,000 in limited release before being sent to DVD purgatory.  Critics however liked it a lot.  Kurt Russell is great by the way.
  Russell, a local sheriff, takes three other men with him to rescue some towns folk who have been kidnapped by Indians.  Before they leave, a local Indian lets them know that they will be confronting not local tribesmen gone on the warpath, but rather a clan of outcast, in bred, cave dwelling cannibals.  They head out any how to do or die in the finest Western tradition.  And boy do they get a work out.  There is blood and gore galore.  The script has the characters speaking as the people of the time would likely speak.  They look, act and seem like people of the old west and not just some actors dressed up.  I did like that a lot.
  The film has picked up a total of five awards here and there, including two from the Catalonian International Film Festival.  The awards range from best make up to best director.
  The film was made in three weeks from a script by first time director S. Craig Zahler.  I have two serious quibbles with the film.  First, the sound is un-even, something we do not ever get in successful films.  And at two hours and 13 minutes, it is too long.  Not too long to tell the impressive and bloody story, too long to maintain the interest of the watcher.  It seems more artistic than thriller like.  The film takes a good long while to get cranked up.  While this allows us to get to know the characters, it is just toooooo slow.  A good trip to the cutting room would have helped a lot.

I was surprised to see so many negative reviews on amazon.  I have to say this really was a movie which told a story (shocking in this day an age) as opposed to most modern movies that use the format to simply dangle sex, explosions and cheap thrills in front of a slack jawed audience.  I don't understand why so many people consider this movie to be slow-paced, as the entire time I was enthralled by the characters' emotions, interactions, and what was an obvious well developed lead up to a shocking and horrible climax.  This movie took the time to actually develop the characters.  Four men go on a long and dangerous journey to rescue a woman and deputy from a clan of cave dwelling natives, knowing that they have little chance to succeed.  On the way they battle the elements in an uncharted and unmapped western frontier and bravely continue through the unforgiving landscape.  The movie contains humor, adventure, drama, romance, and yes, horrific violence for those who are squeamish.  In fact, the scene most reviewers are talking about is pretty difficult to watch and for those of you that have a hard time with that kind of thing should definitely avoid this movie.  But it is certainly horrifying and spine tingling, which is apparently what the director was going for.

Rent interstellar instead.

I watched this at the suggestion of a friend, and I loved it. I don't know why this film didn't have a broader release, and I don't know why it only has 3.2 stars (at the time this review was written). The basic premise: a pair of criminals stumble into savage (not Indian) territory, and one escapes but leads the savages to a nearby town; after some townspeople are abducted, the small town assembles a makeshift posse from the few men available. A few bullet points:
-It has a SUPERB cast of actors led by Kurt Russell, but including Patrick Wilson, Matthew Fox, Richard Jenkins, and David Arquette.
-There is great character development, particularly amongst the posse as they travel. Kurt Russell plays a tough sherriff. Patrick Wilson plays a God-fearing, but injured cowboy. Matthew Fox is a playboy gunslinger, who's a little out-of-place in the small town of Brideshead. Richard Jenkins steals the show as a senior citizen & widower who is enlisted to be a "backup sherriff's deputy" more as a means of the sherriff looking after the man. He winds up being surprisingly capable, and endears himself to the audience throughout the film.
-From the first second, it shows you how brutal the Old West could be. While other films romanticize the notion of sleeping out on the prairie next to your trusty horse, this film shows you how dangerous it really was. A pistol and long gun were not optional, they were essential.
-This is NOT a movie for children, or the faint of heart. There is an element of gore and horror that will disturb some viewers. I personally felt it further reinforced the awful brutality people faced in the frontier, and the sort of violence they routinely encountered.

Once again, I'm astonished that this wasn't released more widely. It has a stellar cast, and I recognized virtually every actor with a speaking part in this film (straight down to the piano player who you might recognize as the principal in Back to the Future). If you can stomach some of the gore, and if you like Westerns you owe it to yourself to watch this film.

Against the other three actors in the posse Matthew gave a weak performance.  Richard Jenkins stole the show with his dialog and character representation being superb.  Lili Simmons gave a respectable performance and finally showed a strong female character.  Hey, anyone who can call Kurt Russell and "Idiot" and get away with it has strength of character.  The film would also have benefited from a continuity check.

I loved this film! I gave it four stars solely based on the fact that some parts were too slow and I hoped the ending would have been a bit more satisfactory.
The cast is perfection while the script cleverly makes each character their own. Everybody embodies said character beautifully. You truly believe in their personalities.
There are some truly horrific parts. It's so disturbing, yet so interesting that you can't look away. Like a bad car wreck, but a million times crazier!
The beginning starts off with a bang! The middle is a bit more slow, but like I mentioned; it's not boring on account of the amazing script and actors portraying these unique characters! Go Mathew Fox! I love his character and I love seeing him acting on the big screen! (Everybody else, EVERYBODY! Is fantastic!)
This middle all leads up to this tense feeling you get. You can feel that things are about to get real, something anxiously awaits! It's very exciting and this build up does not disappoint! You may not be able to stomach certain parts but it's pretty interesting!

18th century gothic, jammed with ruined castles, ghosts, cannibals, and vampires, is the usual literary slot that is imagined when the term is used.  there is also excellent gothic, that sustains that line, written as far as the 1960s.  there is southern gothic, and there are some extremely fine female authors of it.  and a western gothic genre, that has included such authors as bret harte.  tomahawk is a western gothic that pursues a tale of subhuman indian cannibals, who have apparently substituted anatomic whistles for vocal chords (?), includes  extremely explicit gore, and sustains itself as plausible, if somewhat melodramatic horror.
But be forewarned; there are two scenes that will haunt me for some time, and that doesn't happen easily.

It's too bad because the acting is top-notch, believable dialogue, good costuming, and a story that catches one's interest. This is not a Western for kids to watch and the faint-of-heart. However, it is not farfetched to believe these types of humans could have still been alive in the isolated west during this time period. The pace is slow, but adds to building toward the climatic parts. I was not disappointed at the end; it seemed believable, as if real people were trying to stay alive. I won't watch it again, even though I gave it 4 stars.

Dialogue is as old as the setting and slow paced as it would have been for this time frame.  Loved that.  Not something you can sit on your cell phone or not pay attention to or you will miss out on many funny things said between the men in this. The entire movie had a surprise twist and the ending was also a surprise but a good one. I am a huge Kurt Russell fan so this movie took me aback with the gore in it, as he isn't usually in that type of movie, but all in all, I would recommend it. Lot of negative reviews here....too bad. This an excellent and entertaining movie. I was given the Blue Ray version as a Birthday gift. I love this. The acting, filming, pacing and storyline are just right. Even the sound is good and the song at the end, "Four Doomed Men Ride Out" has a classic western theme. There's just enough comic relief in the story to tone down the tension.

This is a classic Horror/Western in the same vein as FRANKENSTEIN,... JAWS,.. THE THING and other films and stories that deal with man's horror of the unknown and overwhelming fear of death and final destruction. How does a person face death when it comes in the presence of brute violence, that's what this is about. And it is done well...It reminds me of a "tall tale" like those of the great pulp fiction writer, ROBERT E. HOWARD.

The character development and dialogue is very good and makes the whole project believable on an uncanny level. Some people have complained about the gore...forget it. One visit to the slaughterhouse will cure of you that complaint. Great movie!

If you liked Kurt Russell in the epic Western, Tombstone, and you enjoy Thrillers, then you will like this movie. Kurt Russell's character is similar to an old Wyatt Earp.  He plays an aging sheriff of the peaceful town of Bright Hope who is obligated to track down a scary bunch of cannibals who have kidnapped a young wife and nurse, and his young deputy. Russell plays the role of the tired but dutiful sheriff well. The movie does spend considerable time developing the main characters, which might aggravate some impatient viewers, but one begins to care about the characters when they are imperiled.  The movie's title probably attracts the wrong viewers since it implies some 'mysticism' or the 'supernatural.' This is a good vanilla Western albeit with a different spin...a brave sheriff and a rag tag bunch of would-be heroes versus a group of ruthless killers and insurmountable odds.

This was one of those movies I wanted to watch and found myself quite interested in it throughout. The story was interesting and honestly it kept me watching. It was a western, so some of it seemed predictable. A western is a western, right? I enjoyed the characters in this movie. Must say, Kurt Russell was a draw; I like his movies. The mix of personalities added to the intrigue. And I must say, I was very curious about this mystery tribe they alluded to. I was not, however, prepared for the savagery toward the end. I won't spoil it, but the scene in the cave with the one guy while the other captives watched was for me the most heinous scene ever. Frankly, it disturbed me greatly and I wished I could un-watch that part. Truly it almost ruined the whole movie for me. That was just too much. Everything after that was pointless, because I was repulsed to the Nth degree. OMG. Did still watch till the end and glad to see how it ended, but would never, ever, ever watch it again. For heaven's sake, do NOT allow anyone under 17 to watch it! This is a tough one to recommend. Viewer beware.

In all fairness, I wasn't sure what I was getting myself into when I started watching this movie. My mind was in the mood for western, which I sort of got. The problem is that is is a horror-western. Now when I say "horror" let me say also that in years gone by I was a horror movie aficionado and as of late I simply have lost the taste for horror at all. There are lots of reasons why, but mostly because I feel there is enough evil in the world and I don't really want to entertain my brain with it. Morals aside, the entertainment value of this movie is ok. Kurt Russell is my favorite actor and his performance was nothing less than spectacular as always. The story was sort of a spin on a classic western tale and I enjoyed it until about halfway through the movie. At that point I witnessed one of the most brutal death scenes I have seen in a long time and maybe ever. Now, as I said, I used to be a horror movie buff; death scenes were just part of the norm in those movies. Something about this one really bothered me on a deep level. I won't spoil it in case you decide to watch, and honestly anything past that scene is a mystery because I turned the movie off during the scene. I was physically nauseated for about 15 minutes or so after I watched it. From what I saw, the level of gore just wasn't needed. However, the writers obviously disagreed and that leads me to another point: somebody's mind has to be sick enough to come up with this. I think that's probably the most disturbing thing.

In any case this movie just wasn't for me simply because I object to the level of gore used in the movie. Would have rather watched something inspiring instead of something so bleak. Again, it's on me for not really researching what I was watching. If you're going to watch this just know what you're getting into.

I quite enjoyed Bone Tomahawk. It begins as a quaint western. The dialog, at times, seems stilted and not at all what one would expect from a western. The characters seem altogether too polite and refined in their speech and mannerisms.

The posse going after the kidnapped townspeople take their sweet time. There is little sense of urgency in their pursuit of the 'Troglodytes'. The title comes from the use of horse jawbones as tomahawks; an almost biblical weapon.

The big flaw that I noticed is when the remaining posse is imprisoned within the cave 'cells', the wooden bars are set shallowly into the ground and pegged at the top by some kind of spike. They appear very flimsy and the bars could easily be removed and used as weapons while an escape could be made. There was no attepmt made to make these bars look like they were 'escape proof'.

The scene of butchery in the cave isn't as gory as other reviews make it out to be... it's simply unexpected and somewhat shocking.

Slow-paced and racially-offensive. The "Troglodytes" are supposedly a sub-species of the indigenous native Americans? Even more "savage" than the "savages"? This film would have been welcomed by the same people who tried so hard to de-humanize the American indigenous people at the time of the Trail of Tears and even later at the turn of the 19th century when industrialists used propaganda to convince US citizens that the Indians were "Godless" in order to make way for the railroads and expansion into the west. Russell and Jenkins should be ashamed and embarrassed for being part of this horrible portrayal of the American west. Sure, some will say it's no different than "Abe Lincoln, Vampire Hunter" or "Inglourious Basterds" as alternate history or fantasy, but I choose to see it as yet another attempt to dehumanize the people that were here a millennia before white Europeans.

This was really incredible. Reminiscent of Apocalypto in its intensity and uniqueness. And the dialogue throughout was worthy of Lebowski or Withnail.

I felt like had they saved the special effects costs from that over-the-top and tacked-on gore in an otherwise tolerable gore-level film, they could have made a better film all-around, with a much more satisfying ending.  But I'm sure there are folks out there that will find their creepy pleasure in this film just because of that extra gory scene.  The characters were good for a B movie, If you watch Fargo the TV series you'll notice a few familiar faces, one of which I hoped would have a bigger part but didn't.

This is not for everyone, but I personally think it was tremendous. It's a western, a comedy, and a monster movie rolled into one. The acting is mostly great, especially Richard Jenkins.  The humor and dialogue are unique and interesting. To enjoy this movie, you need to be mentally prepared for a massive shift in tone at the end. Structurally it reminds me of Dusk til Dawn that way. This seems like a well done western all the way UNTIL... things go horribly wrong. The massive shift from western to... well, horror I guess, really generates a deep sense of how quickly things can go from normal to absolutely horrific. There is no warning or build up, just like real life can be. So much so, you start to wonder "is this really happening?" I'm sure this will turn some viewers off, especially if they were enjoying the regular old posse round-em up story. But I think the juxtaposition only drives home how awesome the movie really is. It's a wonderful risk taken by the film makers, turning this movie into anything but the normal Hollywood movie. The first 66% of the movie is necessary though, to connect us to the characters in such a way that we are right there with them at the end. One word of warning: there is one absolutely gruesome and graphic murder later in the film, like nothing I've ever seen. Again, necessary to drive home how real things have suddenly gotten for our heroes. As long as you're mentally prepared for what this movie is like, I think you'll enjoy it.

I have a pretty extensive knowledge and experience with both the Western and Horror genres. There are certain staples in each that constitute what makes a good film in their respective categories. When I first heard about Bone Tomahawk I honestly thought "how could this be bad?". The answer seems to be pretty simple, the director (and writer) had a good idea but did not really know how to make it happen the right way.

Let's start from the Western aspect. What are the staples in Westerns? Things that make the great ones stand out. First and foremost the cinematography is right at the top of the list. In the first 5 minutes you can see this as a failure in that area. The OVER use of steadicam throughout the film was a huge mistake, there were very few "long shots" of the landscape in this movie which is an absolute MUST. It seems the Director of Photography didn't care too much, or do his homework about how a Western should look and feel.

Next would be the score... or the lack thereof. This could fall into the category of either genre. Plain and simple, through an hour and a half any music whatsoever was used only ONCE, and when music was used it seemed purely incidental. Keeping music out of a movie like this kept it from being suspenseful or interesting.

Too much dead space. Too many long dull moments in the movie with nothing interesting happening, or where too much time was wasted on something insignificant in the movie. This kind of thing IS normal in the Western genre but there is a particular grace about it when done properly. Some very odd and bewildering (at least to me) comedy. This did NOT seem like a movie that was built for comic relief but Richard Jenkins character seemed to be exactly that.

As many others have said on here, Kurt Russell was great (although not specifically so), I'm a huge fan of him but he just couldn't carry this one all by himself. If the film was re-shot, properly scored (a Jonny Greenwood style ala There Will Be Blood score would have perfect) and cut down to maybe an hour and 45 minutes with a better ending, it probably could have been great.
Predictable, but hey, you don't who is going to make it and who isn't !! And it is a Western!!??!!

Interesting film. Not action heavy, but that doesn't detract from good storytelling. Good character writing - each character had their own distinct personality, which I apprecaited. The dialogue is terse, but still felt natural to me - when people work together that don't know each other well, that's how it goes. There are a couple of scenes in this that go against the internal logic of the film, which bothers me (pulls me out of the story) - one is a scene of convenience (there's no underling logic for why the characters show up except to fulfill a plot requirement) and they other is a logic you don't really think about until the film is over, but it's still quite compelling and had me engrossed to the end. It's quite graphic, particulary in one scene - we're talkng horror film graphic, so it's best to be prepared going in. So not perfect, but I always enjoy a decent western, especially ones that rely less on drama, character & plot instead of mindless action scenes.

2 1/2 stars...maybe. This film was not quite what I was hoping for.
At just about 2 hrs 10 mins it could have easily been edited down to 90 minutes. Set in the Old West, the story revolves around 4 men searching for the wife of one of the 4 that was taken by some sort of native American/cannibal tribe. We spend a nauseating amount of time watching these four ride and, and ultimately, walk across baron landscape and desert.
At several points into their journey they have quite a few over-dramatic, childish arguments - each of them always trying to have the last word.
It's really amateurish - even for Kurt Russell. And I enjoy Kurt Russell movies.
The last 20 or so mins are where it comes together and we get to see a couple of gory, graphic cannibalistic rituals and carnage.
This doesn't bother me as much as it seems to bother way too may others. I've seen much worse in film.
The good guys win in the end but at a heavy cost. This is a love it/hate it film... I was on the fence at the end...if it were edited a little better and had a bit more action I would go 3 full stars but this was way too drawn out for the first hour. No - it's not "gritty", no, it's NOT the greatest western ever put to film (whoever thinks that needs to get out more). It's slow and slack-jawed, and it's filmed in a way where I barely felt involved...glad I rented it first.

Fair warning - this is a very violent and gory movie at the end. But it is a well done film with top-drawer acting from Kurt Russell, Richard Jenkins, Patrick Wilson and Lili Simmons. This movie fits its title - crude and violent like a bone tomahawk - a bare-bone movie. It is a stripped-down Western with very little sweeping and grand action but more than a few powerful scenes. Not a movie for a date - unless you and your date do not mind evisceration and decapitation along with the popcorn. Some reviewers complain of slow develolpment and boring pace. I did not detect anything other than refusal by director S. Craig Zahler to decorate the film with easy and pretty standard Cowboy and Indian fare. This is a movie that pays your brain a compliment while punching you in the gut with metaphorical (and not-so-metaphorical) roundhouses. Recommended for a night when you don't have to go in to work the next morning.

This is an unusual cowboy movie.  It reminded me of "Cowboys versus Aliens", but more in an independent film style and storyline instead of a big studio production blockbuster.  The acting is good, Kurt Russell and Patrick Wilson are the headliners, and they play unique characters and are pretty credible in their roles.  It didn't qualify for more stars, even though it kept me entertained; because there is a long, long, section of the film devoted to Wilson's injured character suffering on a quest to catch some Indian kidnappers.  And there is one very unnecessary graphic scene of torture and cannibalism. I had to cover my eyes on this, and no movie for whatever artistic license should ever have an unwatchable scene!
