This movie is bold, begrimed, and bloody. There is a "No Country for Old Men" feel with a hearty portion of western, a pinch of horror, and a splash of mystery. The film certainly doesn't pull any punches, so be ready to feel a bit strange after finishing it. The pace is, like any good prose, varied and dynamic. There are slow parts juxtaposed with hard-hitting sequences of pure drama. Overall, this is an original work of art. I have not seen anything like it before.

It seems that "Bone Tomahawk" is a movie that will really divide viewers. People will either love it or hate it, with no one in the middle ground. Personally, I really enjoyed it. That is not to say that the movie is without flaws. The low budget of the enterprise (less than $2 million) is evident at times though I credit writer/director S. Craig Zahler for working hard so the movie never looks extremely cheap. And yes, the movie is both long (over two hours in length) and for the most part, slow moving; the movie would almost certainly have been better had the pacing been somewhat quicker. Despite these flaws, the movie does have a lot of power. The dialogue is pretty good, being colorful but not too much; you can believe these characters would say what they say. The acting is also professional; the cast manages to sell their characters. When it comes to action and violence, you do have to wait a long time for the serious stuff to come, but it's worth the wait, being very hard hitting and seriously bloody. And while the movie is overlong and slow, I personally wasn't bored at any moment; there is always something of interest going on. But despite my enjoyment of the movie, as I said, it's not for everyone. But if you like westerns and possess a good amount of patience, you'll probably enjoy this movie. Bone Tomahawk

Great movie.  Kurt Russell is sheriff of a small western town when two citizens are captured by Indians.  Not the usual movie Indians; this tribe are cannibals and don't have a language.  He sets out with his elderly backup deputy who is funny, a vain townsman and the injured husband of the woman taken.  Their trip is long and arduous and made worse when their horses are stolen.  Things look grim when the rescuers get captured by the mysterious, creepy tribe.  Kurt Russell is outstanding in his role, as are most of the cast.  Excellent script and there's enough gore to satisfy most without being overdone.

A b-grade flick at best with one name actor, Kurt Russell playing sheriff, trying to lift the load. Acting was at best mediocre ... but worse plot holes galore fill this film.

The film starts with two characters (one played by David Arquette) bushwhacking people on the trail and then being set upon themselves by some nasty aboriginal indians who didn't like them trespassing on their burial grounds. Ok, one of the dudes gets killed by an arrow, but the other one (Arquette's character) somehow manages to escape? Really. Not only that but he escapes on foot to some no name town a few days walk away, where the gets shot in the leg and put in a jail cell just for looking suspicious. Surprise, surprise the indians have manage to follow him. Huh, they follow him for a couple days but don't attack him? No... but the indians do manage to murder a stable boy, kidnap the jailor, the Arquette character and the wife of a local rancher who is treating his wound. All this without any shots fired or alarms raised in the process. Then they drag their captives on foot (no suggestion they had horses) back to some cave in the foot hills. The town finds out that their fellow citizens got taken and the sheriff assembles a rescue party made up of himself, his over the hill deputy, a professional indian fighter, and the husband of the captured female, who just happens to have been laid up with a broken leg awaiting a doctor to come to town to set it. Ok.. Ok...so the rescue team sets out on horseback the day following the kidnapping, but somehow can't seem to catch up the to marauding indians who are dragging their captives on foot? Really? Really? Plus how is it the sheriff is so dumb as to not send a request before taking off after the kidnappers asking the local cavalry to back up his rescue party? Not smart as subsequent events would prove.  Along the way the rancher with the broken leg takes a turn for the worse with what appears to be gangrene after hobbling around for a couple of days on a crutch - which necessitates the deputy being called into action to set the leg. Huh? First, setting a broken leg after gangrene sets in doesn't stop the gangrene. But apparently in this case it miraculously improves his condition so much that he can hobble even better and faster to catch up to his fellow rescuers, who have themselves now been captured by the indians. Second, how is it the deputy couldn't have set the guy's leg when he first broke it back in town before this whole absurd chase began?

In the final analysis this is really a pretty lame film, with one very unnecessary, disturbing, ultra violent scene near the end depicting the murder and cannibalization of the jailer character.

The best short review of Bone Tomahawk might be: You will see things you can't unsee.

The premise is great -- average western settler/cowboy types trying to recover a woman captured by Indians (sound familiar?) -- but Indians like none ever seen in a western before. The cast is outstanding -- Kurt Russell, an almost unrecognizable Richard Jenkins, Patrick Wilson, and Lili Simmons. All great.

Cinematography is mediocre. When you consider the astounding work done by John Ford or Clint Eastwood (among others), this film really fails to take advantage of landscape or light.

But the big problem is the horror angle. The worst of the gore is stomache churning. You may love it. But it may make the film unwatchable. In my opinion, just a bit of a reduction in the violence would have left the film more watchable, and perhaps even more scary.

Bone Tomahawk actually started out promising. The story was simple, as a western should be. But it jumped the shark about 2/3 of the way through the movie. The tribe of cannibals was so over the top, the violence so gory, that the entire thing became a shallow, repulsive mess. I find no fault with the performances; Kurt Russell was dependably gruff and stern as the sheriff,  and Patrick Wilson did a fine job as the aggrieved husband. Matthew Fox's character Brooder was probably the most interesting; he had a very strong sense of duty and justice, but at the same time was filled with a great deal of anger. Ultimately, the premise of the film doomed it, despite the best efforts of the actors. If you want to see a well-made western, I would recommend Unforgiven, Open Range, or 3:10 to Yuma, and skip this one.

All but the last 20 minutes of Bone Tomahawk is slow moving and does little to build suspense or character development. Bone Tomahawk suffers from the same problems of representation that many of its early- and mid-20th century counterparts did: barbaric portrayals of Native Americans under the guise of "godless savages" that need to be killed by civilized white cowboys. Unfortunately, most of the stereotypical cowboy-and-indian movies got made decades ago, and years of social progress and critical interrogation of acceptable stereotypes have prevented many of these kinds of projects from being launched in the 21st century. Unfortunately, Bone Tomahawk somehow got past the not-so-rigorous "Should we... uh... make this kind of film?" test that many scripts now fail. It's clear now why this film had to be independently financed: many studios were certainly reticent to attach their names (or money) to such an offensive and out-of-date premise.

The action sequences are fun, the gore almost plot-appropriate, and the acting is acceptable. But the movie suffers from a lack of plot, sloppy editing, a sophomoric directorial debut, and the shroud of racism that prevents the film's antagonists from being anything other than one-dimensional movie monsters. There is no intrigue, the central conflict is entirely predictable, and the film's outcome was obvious 20 minutes into the movie.

If you need to relive an era in which white people thought Native Americans were merely cannibalistic savages, then enjoy this nostalgia trap.

Given the generally favorable reviews for Bone Tomahawk, I was really looking forward to seeing it. Ultimately, the movie is done in by its length and a pacing that would be generously referred to as languid (probably accounting for its lack of a theatrical release).  Imagine some lame guy (literally not figuratively) limping across seemingly endless desert (which is exactly what happens for a good chunk of the run time) and you pretty much have how this one unspools.

Bone Tomahawk establishes its B movie credentials up front with none other than Sid Haig as a vile bushwhacker preying on sleeping travelers. Sid collects his check early, but accomplice David Arquette manages to survive their initial encounter with troglodyte savages. These primitives are of the ashy, dust-covered variety and look like they wandered over from Col. Kurtzs jungle hideaway. Arquette manages to get himself to the quiet little town of Bright Hope. For reasons disclosed later, the cannibal tribe pursues him there, does a little murder, steals horses and abducts the towns deputy and nurse for good measure (actually, for good eatin and good breedin, respectively). Its up to whiskered Kurt Russell in full Wyatt Earp / John Ruth mode to mount a search party and bring em back. Along for the ride are Matthew Fox as a soldier turned town dandy and the omnipresent Richard Jenkins as an elderly chatterbox. Also in tow is cowboy (and husband of the abducted nurse) Patrick Wilson whose character recently suffered a severe leg injury that threatens to go gangrene at any moment. After some bad breaks en route, the posse eventually shows up for their confrontation with those cave dwellers at a considerable disadvantage.

The acting and cast are truly first rate as is the script, which has period-appropriate dialogue and just enough humor to soften the super-grisly goings-on of the last act. No regrets about renting the DVD, just wish itd been about 40 min shorter. Oh yeah, and the butchering scene is a doozy. Three and a half stars from me.

This film marks one of the better if not the best performance of Kurt Russell in a film. The director is to be congratulated for keeping Mr. Russell's role as understated as it is and intelligent. This film reminded me of  the John Ford film "The Searchers" with John Wayne. That film was actually better than the short novel upon which the film was based. In the film with Mr. Russell are two outstanding supporting roles and are a pleasure to watch. As noted in other reviews there are some scenes in the last 20 or so minutes that are indeed gruesome. And there are a few nits to pick in the story line - but I did watch this fairly long film to the end w/o too much wincing.

Final act is a little...off, but that's only when compared to the rhythm of the preceding acts. Abrupt rhythm change aside, it's not for everyone; but if you like a slower-burn and films that focus on perfecting the little things in each scene, BT is a gem. Russell is completely in his element here, and Richard Jenkins as his "sidekick" provides just the right amount of sincerity and humor to give the flick a unique tone.

I wasn't really aware of this movie until after it had made its theatrical run, and I watched it streaming at home. Its definitely a genre bender, and all three of those genres are polarizing for mass audiences: western, black comedy, and horror. Throughout the majority of the film, it straddles western and deadpan comedy, then through the last 50 minutes or so, horror is the focus. To say that the former section was enjoyable to me is accurate: Im a fan of good dialog (I think its reasonable to say that if you like Tarantino-style dialog, youll enjoy this), and the characters are actually pretty well developed. This is to say that the focus is on the personalities of each character and how the characters react to each other and situations, not backstory (though there is some). I found the characters a mix of intelligent and endearing, despite some of their obvious flaws; all of them are well acted. The horror is actually very well done; there is a genuine sense of terror and dread for a long period of time, and its very obvious when this change occurs.

The plot is fairly straightforward: it follows a small group of frontiersmen attempting to rescue captured townspeople from a tribe of native Americans (the movie refers to them as Indians, but I wanted to be more specific). Id like to address some of the polarizing elements of this film. First, it takes a lot of cues from Western style cinema: this translates into a fairly slow pace for a large chunk of the movie. There are several scenes that are shot fairly long, so the acting is showcased. Second, the dialog is witty but its delivery is mostly deadpan, and theres a lot of nuance to some of it. Lastly, and Id argue the most controversial aspect of all, is its gore. The horror aspect is effective, but a lot of films don't depict violent acts on camera  this one does. There is one particular scene late in the movie that is likely to be stomach churning to most viewers, and while I consider myself to be pretty jaded when it comes to movie violence, I actually found my jaw hanging open in disbelief at what I saw on screen. If any of these aspects are likely to bother you, I wouldnt recommend it.

I thoroughly enjoyed Bone Tomahawk. While its fairly long (2:12), I never felt it dragged, and is consistently interesting. Those who want to try something different should absolutely check it out, though I could never give this a broad spectrum recommendation due to the aforementioned elements. This movie isn't for everyone, but its not made to be. For those that are up for something new and different, its well worth the watch.

This isn't really a horror movie, it's a Western in the old style that isn't really made anymore, with gruesome scenes that films back then didn't have.  Granted The Walking Dead, Hills Have Eyes and films/TV shows that fall under the horror genre have this sort of violent action but just because something is gory doesn't make it a horror film. This is your old townsfolk vs Indians storyline that stopped being made as it is well lets face it a little one sided historically recounting history speaking, and movies killing off native people isn't exactly that politically correct these days.  So the writers have sort of tweaked that old norm with this one, being the bad guys are obviously people who have lived where they do for a long time, long before the white settlers came there, but these aren't Indians, they are in fact feared by Indians who give the area they inhabit a wide birth.  They are Troglodytes or some similar name, if you've come across them, you probably never made it to another town to tell anyone, instead you probably ended up in their stomachs.

Being your typical posse chasing bad guys/rescuing those they've kidnapped type of Western, a lot of the film is on horseback, walking or sitting around a fire so there's not much action between the beginning and end.  Bone Tomahawk as well as being a gruesome film is sort of mildly also making fun of the Western genre in the same but not as strong and obvious way Scream did for slasher horror flicks. With scenes such as Patrick Wilson with a bad leg making love to his wife with her on top for his comfort but getting too embarrassed and wanting to do it the normal way. Or the sheriff asking some other guy to stay with the doctor so he can go home while she operates on the guy he shot, and he rebuts with something like, isn't that the deputy's job, isn't that the the whole point of having a deputy.

If you're squeamish Bone Tomahawk probably isn't the movie for you, if you don't like slow movies, then perhaps you'll want to fast forward the middle.  If you can't watch a movie that is a little bit unrealistic and far fetched in telling the story you might also want to give this is a miss. But if you want a good Western that isn't afraid to make fun of the genre from time to time, and be a little cheesy at others, you won't go wrong with this one.

The western is a genre that has had it's ups and downs over the past few decades, after being the mainstay of US cinema for almost half a century. This is a exquisitely detailed, character-rich western that, for about 75% of it's running time, could have been written in the 1950's. The last act of the film, however, takes a full 90 degree turn into the most intense horror experience in recent memory. Be warned, it is NOT for the faint of heart.

That said, this is a masterfully crafted, richly rewarding film experience that is destined to become a classic in the years to come. Russell is in his finest form as Sheriff Franklin Hunt; an honest, straight-shooting lawman with integrity, grit, and loyalty as his defining traits. He also selflessly gives the movie (and all the best lines) over to his deputy Chickory, played by the wonderful Richard Jenkins in one of the finest character turns in recent memory.

I won't go into a lot of plot details, as this is a film that you should really watch cold, with as little information as possible going in to it. Suffice it to say that the story is a cross between John Ford's THE SEARCHERS and Craven's THE HILLS HAVE EYES, and if that description alone doesn't make you want to rush out to see it, then I don't know what will.

First-time director S. Craig Zahler has made one of the most impressive debuts of the new millennium with this superb film. Do yourself a favor, and don't miss it.

This is what I wanted The Hateful 8 to be - conversations are more natural and the build up of tension, waiting for the enemy to attack, is outstanding. I love this movie and it's slow burn of tension. It starts like a normal "hyper realistic western" (whatever that means) that we are used to, and goes beyond that. Jenkins should, but won't, get a nod at the Oscars for this. His performance of an aging cowboy trying to stay in his prime is so fun to watch. Seriously, the side dialogue that builds the characters is a combo of Clerks meets Reservoir Dogs in the best way possible. I laughed at this movie because of its genuine humor as much as I gasped at its insane gruesome horror. HIGHLY recommended.

The holes in the plot were so vast with little explanation of the ridiculous protagonist.  They then tried to patch up the flaws with over the top turn away gore and lines that were supposed to be heartfelt but came out as flat and uninspiring. I so wanted to like this show but as the movie continued it became more apparent that I should have not even started it. If you're looking for something similar with better acting, a more believable story, and inspiring characters watch The Missing with Tommy Lee Jones.

Bone Tomahawk has to be one of the most, if not THE most infuriating films I have encountered (as a film historian and film maker myself, I have experienced plenty).  Rather than a tediously drawn-out review here, I will be succinct to spare you all.

First, I was lured in, or duped really, into watching Bone Tomahawk by a decent-looking trailer. A new, fresh take on a Western. Check. A grizzled, understated (non-Carpenter directed) Kurt Russell. Check. Then to make sure I was not deluding myself, I read a plethora of reviews. While there were a few that admonished to stay away, there were enough solid reviews to take the chance. Check.

The trailer does not at all depict just how dreadful the pacing is. Yack and bicker some, ride slowly, camp at night. Yack and bicker some, ride slowly for what seems to be days, camp at night. Repeat and rinse until you nearly (& desperately) turn the clunker off. Also excruciating, is one of the lead characters. He whines and whines and whines. I wanted to free spar with this bitchy worm more than punish my eyes, ears and movie soul. My two movie guests would stop me as I motioned to shut it down. Why so? "Yes, this is terrible, but we have already invested.... you know the rest of this classic maneuver for funky films. I concurred, yet grumbled demands that, "This had BETTER get better, or..."  Well, the whiney, pathetic character never may have maintained his King-of-S***e status throughout, but the film DID need to be completed--just to say that I made it and for the last act.

Now, I am not at all contending that the movie was salvaged by the final act, but I do feel that, as painful and disgusting as it was to behold, everyone up for a "B (or C in this case) movie night should try and make it to the end of Bone Tomahawk. Why? Well, you know how everrrry once in a while most of us grow tired of searching for the next great, classic film, and say, "Let's make popcorn and watch bad B-films tonight!" THIS is one of those films. Sure the cinematography is s***e (forget the cool grainy vibe of film here--more akin to a bad tv/soap opera look). Sure, you will want to kill one of the lead actors or at least hope for his demise during their bicker-ride-camp extravaganza. Yes, you may even question your sanity for having completed this mondo-bizarro stinker. Yes, you would rather pierce your butt cheeks than sit through the final cave scenes. Still, you will be able to tell your children that you survived Bone Tomahawk!

Bone Tomahawk is a film fusion of the Western and Horror genres. The understated script and plot manage to give you the proverbial kick to the head.

You have the classic Western elements: The stoic sheriff, the loyal deputy, the determined cowboy and the loner gunslinger that team up against the outside threat.

Then, Bone Tomahawk veers away from the classic plot line and the threat isn't the usual the cowboys from the trail who descend on the town or the rich local rancher who is taking over the water rights.  You have the classic Horror elements: The night time raid, the crazy killers. Then as with the Western elements, the Horror takes a sharp right turn into unusual territory. These antagonists aredifferent, even by the usual Horror standards.

For most of the film you have the usual out on the trail, banter among the posse and the scenery. And then about ten percent of what the heck just happened there?!. The film has an R-rating for a reason; with that said, your senses aren't overloaded with graphic violence.

I cant really recommend this to Western fans even though it does have all the usual staples of the Western film; theres a shock factor here so keep that in mind I also cant recommend this to Horror fans because there isn't enough of the slash and blood factor if thats your usual thing.

I *will* recommend this film to the enthusiast (either Western or Horror) who wants something different. And yes, this film is different. The cast pulls it off excellently. Bone Tomahawk is that rare film which combines genres and pulls it off. If you want an entertaining and disturbing film that showcases both the indomitable spirit and brutality of men during the frontier era (with some possible historical mythology thrown in?), then check out this film.

As a historical horror fiction (?), this movie is a bit slow on capturing interest.  However, as a behavior study of a manly-man (Kurt Russell, the Sheriff) adeptly massaging decision pathways into consistently altruistic, intuitive, morally-correct decisions (within the context of his small, well-controlled frontier town) without weakening, is truly inspiring.  The movie's best feature is the verbal interplay between Kurt & his less than perfect, 3-person posse: an old deputy with dementia that is seemingly kept on the payroll for easy, routine, 'go-fer' jobs; a wealthy dapper young man, in dapper clothes, riding a dapper horse confides that he is an expert Indian-killer; and, a young cattle drover who is disabled from a broken leg.  It's his young wife who is kidnapped by a previously unknown, self-isolating, cave-dwelling, cannabalistic tribe...  Loved the script, but the cannibal scene will haunt me like the old 'Wagon Train' episode involving saber tooth tigers!

Except for the gross butchering of a man the story was interesting. Not one of Russell's better films. Still on the fence about the graphic visions the director felt necessary (I'm guessing) were okay. If the evil graphics had been eliminated the movie would've been too slow.

Bone Tomahawk is an anomaly in that it is in all aspects a Western flick but with a unique twist due to the horrible antagonists in the film. The beauty of it is that it never reaches the point of implausibility. The monstrous characters aren't fake or flashy. They are monstrous and horrifying but very real and well done. It is a gritty, captivating but slow developing film but is an entertaining ride and if you like Kurt Russell it won't disappoint. They manage to work in some mild comedic dialogue as well. Overall it is an entertaining western with a new angle.

Kurt Russell, of course, is a great actor and portrays a soul who is incredibly noble and praiseworthy. I have only praise for his acting and role.

But whoever produced this film--surely you could have portrayed his amazing character in a better light. Seriously, do you really think all of that gore and vileness was necessary? Why do you think we would want want to see something this horrendous? Do you really think we would want to pay good money to see actors cut off a man's scalp and force-feed it to him; then, cut him in half AT HIS LOINS, dump his guts onto the ground with a loud thud and eat him with no regard whatsoever for his humanity? What kind of people do you think we are?!!!!! Such depravity!

No more words. Just pain and sorrow. Wow. Just wow. So sad.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

Bone Tomahawk is the creation of one S. Craig Zahler who is listed in Wikipedia as a jack of all trades: "author, screenwriter, songwriter, musician, director and cinematographer." Zahler's concoction fits into a literary sub-genre known as "weird west"again thanks to Wikipedia we learn that this sub-genre "combines elements of the Western with another literary genre, usually horror, occult, or fantasy."

Zahler is content to promulgate the myth of a violent, wild west, replete with cowboys armed with six-shooters and rapacious Indians bent on scalping the first settler they see. Unfortunately, the reality is that the so-called wild west was far less violent than what we see today regarding criminal activity. You can find late 19th century photos on the internet from places like Dodge City, sporting billboards that read "the carrying of firearms is strictly forbidden."

Zahler's chief desire appears to be out-dueling Tarantino for the coveted most in love with violence writer/director award in American cinema today. Indeed, he begins his magnum opus with Tweedledum and Tweedledee killers, Purvis and Buddy, who murder innocent travelers off the beaten path. Buddy, as you may already know, falls victim to a bunch of Indians who I guarantee did not exist in the 1890s when the film takes place (nor ever existed), and Purvis then makes his way to the town of Bright Hope, which was filmed at the Paramount Ranch.

This location has been used for years as a stand-in for a small, wild western town. Unfortunately, Zahler's low budget prevented his crew from making enough alterations so that the town appears lived in. Zahler trots out a few stock characters including the sheriff Franklin Hunt (decently played by Kurt Russell), his old codger backup deputy, Chicory, and John Brooder, a more intellectual "ladies man," who attempts to summon the town doctor after Hunt shoots bad guy Purvis who can't keep himself from acting up at the local saloon. With the doctor drunk, Brooder finds the doctor's assistant, Samantha, who has just finished a steady bout of lovemaking with her husband Arthur O'Dwyer, a foreman who's laid up in bed with a nasty leg injury.

While Hunt, Chicory and Brooder investigate the murder of a stable hand (the usual "dispensable" black guy), Samantha, Hunt's regular deputy Nick and Purvis are found to be missing back at the jail. Instead of summoning help (perhaps in the form of military personnel), Hunt forms an unlikely posse including Chicory and Brooder and is talked into allowing O'Dwyer (who can barely walk with his injured leg) to trek through the wilderness, hoping to locate their missing compatriots. O'Dwyer's love (or should I say lust?) is so great that he's willing to crawl through the desert to find his lost Samantha.

Before they depart, an arrow found at the jail is examined by a local Native American wise man who links it to a place called "Valley of the Starving Men," where a group of troglodytes (cave-dwellers) is probably to blame for the kidnapping of Samantha and the deputy. The wise man (who sounds more like a professor at a local college), advises that the troglodytes are shunned by normal Native Americans and in fact are cannibalistic savages.

The next sequence (which is quite long) involves the posse heading for hostile territory. Along the way, Brooder kills two Mexican scouts and later the group's horses are stolen by rustlers. O'Dwyer re-injures his leg after fighting with Brooder and is left by the rest of the group to recuperate (before insanely trying to rejoin them, again basically crawling through the desert).

I will not detail how exactly the posse ends up imprisoned in the troglodytes' cave but suffice it to say Brooder is the first casualty. While Zahler perhaps technically cannot be accused of racism because he makes it clear that his troglodytes are an ostracized group of Native Americans, the introduction of these characters into the narrative, leaves a bad taste in one's mouth. First of all, these type of "savages" were never known to exist in the "wild west," but are still associated here with Native American culture. All disclaimers aside, the mere image of Native Americans perpetrating ghastly acts of savagery on "white people" should be enough to upset any Native American when he ponders such "untruths" in a darkened movie theater. Of course the reality is that acts of savagery occurred the other way aroundit was the US military of course which was responsible for the great numbers of heinous crimes against the Native American population during the 19th century.

The pointlessness of Zahler's tale reaches its apotheosis when the audience is forced to witness the scalping of Nick the deputy and his dismemberment at the hands of the zombie-like troglodytes. If we must witness such cheap thrills, why doesn't Zahler turn his zombies into a bunch of aliens so that the perpetuation of the myth of the savage "Indian," is repudiated?

Perhaps with the dismemberment scene Zahler has gone toe to toe with Tarantino, and won. In addition to Zahler's apparent victory over the master of gore himself, I am also forced to conclude that Bone Tomahawk defies its internal logic (how does O'Dwyer manage to get himself up into the cave with his injured leg? And why does Samantha remain apparently untouched by the savage troglodytes?)

Is there a more pointless film than Bone Tomahawk among the selection of Spirit Award hopefuls? I don't think so. Not only is it pointless but offensive to boot. See it at your peril!

then watch Bone Tomahawk!!!  This movie is not what you think.  It is one of the best western movies around and it also happens to be a horror movie and a comedy.  Trust me when I say you will not be disappointed.  Kurt Russell is amazing but the standout performance is Richard Jenkins!!  He delivers such a powerful performance which is deceptively downplayed that it isn't until later that you realize he was the glue that helped his group survive (well some of them anyway).  The movie builds slowly giving you time to get to know the characters and it also builds the horror factor because you don't know where it will come from.  As the movie progresses you see that the men are more brave than you can possibly imagine as they race to face an enemy they never imagined in their wildest dreams.  Early on you get a glimpse of what is waiting for them, and so do they, and yet they still go out in an attempt to save two of their own.  I don't want to give too much away because I think it should be experienced to be believed, but watch this movie...IF YOU WANT TO SEE ONE OF THE MOST HORRIFIC MURDER SCENES EVER...

I love Kurt Russell and so decided to check this movie out.  It started out slow and very very low key.  I waited and waited and waited and boring.  But I couldn't stop watching it because as slow as it was and as lacking it was in dialog and story content, you just have to know what in the heck is going to happen.  So you hang in there and finally get to the end and go what?  It was like a slow drone of a few days that meander along like the lazy slow moving river and has no excitement just a lazy day kind of feeling.  The end is non climatic and you wonder what this whole thing was supposed to be about.  Well it is about a short period of time where the good guys find the disappearance of the deputy and good guys wife mysterious and go on a man hunt to find the tribe that was behind it all.  That's it.  They go through some grueling setbacks and the good guys injury actually puts you in pain not to mention how awful it makes the whole story but again you can't stop watching it because you have to find out how this all ends.  I think this would have been better as a 1 hour movie on tv.  And it's not for lack of good acting by Kurt and company.  They did a great job with the little bit they had to work with.  It was the story line and the plot and the long drawn out way they told the story.  If you are bored and have nothing else to watch, you may enjoy this but if you are looking for a great Kurt Russell movie move on to one of his much better films.

Bone Tomahawk was a surprise. The storyline was interesting, character development was decent, and the action was good. Although, I don't think this fits as a typical western. It had very violent sequences that could easily fall into the horror genre. When I say horror, I mean that moments were intense, the gore was extreme at times, and adversaries were monstrous (behaviorally and somewhat physically). The acting was superb, and the situations were believable and realistic--no superheroes in this one; the characters are vulnerable leaving the viewer wondering who will survive the dilemma. The movie was a little long but only felt slow early. Once the movie got going I never had that feeling again. If you like gritty westerns with  intense horrorish elements, this one might be for you.

This is one of the better modern day westerns that has been produced resent memory. Kurt Russell does an excellent job leading this remarkable cast and taking the viewer on an exciting and harrowing adventure. The opening scene with David Arquette and Sid Haig sets in motion a nightmarish thrill ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Not for the faint of heart. There are some pretty gruesome scenes of savagery throughout this film. Nothing gratuitous as it is probably very true to the time period in which the film is set, but none the less graphic in nature. I highly recommend this film to anyone with an interest in westerns and especially those who like a little blood and guts with their cowboys and indians.

I have always enjoyed Western movies and also Kurt Russell in any movie I have ever seen with him. The plot concerns the kidnapping of the sheriff's deputy  and a married woman whose husband has a leg injury and is bedridden. It is known that Indians were behind the raid and are identified by an arrow used in the killings of town folk to be a peculiar tribe. A posse is formed, the husband demands to go along to rescue his wife with the sheriff, his older deputy and a dandy who hates Indians and asked how many he had killed and was told not enough. For the next hour or so, the the movie starts to drag, The posse runs into trouble in the night when there horses are stolen and they have to continue on foot. The crippled still continues on with them. They finally reach where the tribe is camped in a cave on a high cliff. They are attacked, captured and the dandy is killed. The sheriff and his deputy are brought into the cave and  caged. Across from them is the woman who is still alive. The next scene is gruesome, they find out this tribe consists of cannibals in a horrifying way of preparing their victims to be cooked and eaten. Needless to say, the ending is not completely done with all being killed, and the woman is rescued and the survivors retunn to their town

Lets be real......because this movie sure isn't.  I decided to watch it because I love westerns and Kurt Russell is a draw, especially after his excellent portrayal as Wyatt Earp in Tombstone, and I wasn't disappointed in his acting as a sheriff in this movie....but the story and the plot, egad, the writer must have gotten his idea from a double dose of LSD, or at least while eating several bushels of Denver cookies!!  I mean, Yuck!!  His aborigine people eaters who delight in taking a good scalp before dinner, look and sound like "The Predator."  How original is that!!!  In one scene where seconds before the sherif's deputy is being stripped, scalped, held upside down, and halved, the sherif (Kurt Russell) watching with horror from his cave cell behind primitive bars, true to the script shouts,  not to worry, "the calvary's coming," just before the axe falls cutting the deputy completely in half.  You've heard of "half a beef"? well......., now imagine this, you're high up in a cave in the middle of nowhere, held upside down by a couple of cannibals, naked, scalped, about to be cut in half, and your friend shouts not to worry, the calvary's coming!!  I mean, you gotta feel guilty knowing it's a downright shame to laugh watching a scene like that!!  And why does everybody have a dull knife?  Every time someone is cutting out a larynx, or just plain slitting, it takes forever for the knife to do its job....Good for letting us see a bunch of blood and gore and to imagine the pain, but didn't they believe in sharpening stuff back then?  The script writer does show that he is knowledgeable however, and a man of facts, when after a bad guy slits a throat he asks, "How come they always wet themselves?"  See, most people don't even know that, but by golly the writer wants us all to know that he does and is not some ignorant person!!  Like a good country song that just has to have women, whiskey and trains in it, this movie has a little something for everyone, a little sex, a pinch of  humour, a touch of drama, lots of bloody gore, and absolutely no reality.  But not wanting to appear unjust or closed minded, I have given it a gold star.  :)

I'm a big fan of the horror genre, so I was interested to see Bone Tomahawk when it turned up on Amazon Video.

I can't put my finger on exactly why I was disappointed. The movie just didn't seem to develop compulsive momentum -- it just "mosey-ed" along to it's dramatic conclusion, and then was over. The characters were, by and large, well-cast, but seemed to grow hum-drum during the long, long center portion of the movie (the horse ride of the posse). Then, suddenly, the action peaked and it was over.

Seems like the writers could have told the story better; built the suspense more steadily; and built to the finale more methodically.

If you prefer to live in the "John Wayne" vision of what the west was like - do NOT rent or buy this movie.  However, if you get that sometimes things were pretty savage & brutal - and sometimes a movie must portray that in order to tell a story - then you will enjoy this.  I covered my eyes for a few spots, and ears.  I would probably watch it again - mainly because now I know where to leave the room.

Not really a horror film, but a classic Western story, albeit one with more stylized gore than a typical Western. The movie takes a fresh look at classic Western motifs such as the search for a wife abducted by savages (in this case bearing no resemblance to any American Indian tribe, past or present), the garrulous sidekick, the sheriff determine to do his duty and the dandy who is deadly with his guns.

It's either a 2-star or 4-star.  The missus didn't think much of it, though she thought Kurt's role was a good one.  As a spoof, it was a solid 4-stars.  The production had a little feel of a "Breaking Bad" episode (eg, the capture of Russell and his assistant deputy at the opening of the "troglodytes' " entrance) with a little Q. Tarantino mixed in--like , how miraculous was that leg recovery of Mr. O'Dowd's?

Maybe an old western version of Escape from NY,  I had no idea about the movie's story line--I just saw Kurt on the box cover and played it via Amazon Prime.  Don't let your kids see this one before you do.  Fortunately, my kids are in their 30's.

The cave scenes were, purposefully, over the top; while some of it worked, the butchery--literally--of the younger deputy was too --what???  The gang members were also clearly Gentile.

Brilliant? No.  Hilarious in places? Yes.  I'd love to know if the gang of deviant Indians was a pure contrivance or if they actually had a historical link somewhere.

The story needed to explain more....  By way of example, the women of the "troglodytes", were pregnant, crippled and deformed, as well as blinded - how did they raise their children?  Also, how did Patrick Wilson's character, with a leg ready to be amputated, miraculously heal enough for him to rescue the prisoners, and walk home?  In addition, how did Patrick Wilson's character get into the cave of the troglodytes?  Also, apparently, the troglodytes use jewelry as a mechanism to make sounds.  How does the jewelry become embedded and why?  This could really be a great movie, just too many unexplained items.

I made it a point not to read reviews for Bone Tomahawk because I'm a long-time fan of Kurt Russell and also enjoy Westerns that offer dialog ripe with an authentic rural cadence. At first blush, this is an original and oddly compelling film featuring really enjoyable performances from Russell and the cast, especially Richard Jenkins who's never been better. As I'd hoped, the dialog sounds authentically archaic and manages to be witty and believable but as the film moves into some genuinely chilling sequences, the graphic violence just became too extreme for me. It's been a long time since I've looked away from a screen. I won't be watching this one a second time.

I loved this movie and it was nothing like I thought it was going to be. There are some slow and deliberate parts in this movie. Is it dull? No way. Even in the quieter moments when the men are just walking along or sitting by the campfire, the dialogue takes over. A little wit, a little humor, some serious business and a little violence from time to time. Richard Jenkins plays the backup Deputy, Chicory, to Kurt Russell's Sherriff, Hunt. Chicory is an old timer who has a story for everything and continues to talk, ask questions or offers his opinions throughout the movie. Much to the chagrin of some of the other party members. Kurt Russell is on his game here and Jenkins steals his thunder. But don't underestimate the performances of Patrick Wilson (Arthur O'Dwyer) and Matthew Fox as Brooder. The movie starts out violent. Sid Haig and David Arquette open things up at a camp sight with Arquette using his knife to cut open a campers neck. The crunching sound of his knife through flesh is the first thing you hear. From there they stumble upon a burial site. Most likely Indian. They are on the run after killing the campers so they end up in a bad place. After one is killed violently, the other ends up in the Sherriff's jail cell. Patrick Wilsons wife attends to a bullet in the prisoners leg while being watched by the true Deputy, Nick, played by Evan Jonigkeit. When morning rolls around Wilson, who has a broken leg, it is important, notices his wife isn't home. Then a stable boy shows up dead. The prisoner, Deputy Nick and O'Dwyer's wife are all missing. Abducted. O'Dwyer, Sherriff Hunt, Brooder and the vocal Backup Deputy, Chicory head out on a trip to find the missing. After showing an arrow to a local expert on Indians, they have a position to look for the missing. Things are not what they seem, trust me. What they end up seeing and experiencing once there, is completely beyond what you would will be expecting. It is violent, extremely violent and bloody. There are some extremely disturbing images once they show what happens inside the kidnappers cave. One characters ending is just repulsive. And another's is not as bad but disgusting for sure. If you like westerns but not horror, then don't watch. If you can deal with whatever a movie can show you, then this is it. I loved this movie. Give it a chance as long as you know what to expect as far as violence and blood is concerned.

I have a new favorite screen writer:  Craig Zahler

Let me preface this by saying that I clicked on this film by accident.  I meant to hit "Inside Man" but this cued up instead so I thought I'd give it it's day in court.  WooHoo! So glad I did!

It looked like a western, sounded like a western, but delivered like a Cormac McCarthy novel.  Craig Zahler is a genius (and a freak in a really good way).  He wrote this, directed this, and made me a FAN!

Bone Tomahawk moves like a cat from beginning to end.  I had some idea where it was going but wasn't expecting to be entertained to such a high level and I never expected such glorious gore delivery.

I could kiss whomever is responsible for this  dialogue.  Richard Jenkins nails it every time he opens his mouth.  Kurt Russell's dead-pan delivery made me feel a tad wicked for giggling through some of the nastier stuff but every word was a pleasure.

So sad that "Saucy" was collateral damage ( she was a nice looking mare) but the rest of the blood-n-gore was terrific!  The kill scenes alone  were worth the price of admission and the maiming stuff was off the hook.

To hell with free shipping, this is what I paid my "Prime" membership for.

Remember when intelligent screenplays were the basis for films? Bone Tomahawk is a pleasant throwback to those mostly-bygone days. Kurt Russell leads an outstanding ensemble cast in this modestly-budgeted, script-driven tale of heroism and loss in the Old West. Russell seems born to play Sheriff Hunt, the no-nonsense but all-too human lawman who is charged with assembling a posse to rescue kidnapped townspeople from a nearly extinct tribe of cannibalistic Native Americans. Russell conveys the pathos of leading a seemingly-doomed mission in true old-school fashion, with few words and a heavy gun hand. The supporting cast is nothing less than outstanding with veteran actor Richard Jenkins the standout as the verbose and largely ineffectual "back-up deputy" Chicory. The limits of our heroes' endurance, morality and cunning are tested on their journey and the plot spirals into a shockingly violent and gory conclusion. The presence of A-level talent like Russell and Patrick Wilson is a testament to the quality of this production, and I only hesitate to award this film five stars because the limited budget seems to hold it back from becoming the sprawling, Dances With Wolves-style epic that it so narrowly misses being. Support this film and send Hollywood a message: give us smart movies again, we deserve it after putting up with the last three decades of your over-budgeted, under-scripted garbage.

Behind this terrible title is a surprising, well-crafted thriller with topnotch acting and quirky but very human characters. Richard Jenkins sells half the show with his portrayal of a simple-minded old man who rambles on endlessly in what turns out to be very well-written little reveries about weird unexpected bits of life in the old west. Kurt Russell's great, and the relationship between Patrick Wilson and Lili Simmons is cool.

It feels low budget at times, mostly because of the small cast and small sets, and in the end when you finally meet the horrible villains starts to feel a little monster-of-the week. I would have given Bone Tomahawk 4 out of 5 stars, but the fifth star is to hopefully raise the profile of this film I don't think many people have heard of. Again, don't be put off by the bad title, this is a quality film with a fresh, interesting, intense take on a classical western storyline. If you're looking for something that's both fun AND smart, with unexpected quality, this is a real diamond in the rough.

" Wow " , I do not understand criticisms of this movie. The negative one's I should clarify. Excellent characters, great performances and gritty realism make this a classic for me. The odds were against them from the outset and this did not deter them from their mission. It has a level of character study that in places reminds me of the vibe of Eastwoods  Unforgiven. Although less space between pivotal moments. This is no dig because Unforgiven was the movie that separated my initial love of all things Western to my actual involvement with the whole of the experiences'. Meaning for me it did not have to be lead flying all movie long any more. Bone Tomahawk offers more overall action than Unforgiven yet is tempered by really telling the whole story. Great film, at least watch it once and decide for yourself. I purchased it and can not wait to see it again.  Nice ending as well because you really are not sure what will transpire . Good to guess and not be right.

Watched a weird movie on Amazon last night.  It was called Bone Tomahawk.  Check out the preview sometime.  I had never heard of it but it stared Kurt Russel and had Matthew Fox and David Arquette and Patrick Wilson.  I don't know the actors in the movie by name except for Kurt and David but I could recognize them as I have seen them before in many movies.  It also had a pretty lady in it, her name was Lili SImmons, I think.  It sort of reminded me of Cowboys and Aliens, But only a very teeny tiny bit, very teeny tiny bit.  I can't say it was a bad movie, just, an odd, weird, gross and somewhat graphic movie.  I really think they didn't need to be so graphic and gross and show all of what they showed but it does have a story to tell.  A made up gross story.  Spoiler ALERT!  "think Cannibals"
  SO I'm not really sure if I liked it or not.  I think for the most part I did like it.
  I takes place in the wild-west during the cowboy days, and these bad murderous thieves get the attention of some cannibalistic animal people.  ..not good.  So the law, Sheriff Kurt and his posse, go out in pursuit of. well, I'm getting ahead of myself.  They do go out and have to pursue one bad guy and some other along with the damsel, hot looking doctor woman, and bring them back.

  like I said, I don't know yet if I liked it because of all the graphic, sick stuff they showed that wasn't needed (in my opinion) but it was something I watched.  Fairly good story and good acting I think and even had nice scenes as in filming locations and making it look like the wild  type of west.

  Can't  give it a thumbs up or down right now, and don't know if it's rate-able but it is something. Without the sick gross stuff, it's good I think. It is a little slow compared to today's action movies but it is a western sort of moive.

Outside of a slow start, which isn't really so much a slow start as it is a stage setting 15 or 20 minutes, this was very well done. The attention to detail, not just costume design but set design that included the things that you would have found but overlooked in most movies like the fitting doors and floor boards that don't actually close anything out, was fantastic. The cinematography, particularly shots where travel on horseback was involved, was amazing  but with backdrops like that there was a lot to work with. Still, that the effort was put into the production aspect of the film is rewarding for the viewer when you get to watch this movie in high definition. As for the plot, no spoilers, so no discussion  refer to the description provided by Amazon. I'm just going to leave this with the observation that it took a particular kind of person to Go West. I was very impressed with the cast they assembled for this.  The acting was quite good, and I very much liked both Matthew Fox and Richard Jenkins in their respective roles.  The journey to the final confrontation seemed a bit drawn out, and I wish they would have played up the horror angle of a lost/degenerate tribe of cannibals living in a remote area a bit more in some fashion (perhaps if the Professor hadn't offered up the "troglodyte" descriptor so early and the rescue party was operating under the impression it was another Indian tribe).  However, overall, I quite enjoyed this movie.  Recommended.

I hated to give this movie 2 stars. I love Kurt Russell and was happy to see him in a new movie and of course he's a fantastic actor. The other actors were also great. The directing was excellent. The movie started slow but I felt that set the mood well. This is not your average western which becomes apparent soon enough and the excitement and tension increase from there. Unpredictable also and novel. The STORY was compelling. The major problem I have with this movie came near the end. I do not understand what all the hullabaloo about guns was regarding this movie because it's a western for pete's sake so expect shooting and dying. I don't even have a problem with the story premise. My problem with this movie was how graphically the premise was illustrated which I felt was way over the top and disgusting. Be careful what you let into your head because once it's in there, you will never get it out. Now I'll have those images and  sounds in my head forever. I had to close my eyes for a while. I considered turning it off at that point but it was so near the end that I felt the director probably already made his point and wouldn't harry it to death and I wanted to see how the characters ended up. If you are sensitive at all to disgusting gore, without giving away the premise, you may want to reconsider or ask somebody else who watched it and who knows you to advise whether you should watch it. I'm a little angry that such a wonderful movie contained such disgustingly graphic imagery. Too bad because that spoiled it for me. I hope Kurt Russel plays in another movie soon. I like him.

I told myself I wouldn't write a review. But here I am .. this movie is absolutely terrible. It has no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The central theme is these "troglodytes" (humanoids) and we never get any development on this. The entire story, the journey, the finale - absolutely awful. Kurt Russell is a great actor, but this is a total POS. Do not buy it. Horrid script, writing, story. I mean they didn't even capitalize on the ridiculous central theme. This is very much a B movie, with (mostly) A production (questionable editing). This type of movie is a vehicle for ultra-low budget straight to video sequels. I can foresee these humanoids coming back in sequel type movies based on them.

If I could give zero stars, I would. The scene at the end was unnecessarily gruesome and disturbing. I even had my hand over the screen to avoid seeing all the gory details, but didn't mute out the sound fast enough.  And a week later I still can't get the horrific images out of my head. There was no need for a scene like that. It could have been done with innuendo if the director truly felt it was needed to further the story.  This movie needs to come with a serious warning. And if the violence of that scene doesn't bother you, you should be concerned.

I have watched movies like Band of Brothers, Pacific and Braveheart which have a good deal of violent scenes and I enjoyed them. Think The Hills Have Eyes meets a 90's style western. Lots of violence and gore. Decent performances from the Kurt Russel and Matthew Fox. The plot was mostly lacking - monstrous cannibals who live in a hill which is apparently close enough to a civilized town for them to raid the city, yet somehow this has never happened prior to the events of this movie. They come to take a drifter, who escaped them previous, who was in custody, as well as a deputy and the town doctor, a woman (a bit out of place for the time period). The cannibals are supposed to be natives to the Americas, but they look like fat, pasty, white dudes with some bad makeup on them. Despite three members of the city having been attacked by a settlement of cannibals, only  4 men, one of whom is seriously injured, set out to attempt to retrieve the 3 people taken hostage.  If this doesn't make a lot of sense to you, then skip this one, because the rest of the movie will make even less sense.

I don't do movie reviews but I do want to comment on this one. It's been a while since the Western genre has faded off ......this is a very good one. The language I suppose is appropriate to the time period and adds to the flavor; there is little to dislike here. I don't know how realistic it would be to find "cave dwellers" living a stone-age lifestyle in the time period depicted in the movie, but it sure makes for a very interesting and different "cowboy and Indians" movie! It does get a bit gory at times, but adds to the 'realism' of pain and suffering. I think this is one of the very best roles I've seen Kurt Russell perform - loved it.

When I was looking for a good action movie to watch one night I thought a Western with Kurt Russell was a no brainer. I loved him in Tombstone so I thought this would similar... Heck no! From the minute this movie started, it was a gore fest. I kept thinking that it would get better since there was some story and character development. At one point I thought I'd turn it off but I was hoping for some closure for all the savagery. Unfortunately it got worse. In fact, for days I couldn't get those images out of my head. An interesting take on the old west in that it's styled a bit by being gothic horror interlaced. Certain physical aspects of the "monsters" are unexplained, which would be ok if the premise was so incredibly ourtrageous. Also, some might interpret the film as being anti-American Indian in a grotesque portrayal. I can understand that, but beyond that - I think it plays along a couple more interesting levels. Firstly, again, it's partly a horror story - and in a horror story, you never know that much about the monster. That's why it's scary. Secondly, I think it might be a good insight as to what white people feared most about the native peoples - and in the white persons retelling of experiences with the native Americans, those who listen could and would imagine the most horrifying of pictures in their heads. It's a pretty good movie, if you can look at it on those interpretive lines. And of course, as always, Kurt Russel is his awesome self.

This was a slightly bizarre story, and quite unbelievable.  A woman and a prisoner are abducted by savages.  The sheriff (played by Kurt Russell, whose performance was stellar in spite of the weird story) gathers a possie to go and save them.  Along the way the woman's husband breaks his leg.  The only thing they could do for hom was to tie two brances to his leg and give him another tree limb to use as a crutch.  He continues to accompany the possy, but falls behind.  The sheriff and the others track the savages to their lair, where they find some primieval like beings with strange apparatuses inserted into their larynx' that enables them to make some very odd screeching noises.  Oh, and these savages are cannibals.  And did I mention that this is a Western?  There is more weirdness, but I don't want to spoil it for you.  This movie has the potential to become a rotten tomato award winner, but do not look for it at the Oscars.

Half western, half horror movie. How can you go wrong. Kept me interested and invested in the film, the entire time. Acting very good, Kurt Russell did and excellent job. Was a bit understated, than in his usual roles. Which was key to buying into the movie. For the plot, kept you near the edge of your seat, a small twist here, a turn there, made it interesting. Hard to buy into the way the movie resolved itself, but use the tag line true love can conquer all, and it is plausible. If you are a fan of either genre the movie will be an experience you will enjoy, and think about for days to come.

BONE TOMAHAWK is one of those movies where all the money went into big name stars, with very little left to get a good writer. The character provide a great dramatic base which is never developed, or even explored. Every single person in this movie is nothing more than a flat silhouette.

The premise is a moderately good one, an attractive nurse lady is kidnapped by a band of inbred renegade Indians, and the town's sheriff/husband/old-suitor must go and get her back. But there are too many plot holes to count in the story (believe me I tried!).

A violent and unflinching depiction of the American West. This is how you make a low budget western. Concentrate on characters and story. The cast is excellent and well suited to their roles. You get a great sense of the west being a vast wasteland interspersed with pockets of fragile civilization. The action is easily followed and tense. There are scenes that are  uncomfortably violent and the camera captures them with an unflinching clinical gaze reminiscent of films such as men behind the sun. These moments are shocking and they are meant to be. incorpoarting concepts of both the western and horror genres, the film is entertaining, shocking, and if you can look past the seminal moments you will see some very good performances and excellent writing. Overall I recommend, but there are several scenes, one in particular, that are not for the squeamish or feint of heart.

A mixed bag, with some great stuff and some exasperating stuff. I loved the naturalist aesthetic, the mix of banality and terror. The filmmakers achieved a good lived-in feel to the story, with lives and relationships in progress. The lead actors all do a solid job, even if there are hints os stereotypes around them. I think Chicory is a fantastic character with more depth than any of the others. But the foes all being Indian (even if an aberration), Mexican, and hardscrabble Euro-Americans was annoying, even though they tried to insert some dialogue to ameliorate it. This contributed to the plot feeling tiresome and predictable. The music was terrific, understated but resonant with the visuals. But there are no surprises as the movie converges on its endpoint. Well-filmed as it is, it lacks a memorable emotional effect on the viewer.

Sadly, this movie never made it to the big screen. It could have been an Oscar contender. Kurt Russell and Richard Jenkins both deserve nods for their outstanding portrayals of a sheriff and his back up deputy on the hunt for a mans kidnapped wife in the early west.

It gets mighty dark at the end, but the build up is a slow and meaningful burn between four travelers on the hunt for some pretty tribal and quite disturbing natives. This isn't your fathers western. But it isn't so far off from the reality of what kind of vicious events may have taken place during the early days of the American West.

Highly recommended for anyone that loves a good story where the characters really drive the story.

A low budget, high-concept Horror Western that never quite takes off.  The cast makes the most of the material, but overall it feels a little "forced". In general, I felt the film was a collection of missed opportunities; An interesting premise let down by a lackluster set of reveals and a predictable ending, an incomplete horror mythology that could have been deepened and given symbolic weight, a two-dimensional hero with no ghosts or weaknesses to overcome, and no compelling motivation or desire line.  I might have given this two stars, but I am awarding one for originality and effort...and the chance to see Kurt Russell in a Western again.  In my opinion,  a similar and much better take on the "low budget, high-concept Horror Western" is the film, "The Burrowers" featuring a strong cast of character actors - Clancy Brown, David Busse, Doug Hutchison (everyone's favorite A-hole from "The Green Mile") and Tom Cruise's cousin William Mapother.  It has some genuinely horrific moments, snappier dialogue, and a more satisfying, ironic ending - and it even manages to be a little more fun.

The deserts of the American Southwest were, and still are, very scary and dangerous places, even more so when two bumbling idiots named Purvis (David Arquette) and Buddy (Sid Haig) stumble their way upon the hunting grounds and the sacred stone circle of something not quite human living out there. Eleven days later, Purvis arrives in the small town of Bright Hope and is confronted by Sheriff Hunt (Kurt Russell) after Purvis is seen burying luggage out in the desert by Assistant Deputy Chicory (Richard Jenkins). Purvis is shot trying to escape. While he is being treated for the wound late that night in the jail cell by Samantha ODwyer (Lili Simmons), whatever attacked him and Buddy kidnaps Samantha, Purvis and, Deputy Nick (Evan Jonigkeit) as well as stealing six horses from a nearby stable and killing and gutting the stable boy.

Samanthas husband, Arthur (Patrick Wilson), is suffering from a broken leg but insists on joining the search and rescue for his wife. Sheriff Hunt, Chicory, Gentleman John Broody (Matthew Fox), and Arthur ODwyer head out. The remainder of the film is devoted to tracking down the beings which we are told are a tribe of troglodytes by a local Native man. Hes willing to show them on a map where they can find the cave of these creatures, but hes unwilling to go with the posse to rescue anyone.

Oh, the potential! I really enjoy a good western and its no secret Im a huge fan of the horror genre, but this. Ugh. This was not a good western nor was its potential to be an amazing horror film at all met. The scene with the Mayor and his wife was farcical and irrelevant. Way too much time was spent dwelling on the very, very dull trek to the cave itself. Zahn McClarnons role as Native known as The Professor could have been so much more interesting, instead it was brief and brushed aside, used as a mere information dump instead of actually having any depth and meaning to it. It could have been used to heighten the suspense, to give us an idea what sort of evil madness our intrepid team was walking into. Instead, no, were merely told they will be facing dangerous, inbred cave dwellers.

When we finally get to meet our gruesome enemy, they just wander about their caves, call to each other in what appears to be some sort of paranormal howling-scream, go out and kill or capture for their own heinous reasons whoever happens to come along, and to steal horses. We never do find out what happens to all the horses they are taking. There is one particularly nasty scene in the cave in which Deputy Nick meets his demise which is not for the squeamish.

Even with its simplistic plot, this film could have been done better, A LOT better. It wasn't dark enough (in a psychological way), it dragged on needlessly, too many questions were left unanswered, and the character roles were shallow and uninteresting.

1 out of 5 stars for Deputy Nicks shocking death scene!

I saw this film without an idea what it was about . As the film starts out like many other Westerns a kidnaping by Indians . What caught my eye right off was the budget . The Cast must of worked for Union Scale , because most of the extras are used in a couple of scenes an then disappear . Also the dialogue too seem made up as it went along mainly by Jenkins who steals the film as the Deputy and  Kurt Russell plays the Sherriff  . This film could had been edited  down some but still keeps you watching . As they get closer to this cannibal tribe , they run into a few skirmishes  with Thieves . This isn't a bad Western  but it does get a bit gory . If anyone out there ever ate steamed crabs and opened one , then the sound when you open a shell is a sound you hear in that cave when a other Deputy meets his end . This film also stars Matthew Fox from Lost as a Indian Killer. If your a fan of Westerns from the 50's , You won't like it but if you can handle some gore and violence you will like it .This is a low budget sleeper. Kurt had grown this beard for the film that He kept it for the Hateful Eight .

Reminded me of Michael Crichton's Eaters of the Dead (The 13th Warrior) with a Western twist & horrific gore. Kurt Russell is a small town sheriff who, together with Patrick Wilson, Matthew Fox & Richard Jenkins, sets out to rescue two town residents who have been kidnapped. Unfortunately, Native Americans are depicted as a cult of bizarre cannibals who have mutilated their bodies and who go so far as to blind and amputate all limbs from females who are pregnant. This combined with the unspeakable acts perpetrated upon their human prey while still alive makes for an extremely disturbing & graphic movie. I've watched the Saw series and The Ring but this movie is worse, so be prepared.

On a lighter note, the movie has an atmosphere of semi-Monty Pythonishness where politeness & social niceties are maintained regardless of circumstance, so the odd bits of levity add a quirky nuance. Stellar performances by the movie's great cast, particularly Matthew Fox, adds to the temptation to continue watching it despite its grim and nauseating scenes. I cannot imagine how the producers were able to lure the cast to make this movie except perhaps if they left out that horrific slaughtering scene so the actors were unaware just how repulsive the movie would actually turn out.

Awesome western/horror hybrid with one incredibly horrific scene that almost had me blow chunks. Decent find, definitely worth an hour of my time whilst eating my porridge. Besides...it's got Kurt Russell..and who doesn't love Snake Plissken? AMIRIGHT!?

The movie overall is pretty dark and yet has a humorous co-star played by Richard Jenkins which keeps you wondering, should I let my guard down because a joke was made or is something bad about to happen? I really liked it if for nothing else than the original feel it had to it and the acting was pretty good as well which made it a smooth watch. I recommend this to anyone who is a fan of Kurt Russel's action movies or dark, slower movies. It is quite gory so be warned.

One of the best western movies ever made.  It was refreshing to see the accuracy of polite language and respect that was part of 19th century western society.  The violence is shocking, very shockingly realistic, so it is not for the faint hearted.  One unnecessary bedroom scene makes it not suitable for kids, unless you send them out of the room that one scene.  The refined manners and respect is what sticks out most in this western, even more so than the extreme violence.

This will be a cult film, no question about it.  Beautifully non-Hollywood, it's a film which took me by complete surprise.  Wonderfully written with some of the most fantastic dialogue I've seen in a film in decades (owing in no small part I'd imagine to the director being the author).  An Old West yarn turned thriller/horror with a small bit of black humor.  Refreshingly absent of the cliche film techniques and methods, it's a wonderful breath of fresh air.  Slightly absurdist but easily enjoyable.  If you're looking for an action-junkie modern film, this may not be the one for you.

Special note: Richard Jenkins puts on an absolute clinic with his portrayal of Chicory, the lovingly obtuse aging "back up Deputy".  This is a film which makes no concessions to standard film methods/pacing and does not modernize its language or characters to suit modern audiences.  This is its strength.  Be forewarned, this film does contain brutal unforgiving scenes with no warning to the viewer (another splendid surprise).
A good Western with interesting characters.  An underrated line up of talent with a solid story line.

Maybe I missed the point of this movie; everyone acts well, it is beautifully shot, but it feels almost like a horror-movie (soft) than a Western. As usual, the brown man is horrible; inbred, dirty and he eats people. Their women are eyeless breeding machines lying with extended bellies in the dirt. And the white man, as he should for the narrative,  sacrifices himself to save the maiden. Left this with a bad taste in my mouth. You may not see it like this; I'm a (over) sensitive far-leftie who sees racism, sexism and other bad things everywhere, so if you're a tough guy with lots of hair on your chest, disregard my review. Two stars for the acting, no star for the theme.

I consider this an art house film.  It is written, acted and produced beautifully.  Loved the nuances of the sound editing, notice the sound of the shod horses as they go over the wooden bridge. If you enjoy a good western story this is it with an unusual twist.

No two ways about it -- this is a western/horror hybrid, and it's disingenuous of Amazon not to give it the Horror tag. If you LIKE the idea of an unflinching western/horror hybrid, read no further and dive right in. Seriously, go enjoy what's about to unfold and don't let the following spoil anything for you.

If you're unsure, know this: you need to enjoy both genres or you're going to be uncomfortable. It's not "western with a dose of human flesh nibbling for gritty realism," or "jumpscare-n-redsyrup horror in period costume."

The first half is all modern Real West western -- leisurely unfolding of routine events, each character with a different kind of hat as the first signal that they're all interesting characters, time on the trail to create friction, challenges to create bonds, and a deep cast of professionals making the pace worthwhile. The second half is unflinching torture/body horror. Chekov's Gun is right there in the title. Amazon's tags may not have warned you, but this and other reviews have.

This is a superb movie in that it shows how ridiculous the falsely held notion that the white people were the plundering, pillaging murderers that killed off so many "peaceful" Indian Tribes. I am 1/4 Cheokee and have always found that a  one sided view. The Cherokees got along with most of the new people to the Americas and their bloodline is the largest running through the veins of present day Americans out of the five tribe nation. Many tribes were extremely savage, and indeed would torture, kill and sometimes eat other tribes. When people headed West which was more so after The Civil War , they were looking to avoid Indians , as much as possible. America had already been a country for nearly 100 years. Okay, long story short, some of The tribes were insanely brutal and would kill as many settlers as possible. This movie brings this long arduous journey to save the captives , to our viewpoint where we could feel like we were along for the journey. A very scary journey when they finally meet these human creatures! I saw an interview a few weeks ago with a Leftist television station where the commentator was visibly upset about the violence in the film . Kurt Rusell said that the movie depicted a reality and that is one job and beauty of the world of cinema. The commentator also mentioned that there was some controversy surrounding the film. After viewing this today,  I see what The Liberals were spinning their heads around over in the depiction of the natives in this film. Oh my!!! So, not all of the Indigenous people were not all sitting around in a circle smoking peace pipes, having rain dances, hunting , gathering and minding their own business, as The Liberals desperately want to have us believe. The two pregnant women lying down blinded with huge stones in their eyes told the story of how these people felt about the women. The women were merely breeding machines, most likely to be roasted over the flames themselves after menopause. In 2016 , we need to see all the sides to a story more than ever when people of Caucasian backgrounds are constantly being portrayed in Universities and The Media as the evildoers!

The movie starts with a couple of bad guys killing and robbing people and then during their escape they stumble across a group of cave dwellers in a remote area.  Later one of them ends up in a small town jail and along with a deputy and a woman are taken by the cave dwellers.  The town sheriff, a deputy, the woman's husband and another man set out to rescue them and that's the story.  The local Native Americans know about the cave dwellers but won't go near their lands because they are a vicious  group that kills and eats anybody that trespasses on their land.  There is a little sex, frontal nudity, and graphic violent scene.  The acting is excellent by everybody.  I wouldn't have known Kurt Russell was the sheriff because he was unrecognizable.

People keep giving this film a bad review because its not what they expected from Kurt Russel, these people must not understand this this movie is a genre blend of horror and western  that was made on a shoestring budget with no studio interference. So no, Russel didn't do this movie because he needed the money, he did it because he was a fan of the novels that the direct/writer of this film had written in the past, and was a fan of this script. So get over your expectations and rate the film on what it is, a well acted, well made indie film with great cast and great characters. And not because you thought it was gonna be something other than what it was.

I enjoyed the movie very much.  There were some areas of the film that were too predictable but they were balanced with a few surprises.  Make no mistake about it, this is a horror film and if that is not your genre then you will not be happy with this film.  I will say it is a horror film in the since that there were a couple of scenes that were very over the top and gut wrenching (not for the meek), but thats how horror films go these day.  The suspense was OK but definitely not a suspense driven film but enough to hold your attention.  The film is several steps above your typical slasher film containing more film value than just scene followed by scene of more and more horrible events.  There is a decent story going on which elevates it above the average slasher film.  Some other reviews seemed to attack the films believability, but I don't think you should be looking for a believable story line in a horror movie.  I found the movie stimulated the adrenaline since and kept me interested, exactly what horror movies are supposed to do.  If you are a fan of horror with a story line then you may find this entertaining but if you want a John Wayne western, by-pass it
