This is the best horror-western I've seen since Deadbirds. It's a well-written, finely-acted slow burn story with witty dialogue, great characters, and a third act attack full of gruesome gore, genuinely frightening moments, and glorious fight scenes. Film critic Scott Weinberg's assessment that it's "The Searchers meets the Hills Have Eyes" is pretty dead on. There's just enough originality in the writing department to make this beast it's own brand. S. Craig Zahler is immensely talented and I can't wait to see what he cooks up next. I won't give anything away here, but the bad guys are seriously terrifying. The dusty mountain scape scenery is beautifully evocative of every good western you've seen. Kurt Russell is a laid back badass. Patrick Wilson brings so much life to his stubborn, hopelessly devoted husband on a mission - he's hobblin' and limpin' around most of the movie but it's great. Last but not least, Richard Jenkins is a total riot as our senior citizen assistant deputy "Chicory". He's got some of the flick's funniest lines, and his performance is, at times, comic gold. Anyone who'd just write off Bone Tomahawk as "dull" or "slow" or "tedious" must have had some crazy expectations of what the film should deliver. Go into it expecting a well-told Western slow burn with one helluva mean third act, held together by some great cast and great gore and you'll be entertained. I'm going to add this to my collection ASAP - it's definitely a repeater. Oh, and as with most slow burn horror, watch this alone. In the dark. And late at night for maximum fear effect.

I love Kurt Russel as an actor. This is why I picked this movie. The movie it self is slow moving in plot. It was hard to follow in some scenes. There was no explanation on who the Indians were or where they came from or why. You are not missing anything by not watching this movie.

At first I thought it would be another "Indians steal the girl, and fearless lawman and his posse retrieves the girl and saves the day" kind of movie. Believe me, it wasn't that at all. These Indians were something straight from hell, and you have never seen anything like these guys before. All in all this movie leaves you with your jaw slacked and wondering, what the heck just happened?

Bone Tomahawk is a powerful experience, and I can't really say that I regret watching it but it is not one of the movies that I will go back to again and again.

The plot is as simple as they come -- rescue the hostages -- but, as with movies like Jaws or The Edge, the thing that captivates is the interaction between the characters, all of whom seem surprisingly three-dimensional.  The dialogue is stilted to modern ears, but well represents 19th century verbal cadences.  The savages are savage indeed, and one scene was very difficult to watch.  I don't know enough about the frontier to know if any groups like this actually existed in America, and something in me is uncomfortable with the portrayal of any indigenous people groups as so sub-human.  Nevertheless, wow, what a horrifying clan, almost on a par with the Predator.

This had to be the worst movie of all times. I wish there was negative stars that I could give this. It has the most absurd plot, the most insipid dialogue, the most implausible portrayal of the times. It could only appeal to those who like gratuitous sex scenes coupled with violence and gore for the sake of violence and gore. I feel sorry for Mr. Russell who must be lacking in offerings to not only  have read the script , but to actually take the role. The directing is done by a wanna-be Quentin Tarantino who does a dreadful imitation of his genre. The most unbelievable aspect of this "film" outside of the tribe of cave dwellers who are listed as cannibals/Indians who no one seems to know their location or much about them, and are found to be accessible by a long lowered rope is that one character has a broken ankle at the start of the movie, proceeds with the posse to save his kidnapped wife from the aforementioned savages; has his horse stolen, and then proceeds to walk all the distance over rugged territory and somewhat keeps up with the rest of the posse with this broken ankle. One scene shows the other posse members resetting the bone after he fell, much to the man's agony, yet he carries on to eventually rescue the survivors. How he managed to do all this defies any plausibility that I can conceive. If they showed  this "film" at Guantanamo Bay to the prisoners, the Red Cross would have us up for cruel and inhuman treatment. This should have been Rated "B" Bad!!

I would've liked for there to have been more explanation about the Troglodyte's origins, given the length of the movie, but I really liked it overall.

Dont quite have the energy for a lengthy review at this point, but ill try to give the cliff-notes version:

1. While Kurt Russel and the older guy helped give the movie a 'western" feel, others- like the guy from lost and the crippled husband- were really too well-known to be able to take seriously in the roles. Theyd have been better off casting some talented no-name actors if they wanted it to be a more impactful performance. The entire movie I just kept thinking "Yup....thats Matthew Fox in a moustache. Sure is. Is that David Arquette with blackened teeth? Yes...that is indeed David Arquette with blackened teeth."

2. The pacing is kind of weird. Especially towards the end and the last scene. When the screen went black, I actually said "Theres no way thats the end...". A scene of a rock in mud? I don't expect to see the happy couple back at home and everything tied neatly in a bow, but something more substantial than a rock in mud wouldve seemed like a given to me if I were in charge of this film.

3. While some of the effects were especially good (like the....*ahem*...."barbecue" scene in the last 1/4 of the movie- some of the other effects were just laughably bad. Im not sure if that was by design- to pay homage to the campy B-movies of yesteryear. It just seemed super out of place and rather jarring when some of the practical effects were so solid, and the others were so obviously poorly done.

One of the reviewers mentioned it having sort of a "The Hills Have Eyes" horr type vibe. I could sort of agree with that. But The Hills Have Eyes had kind of a consistent tone all the way through. This movie seemed stuck between wanting to be a gritty, authentic-type westen (like my beloved Lonesome Dove), and a horror flick- doing neither particularly well. Now Im not a snooty film critic by any means, but I still got the distinct feeling that this movie missed the mark in many ways. I don't know where all those 5-star ratings are coming from. Even 4 is probably generous. 3.5 is more like it.

So- its certainly worth watching if youve got a couple of hours to kill. But having just finished the movie, I find myself wishing id have chanced upon ANYTHING more gratifying than the 2 hours I just sat through.

Huge fan of Kurt Russell. That is why I kept looking for the film when it was released. For some reason, it had a very limited theatre release, which I've no idea why. I had to wait until it came to in-demand on cable to see it.
A lot of people, apparently, have stated how "gross" or "put-off" they were by a few scenes, which, I fully admit, were pretty graphic. However, in my opinion, these scenes added to the brutality of the unforeseen situation in which the main characters (as well as the audience) found themselves. After all, we're dealing with savage cannibals here; there are no napkins, cups of tea, or any kind of table manners involved. In other words, the savagery was expected.
I thought the story was a little different and original. It isn't every day (or year) you come across what appears to be a traditional western and end up with creepy cannibals in a cave.
Highly recommended for people who like something different and don't mind a couple of graphic scenes. Also highly recommended for anyone who is a Kurt Russell fan.

Although the plot of this movie is certainly not very original (basic kidnap and rescue, with some creepy adders and significantly more blood and gore), the acting is excellent by the entire cast, particularly by Kurt Russell. A lot of his roles in his younger days were types (see Escape from New York (ca. 1980)  ("Snake Plissken!! I thought you were dead!")). Now, he has settled into a more mature and thoughtful mode of acting, which adds a lot more depth to his characterizations. In other words, you can more readily identify with, sympathize with, and even like his character. Maybe Snake Plissken is really dead after all, which would be good news for Kurt Russell.

But while the plot is not new, this and other modern westerns have abandoned the stock good guy/bad guy dichotomy that was central to the genre from the 1950s onward. The old westerns portrayed a "West" that was essentially a kind of post-war suburbia set back in time by 80 or so years and without all the new kitchen appliances. Bone Tomahawk is very much in the current western genre, one that depicts the Wild West in a way that is much more gritty and realistic.

This film would really stand out if the plot had some unexpected twists and turns, but it doesn't include those. Still, the acting makes it much more than the ordinary run of the mill western. All in all, an enjoyable, if somewhat gory, western.

For an example of cheap-o low-value production values:  Kurt Russell's character is seen in his house interacting with his wife.  Clearly visible in every shot of this home is a wood-burning cook stove.  Sitting atop this stove is a CHAMBER POT!!!  That's right!  In ever shot of Russell's character's house, we get to ponder over why this couple keep their urinal on top of their stove.

This is a glaring example of cheap, inattentive production values and is an example of so many things wrong with this sad little movie.

Man, I wanted to like this film. It had a lot of the fantastic characterizations and languid pace of "True Grit," the best of the Western genre, IMHO. And I've been a fan of Kurt Russell since the "Escape from..." movies.
But this, this is something else.
No spoilers here, I promise, but at the 3/4's point in the film the "horror" kicks in and there is a scene of torture, mutilation and murder (of an innocent) that will likely never leave my mind. It is so believably filmed with special effects and a stunning performance by the young actor, that it became traumatic and unforgettable... but in a way that I truly wish I could forget.
If torture-porn of the innocent is your thing, this is your thing. If you think you're going to see a good, stylized movie Western, you're not.

Having read no reviews I watched this as I am a fan of Western movies and I like Kurt Russell. I had no idea what to expect. It wasn't a great Western movie, but it was a decent horror movie in an era of really terrible horror movies. The grittiness of the characters was difficult to believe, not because people who lived in the old west weren't tough, but because people outside of special forces aren't generally tough enough to persevere when the odds are increasingly stacked against them.

SPOILER_ Stop Reading here if you haven't watched it.

I find the hardest part to believe is the fact that a beautiful woman was abducted by savages for several days and was unscathed at the end. They were savage enough to maim their breeders (which by the way the main characters left to die slowly by starvation, who's the savage now?), but left this captive woman intact and untouched? It would have been more believable if she hadn't survived or had been at least severely injured, leaving the husband in a rage to finish off the clan. Another note, 3 healthy men couldn't make it to the cave without being killed or injured, yet a crippled man could, even though one savage had him 'dead to rights' while he was sleeping and missed him with an arrow from 10 ft. away. That had to be the worst action sequence scene of the entire movie. At least wing him to make it more believable. This movie was good enough in spite of itself, but there was a lot of potential that was left to be desired.

I really liked this film, but it's not for everyone.  The plot is pretty similar to the John Ford classic "The Searchers": basically the town sheriff and his deputy set off to rescue an abducted woman from a savage band of native-American "troglodyte" cannibals.  Her wounded husband and the town douchebag insist on coming along and together they ride into the harsh desert on their mission.

This is more of a dialogue-driven slow burn western rather than an action-adventure film and it gets off to a somewhat slow start, before getting to its dark and very gory conclusion.  It is not for everyone.  Be warned that there is a scene about 3/4s of the way through that is one of the most savagely violent and hard to watch scenes put on film in the last year or so (I will only say that the weapon in the title does come in to play and that those natives are not vegetarians.)  That part is impossible to unwatch once you've seen it, but fortunately, I have the stomach for that sort of thing and feel like it was well-executed and not simply gratuitous like an Eli Roth or Tarantino film.

The strength of the film comes from the well-written dialogue and some performances from Kurt Russell, Richard Jenkins and Patrick Wilson.  When  the violence comes in the movie, as in life, it is swift and brutal and it felt like a pretty authentic portrayal of a very savage time and place.

Probably (no, definitely) not the best choice for a date night movie, but a great choice for a guys' night for fans of old-school westerns and horror.

If you ever wondered what a movie collaboration between Quentin Tarantino and Eli Roth would look like, you now have the answer. Novelist turned writer/director S. Craig Zahler pays homage to both Tarantino and Roth with his horror Western "Bone Tomahawk," a movie that mixes Tarantino-esque dialogue (much of it uttered by one of Tarantino's favorite actors, Kurt Russell) and Rothian forays into cannibalism.

The plot has elements of John Ford's "The Searchers" and a little-known Gregory Peck Western, "The Stalking Moon." A couple of small time outlaws disturb a Native American burial ground. and the natives take exception, eventually pursuing the survivor to a small town where he gets medical attention from the town's female doctor (Lili Simmons). During the night, she and a couple of other townspeople are kidnapped by the natives and taken back to their lair. The town sheriff (Russell) puts together a small rescue posse consisting of the doctor's husband (Patrick Wilson), who is recovering from a broken leg, a dandy (Matthew Fox) whose marksmanship skills and combat savvy are exceeded only by his dislike of non-whites, and Russell's geezer deputy (Richard Jenkins).  The posse has been warned by a local expert that their quarry are a group of flesh eating, cave dwelling, inbred freaks warmly referred to as Troglodytes, so the posse members already have a good idea what to expect.

"Bone Tomahawk," like Tarantino movies, is deliberately paced and spends a bit too much time before the action really starts. But Zalher has a way with dialogue and takes his time sketching in the four main characters, who are often going after each other based on their differing ideas about morals and tactics. It becomes obvious fairly early in the movie that the "code of the West" doesn't apply here; the characters make cold, hard, practical and sometimes cruel decisions. These hardnosed decisions and actions come across in stark contrast to the often languidly paced, entertaining dialogue of "Bone Tomahawk," but that dialogue is so well done that Zahler draws the audience in listening to Russell (who's a natural at this) and Fox (who's surprisingly good as well).

Eventually, the posse does run across their quarry, and the Troglodytes will not disappoint horror audiences. They are quite tall and cover themselves in white paint so that they blend in with the sand of the desert, allowing them to sneak up on their targets. Unlike some authors turned directors, Zahler proves himself rather adept at directing action scenes. The fights and shootouts are well staged and fairly exciting. But my use of the word "freaks" to describe the Troglodytes wasn't hyperbole. When Zahlers finally shows them and their prisoners, he doesn't hold back. The last half hour of "Bone Tomahawk" contains some extremely grisly and gory footage (the movie is unrated for good reason). When I saw it, my reaction was incredulity... that Zahlers couldn't possibly be going to show what was going to happen next, but he did, and it was even more graphic than I thought it would be.

Obviously, "Bone Tomahawk" is not a movie for general audiences (it got an extremely minimal theatrical release before going to VOD). But it's a quality production with a good script and an excellent cast of character actors (you won't see a cast like this in an Eli Roth film). Ironically, the very subject matter and style that made "Bone Tomahawk" box office poison ensures its long-term cult status. For those who aren't appalled by the subject matter, it's a Western worth watching.

This movie reminded me quite a bit of Gallowwalkers with Wesley Snipes, which was my introduction to western horror.  Bone Tomahawk is a dark slow-building movie until the last half hour, then it quickens its pace a bit and becomes quite gory.  I had to peek through my fingers at a couple of the more...hmm...graphic places.  It's not a movie you can do something else and just listen to, the actors are all superb and much of the story is told with body language and facial expression, and you don't want to miss the grisly scenes at the end, even if you have to peek your way through them. It is tense all the way through and ends on one of those quixotic notes that short stories turned movie loves to end on.
I enjoyed the dialogue that was formal and witty.  The acting is superb, everyone showed up and played their parts well.  But most of all I enjoyed the exploration of sub-themes, blatant racism, the harshness of wild west life, the earnestness of being true to self. and the isolation of subcultures within geographical isolation.  I will watch it again.

Better than I expected given the cover and description. The most unlikely people band together to rescue a kidnapped woman. The kidnappers are the remaining cave dwelling cannibals thought to be extinct. They impose horrors beyond one's imagination, The ultimate hero, of all the heros, is the least expected, How a few men who don't like each other manage to become a team determined to hunt down kidnappers knowing this is certainly an impossible persuit. As the rescue journey rushes forward the men become comrades dedicated to their mission and each other to the end. The ending is unexpected and a relief after this brutal roller coaster to rescue a woman. WARNING - graphic violence, brutality and nudity

I don't write a lot of reviews about movies but I felt I had to chime in on this one. It was fantastic! If you like realistic feeling westerns, along with horror that will make you cover your eyes then this is the movie for you.

You should also be able to appreciate character development because most of the movie is about the characters. Kurt Russell was obviously the biggest name here but I wouldn't say he was the main character. All the actors felt like main characters and I left feeling like I knew each one of them really well. Most movies have one or two characters that you get to know and the rest are simply there to let the main ones shine. This is not the case here. Excellent performances all around and I think everyone involved should feel proud of what they accomplished.

True Grit (2010) meets The Hills Have Eyes (2006). This would have easily been a five star for me, but I did find quite a few scenes lingering too long on a plot that was never really the focal point of the film. Otherwise, there is a great dark western feel to the film with a nice dose of horror mixed into the last third. There are better films with more action, better effects, and less cliche characters, but I've seen many, many worse films with far larger budgets and promotions.

If this is included with any streaming service you have, you need to watch it. If you see it somewhere for less than $10, you can even add it to your collection.

A Western with a fair measure of horror--the third act is downright harrowing--BONE TOMAHAWK is beautifully shot and boasts stellar performances. (The entire cast delivers, but extra praise must be directed at Richard Jenkins in particular, who shines in what may well be the greatest role of his career.) Strangely enough, the film also has a superb sense of humor and a genuine warmth about it: Even in its darkest moments, when the characters are at odds with their world and with each other, you can sense them reaching for understanding of one another. There's respect amid the conflict, which serves to brilliant separate our heroes from the seemingly unfeeling, barely-human monsters they face.

BONE TOMAHAWK is not for everyone. The squeamish had best steer clear. However, it is an entertaining and unusually thoughtful film, and those with the stomach for its lows will be delighted by its highs.

We've been watching Kurt Russell since we were children and knowing "The Hateful 8" was recently released, we decided this was a great choice for a snowed in weekend. Several reviews indicated it was more of a slasher movie, but we decided to watch what we could. I am so glad we did. There is really only one gruesome scene and it is nothing I would compare to slasher films. It is a Western and it does have Indians and "Cowboys". There are only a handful of star actors but they each shined! This is not your average Western and the language is much cleaner than most films these days. We loved it and are happy we gave it a chance. It is long, 2 hrs 12 mins, but we were never bored. Highly recommend.

This movie felt like you were put in a time machine and taken back to a bygone era, it is dripping with authenticity.  The dialogue was nothing short of superb from start to finish.  It's a truly terrifying film though, definitely not for the faint of heart.  I get that when you are dealing with savages, there will be a certain amount of gore involved.  But boy, I could have done without some of the graphic scenes toward the tail end of the film.  I'm just not convinced that such graphic imagery was necessary to convey the savage nature of the films antagonists or to convey the sense of horror and dread felt by the heroes of the story.  That's the only reason I took away a star in my review.

Bone Tomahawk (2015) is a rather weird movie in that it combines two genres - the western genre and the horror genre.  The main thing, though, is that's it's an original movie and not a remake of some movie.  Kurt Russell gives a good performance as the sheriff.  This movie slows down a bit in the middle, but it never gets boring and it holds my attention.  The acting throughout is good by all involved and the musical score does the job well.

If you like westerns and don't mind some gore and the overall horror element, then see this movie.  Recommended.

If you were attracted enough by the offbeat premise to start watching this film, knowing not to expect a standard Western and willing to accept its unconventional theme going in, I don't see how anyone could not admire this film as it played fair throughout on that basis, and delivered as a fully engrossing well crafted story that sucked you into its world as inexorably as a super gravitational cosmic vortex.

Consider as a comparison the far more highly contrived truly mixed genre "Cowboys and Aliens" and compare it to this considerably more successful effort only mildly in that vein, that really doesn't mix genres at all actually, nor certainly to such an implausible extent as to be almost laughably impossible to produce the required suspension of our disbelief required to take it seriously as that film was.  There are no inter galactic space creatures here, no supernatural beings, no spawned by H-bomb radiation produced mutant monsters or slack jawed shambling zombies here, but perfectly believable savage adversaries in a tribe of backward cannibalistic inbred brutish primitives whose existence and horrific behavior is not only believable in a real world, but has well documented non fiction precedent.  Kurt Russell is at his stalwart heroic best here, and the supporting cast is nothing less than superb.  My only criticism here is perhaps the dumb song played over the closing credits, which I only mention for want of any other flaw to pick on, which of course was no big deal anyway and only mildly irritating given the exceptional quality of the whole.

I'm not one to post reviews, but the negative reviews go me riled up. First, this film is straight up Kurt Russell's alley - he does a fantastic job in the role, and the other main characters balance it out perfectly. There is no doubt that there is some gory scenes, but the mere fact that it opens with two westerners calling natives "savages" after cutting the throats of sleeping travelers and stealing their belongings, says exactly what this film is getting at -- the savagery that human animals can possess. Who is the savage in this story? Who deserves to live and tell the tale? Is there redemption? It is a stark reminder of what humans are capable of, even if it's a fictional mystic tribe of "troglodytes" its not to far fetched from the horrors we see committed today across the world.

I'm not a fan of horror movies, generally, but this didn't feel like a stereotypical horror movie. The quaint, interesting dialogue gave the story a feeling of authenticity, and it helped build more or less three-dimensional characters. Events near the beginning of the story set the stage for a dreadful, disturbing final act, where the real horror was on display. For my taste, the "road-trip" (middle) part of story dragged on a bit too much; otherwise I would have rated the movie 3.5 stars. There came a point during the second act where I was thinking, okay, when are we going to get to the climax. I'll probably never watch it again, but I don't regret watching it. Oh yeah, right now I can't think of a good alternate title, but to me, "Bone Tomahawk" is a stupid title.

This is the strangest western I've seen, a sort of horror movie version of THE SEARCHERS with a much shorter but very intense search.  Good action when there is action,  good plot when there is plot, but it also contains long, drawn-out sequences of O'Dwyer and wife at home, of O'Dwyer's leg injury, of O'Dwyer gamely carrying on despite his injury, etc.  I estimate that at least 15 minutes of the 2 hour, 12 minute movie is just wasted film.  The dialog is interesting, particularly the odd statements and observations by my favorite character, Chicory, the old, official reserve deputy.  Thinking of Chicory, I am increasing my review from 3 stars to 4 just for Richard Jenkins' performance as Chicory, an elderly, slightly befuddled but brave and effective man.

The movie is also interesting in that everyone is not carrying the Colt Peacemaker which is standard in most westerns.  I identified the sheriff's revolver as a Smith & Wesson top-break, probably a .44-40 or .44 Russian rather than a .45 Schofield.  Even more unusual and rare is O'Dwyer's Merwin Hulbert.  I have been unable to positively identify the revolver with the lanyard ring used by the outlaw Buddy at the beginning of the movie.

Yes, there were cannibals in the American Southwest.  Probably not as late in the 19th century as depicted in this movie, but the movie has a sort of lost world, lost tribe aspect to it which explains that.  For those who have, in their reviews, expressed shock and outrage that this is a horror movie, I will just point out that the description on Amazon begins, "When a group of cannibal savages...."  I should think that would be enough warning to let most people know that this isn't Tombstone 2.

A loose plot revolving around cave Indian canables upset that two murdering thieves walked across their sacred burial ground, one is killed the other escapes.  So the mystical Indians seek out  the survivor hiding in a small peaceful town, and for some reason take a lady Doctor, the thief, and the deputy back to the caves for future dinners.  But, not before killing the black stable boy as apparently these pale white Indians don't like eating black people.  So Kurt Russle forms a posse to save the captives from being thanksgiving dinner. The supporting cast was under budget and did not depict what I would expect to see within an old west posse:  the doctors husband with a broken leg, a more mature man dumb as a box of rocks, and a playboy quick trigger with a thing for killing Indians.  Too many long and drawn out scenes, filled with silly and senseless dialog, attempting to give these yahoos a sense of purpose and character.  Like a good country song, the wife is gone, a dog is shot, their horses are stolen, and the husband with a broken leg entertains us with what felt like 30 minutes of his agonizing hobble through the plains / desert on a crutch.  If you can fast forward to the last half hour, you have a low budget action film that falls short on action.  At least you get to see one of these savages split one of the prisoners in half, it's guts fall out, in preparation for a meal.  Save 2 hours of your life and get some sleep instead.

Wow, this is  a real movie! The other stuff lately just seems like overly flashy scenes from a dozen episodes all condensed into a 2 hour sitdown. But THIS is a real movie. The pace is perfect. You are relaxed, and the tension builds and just sticks with you. I am still thinking about this movie, and I saw it two days ago.
If you are a person that reads, you understand investment.
The gore everyone is talking about is well done. It's not Rob Zombie ridiculous. This is just tough as hell to comprehend, but, you weren't there during the Western Expansion, and you live in a charmin world, so, use your imagination and get over it.
Riding horses is always made so damn pretty and glamorous, but, in this movie, you get  a sense that they were not pretty animals when they were workers for the working man. You loved it, but, family comes first, so there is a "minivan horse" in here. I loved that!
And, while the cinematography is splendid, it's not there to make you feel like you're in a NatGeo episode. It's there so you get to add even more tension, because there is no way you could tell where you're going there. It's all open. It's so defenseless. It's just you, sitting there, with the characters, waiting for something either good or terrible to happen.

Kurt Russell -- REALLY? WHY? I will forever wish I had not seen this film. I love Westerns for the cowboy atmosphere, historical depiction, the scenery, horses, etc. This one has that, but the horror and brutality is beyond comprehension. The savages torture and kill one of the cowboys in an unspeakable manner (I can't even say it) in front of the others, inferring that they are next. They keep their women in line by amputating their limbs and driving pegs through their eyes (and leaving them there). At one point the imprisoned woman doctor's husband kills one of the troglodytes and, in order to trick the others into coming to him so he can shoot them, he removes the throat whistle or whatever the hell it is from the dead guy's throat (by hand). This seemingly goes on forever with lots of effort and gristle-crunching sounds. Then he puts it in his mouth (blood and all) and blows a shrill, cheesy sound that reminds me of a crackerjack whistle, which, of course, draws the other 2 troglodytes to him as planned. A few minutes later (the end of the film), he goes to kiss his wife, realizes the guy's blood is still all over his mouth, wipes it with his sleeve and kisses her - a happy ending!

Prime instant video rating showed a five star and Rotten Tomatoes had an 88% rating so my expectations were probably set way too high. This is a terrible story but I'll get to that. There is a lot of praise for some aspects of the movie. Casting was great; the acting was very good and I was particularly happy to see Kurt Russell play a Wyatt Earp type character again; costumes were good; and most of the cinematography was good. But all of that goodness can't cover up the smell of bull droppings that is the script. This movie isn't for kids due to graphic violence, torture, murder, and cannibalism. I wish I hadn't seen it either.

SPOILER ALERT
The starting premise of the movie is that an bumbling, illiterate outlaw with an apparent IQ of 60 desecrates a tribal burial ground and somehow manages in broad daylight, and on foot, to elude members of a small Native American tribe so terrifying that other more mainstream tribes won't go near them. The outlaw manages to make it to a town, still in reasonably good condition, despite having travelled more than five days on foot through the desert by himself with the Indians in hot pursuit. The outlaw gets shot by the local sheriff (Russell) and taken to jail. In the night the Indians attack silently, swiftly and brutally, killing the local stable hand and captures a deputy, a female doctor and the outlaw. A posse of four men is formed, the sheriff, a vengeful Indian killer, a half-witted deputy, and the doctor's husband (who has a broken leg).

I call the deputy on the posse half-witted because there is a scene where he asks the sheriff for advice because he couldn't figure out how to keep the pages of a book dry while taking a bath and another where he is delighted by the thought that a flee circus was real instead of dead flees glued to mechanical device. He is repeatedly shown as slow, inept and has to be reminded to eat but somehow we are supposed to believe he was once a military field surgeon and still capable of diagnosing complex infections and break and reset the leg bone of another posse member in the field.

Soon into their travels the four loose their horses but continue on foot. Not surprisingly the four become three when the doctor's husband can't keep up with a broken leg and he is left alone in the desert in an opium fuelled slumber for at least 12 hours and somehow nothing eats or kills him. The three then become two when one is killed and the others taken prisoner. At this point something seems to have gone wrong with the movie production quality and it seemed to me they were running out of money for sets and filming. From here on the Indians, depicted earlier as terrifyingly swift, silent and deadly, become clumsy and stupid cave dwellers who can't even fight off a noisy crippled man on a crutch (the husband). Of course he saves the day and at least three people make it out alive, the doctor, the half-wit and a man on a crutch.

There are also several scenes towards the end that are disturbing (blind pregnant Indian women with arms and legs amputated by their own tribe) and gruesome (torture, killing and cannibalism). These seem added for shock value more than any coherent thought. How for example are we to believe that a primitive tribe of cave dwellers could successfully amputate their womens arms and legs, blind them, care for them throughout their natural lives and take care of the children? None of the tribe actually speak because they have had a complex whistle surgically implanted in their windpipes, how exactly did they manage that? How exactly did this tribe survive against all the other Indian tribes if they could be defeated by a pitiful posse of four white men walking through the desert? These questions and many more will confuse you if you watch this movie.

Reading some of these reviews is like The Emperor's New Clothes. If this is an inside joke, please let us in on it.

Good acting by most of the major leads, if only the movie held up to Russell & Wilson's performances. Left to assume too much $$ was spent on putting together a nearly all star cast (did they need Sean Young?) & either corner cutting, inexperience, or both lead to the cheap sets, mediocre cinematography,  continuity errors,  & occasional sci-fi channel effects that dumb it down.

Music sets the mood, and this movie has none (save for the magnum opus @ the end credits composed & performed by the writer / director- not joking). A good soundtrack goes a long way and there were so many moments that cried out for something, anything, to build on the emotion being laid out by the cast. True, No Country for Old Men had no soundtrack, but did Zahler really think he could pull that off out of the gate?

I was really looking forward to something original & was really let down with this redux of the Burrowers. Not the worst movie I've ever seen, but the hype killed it for us. If the picture would have reveled in what it was (a b-movie) and had a little fun @ its own expense it would be alot more enjoyable. It should have taken a page from Rob Zombie, Robert Rodriguez & Quentin Tarantino instead of the Cohen Brothers or Sam Pecinpah.

I'd be really interested to hear the backstory on the making of this movie someday. Its not anywhere near as bad as The Room, but st times it has that strange vanity / pet project feel. I'm dying to know, "What were they thinking!?"

I hadn't even heard of this movie when my husband suggested it and I am really not a fan of westerns. I only agreed to this as our Friday night movie because Kurt Russell is in it. We watched it a couple of weeks ago and I still bring it up to my husband like, "What the eff did we watch?" As another reviewer has already said, it starts off like a typical western. The search party's journey might be considered slow by some viewers because there isn't a lot of action but the dialogue between the characters keeps you invested. During the climax, I was gripping the couch and my toes were curled  because I was scared, horrified, and anxious to see how the film would be resolved. This movie was surprisingly grotesque for a few minutes so don't try to watch this with your kids. I would also not recommend walking away or playing on your cell phone because you might miss the very brief explanations given for the Indians and why they've kidnapped some of the townspeople. I think the brief explanations really lends a hand to the tension in the movie.

Bone Tomahawk is not your typical western movie, however it feels more realistic in tone, pacing and dialogue than most other western movies out there.  Bone Tomahawk felt like a genuine slice of the old west in the late 19th century, and I really enjoyed this movie because of it's realistic presentation.

Some reviewers fault this movie for it's slow pace, and not having enough of a story.  Bone Tomahawk has it's own pace, more akin to the times when telegraph was the fastest form of communication a horse was still a mainstay of travel.

When the story hits it's stride, there is an urgency in the narrative but that urgency exists in the slower pace of the old west.

Also, some reviewers were taken back by some of the violence and gore in Bone Tomahawk, which it does have, but in my opinion the violence and gore is not exploitative, and that it both fits into the narrative and is quite realistic for that period in time.

The story is simple, but compelling.  Acting is solid, but it's Kurt Russel who shines here...just low key brilliant.

Bone Tomahawk does not cater to the typical viewer; who is most likely entertained by fast and loud action edited with a.d.d. in mind.  Cool people doing cool things, and saying even cooler things.

The viewer must cater to Bone Tomahawk, to slow down a little and become immersed in it's narrative...and that is exactly how I like my viewing experience.

If you enjoy American western films, Bone Tomahawk is a must see.

BONE TAMAHAWK

Not only am I a huge fan of westerns but I also love everyone that was in this movie so I knew this was going to be a winner. I was surprised  though by how much I really did enjoy this film from writer/director S. Craig Zahler. I cant wait to see what he does next as this was a superbly written and directed film. A western with some horror elements thrown in even though it never feels out of place.

The story follows a sheriff who gets a little posse together after a deputy, fugitive and a doctors assistant are kidnapped by a tribe so brutal even the other Natives are scared of them. These four men including the Doctors assistants injured husband set out on a long journey that is just as dangerous as the destination. The trip will test not only the mens physical well being but their loyalty to one another as well. This of course is all leading to a showdown with the kidnappers who are way more dangerous than anyone had imagined.

This was such a good film, Zahler did an excellent job with this movie giving it time to develop the characters and story over a slower but never boring pace. The characters are super interesting and the actors portraying them all do an excellent job as well. Star and sheriff in the story Kurt Russell gives an A level performance as usual but the supporting actors are just as great including scene stealers like Richard Jenkins, Matthew Fox, and Patrick Wilson as his posse members. Plus we get appearances from people like Sid Haig and David Arquette as well as  a great performance from Lili Simmons.

The story is a very intriguing one and the characters make it one that you actually care about. It is also realistic and when things happen, they happen. This was a wonderful film and the DVD came with a great behind the scenes making of, I just wish we would have had a commentary to go along with it. This film is highly recommended.

Epic , this movie is what I call it for a western . The Kurt and the supporting cast gives great action and toughness!! the plot was suspenseful and keeps you on the tip of your seat! I will watch again and if you are true western/cowboy movie fan then this is your "huckleberry", dig it!

It's all about the simple stark details in this one. The journey is more than half the battle here as we spend a large portion of the film following a rescue squad of four men, two up in years law men, an able bodied man experienced in slaying natives, and a crippled man with a broken leg. Much time is spent on the difficulty of the crippled man, who's wife is the one held captive by vaguely super natural indians. By much time I mean, wincing through every agonizing step. Hobbling with a crudely made splint and a stick for a crutch most of the way. There are cringe moments throughout this film, the pain and injuries sustained are palpable. Woven together with an old western style story and understated, simple, yet highly effective dialogue, acting, directing and production. The realism of the violence effects is quite visceral and unflinching. Can't recall anything quite like this film, it's strong across the boards spanning horror and western. If you are a fan of both, you can't really go wrong here, just be prepared to settle in for the long haul...it feels like one with each painful step forward..

Bone Tomahawk is two separate movies, one great, and the other merely okay.  With a script full of witty, engaging dialogue by S. Craig Zahler (who also makes his directorial debut) and outstanding performances all-around, the western portion of Bone Tomahawk is sure to satisfy fans of the genre, but the horror climax is bound to leave western fans unsatisfied (and more than likely nauseous).

The film centers on the community of Bright Hope, under the stern, watchful eyes of Sheriff Franklin Hunt (Kurt Russel), whose lives are thrown in disarray when their acting town interim-doctor (Lili Simmons), is kidnapped in the dead of the night by an unknown group of natives.  Her husband, Arthur (Patrick Wilson), despite nursing a broken leg, is determined to ride out into hostile territory and retrieve her.  The kidnappers, the towns local Indian informs them, are a members of the troglodytes, a clan of cannibals who dwell in a cave five days ride from Bright Hope.  Despite the mans warning, Arthur isn't dissuaded by the warning, or his broken leg, and, along with Sherriff Hunt, back-up deputy Chicory (Richard Jenkins), and dapper Indian killer John Brooder (Matthew Fox) set out to rescue the captive Samantha before its too late.  When they finally reach the troglodytes cave all hell breaks loose as the posse finds themselves outnumbered and thrust into a harrowing fight for survival against an enemy that can only be described as evil incarnate.

For many viewers, the final act of the film  when it shifts from The Searchers to The Hills Have Eyes  is where Bone Tomahawk stumbles.  I find myself agreeing with that sentiment.  Ive often heard that writers need to know when to let a story grow, even if it means abandoning the original concept that inspired it.  It is my belief that Bone Tomahawks inception came with the idea of being a horror film set in the old west, but, as it was written, evolved into a stellar western that was dragged down by its horror climax.

Where the Bone Tomahawk is at its strongest are the classic Western elements.  While the story about a posse setting posse setting out to rescue a stolen woman is as generic a western plot as you could come by (most famously used in John Fords The Searchers), S. Craig Zahlers script and direction successfully updates the formula for modern viewing audiences, and provides four distinct, memorable interpretations of established Western archetypes. The chemistry between the films four male leads is nothing short of electric.  I genuinely liked these characters, and found myself forgetting they were actorsthe direction, script, and performances were just that good.

The final act flounders not because its bad horror (its plenty shocking, and knows where to subvert horror clichs), but because the Western portion was so good, the horror finale seems merely serviceable.  S. Craig Zahler proves hes a force to be reckoned with in the western genre going forward, but is merely a serviceable as horror writer/director.  Any number of horror filmmakers could have produced this films climax, but only a select few could have written and directed the western portions with the Zahlers strength.

Despite the messy tonal shift in the final act, the good of Bone Tomahawk far outweighs the bad.  When its at its best, Bone Tomahawk is another solid entry in the western genres resurgence in recent years through independent film.  S. Craig Zahler shows great promise as a writer/director, and is someone to keep an eye on.  If you can stomach the finale, Bone Tomahawk is well-worth your time.
This was an excellent movie for both the western and the thriller genres and I recommend it to any fan of either.
It was ok. Different style for a horor movie, but ok
slow moving, but well worth the time

Excellent Western. A huge fan of Kurt Russell and this is one doesn't disappoint. Patrick Wilson also gives an excellent performance.
This movie is definitely in my top 10 favorites. So we bought the DVD!

***** 5 Stars ***** Well, OK, 5 stars for an imaginative action flick brought to you by a streaming service ... obviously, this ain't "Lawrence of Arabia" or "Citizen Kane," but if you just want to be entertained, here is your best option today (you found it today, right?)  A bizarre but fascinating Western - Horror - Psychological Thriller hybrid ... you will keep watching to see 'what happens next,' and the excellent cast and script won't let you down.  Jeff Bridges is perfect - if you liked him in "True Grit" you will love him here.  The film moves at its own pace, and I think it is just fine, but if you lack patience this is not your film ... just go watch "Expendables 3" again, and that way you won't write a dumb, whiny review of this fine film.  Thanks for reading!
Don't watch you'll never get the time back

Kurt Russel did a wonderful job as always, as did the rest of the cast, but I have to agree with some other reviewers that Richard Jenkins as "Backup Deputy" sort of stole the show in this one. The movie wasn't a nonstop action thrillride, but it certainly held my interest. I enjoyed it, but the song during the final credits was hard to stomach and a score during the rest of the movie (if there was one) wasn't memorable at all. This wasn't packed with brutality and gore either, but when it did happen there were NO punches pulled and it was hard or even impossible to watch. I have seen some pretty gruesome movies in my day, being a horror fanatic, but even I flinched and looked away. If you watch the movie you will know exactly what scene I am talking about. If you haven't seen the movie, well...they are cannibals. Over all I enjoyed the movie and think it certainly earned every one of those 4 stars. I would have given it a 5 if the ending had been slightly different (maybe let us know if all the cannibals were dead, if the town was safe, if they even made it back to town) and if there had been a better score to the movie.

Kurt Russell was the pull for me, although the other actors did a fine job. Thriller western, gothic, a lot of descriptives in there that held my attention. It was a different type of western that I'd never seen before. It's a shame that few survived since the remaining characters/actors were quite interesting especially the one who'd taken out so many Indians in his day for personal revenge of family massacre. I'd like to have seen him confront the majority and go out in a blaze of glory. I liked this character. TNT was mentioned, yet I never saw it used unless I missed it. That might have helped, like why have it unless you're going to use it? I noticed the settlers seemed to be equipped with plenty of opium. All in all, this type of "different" western was entertaining, and kept me watching.

Amazing movie. Minutes 6-45 focus on dialogue which helps put the story in place, from there on the movie just takes off. For it being a low budget western, I was not expecting much. This movie was a pleasant surprise. Glad to see Kurt Russell. Awesome movie. 5 stars.

I did not know what to expect but I enjoyed it every step of the way.  I really liked how I noticed very little music but when it did come in it was appropriate.  The backup deputy was all heart, and really stole the show.  Kurt Russel plays a hard case that goes on a rescue mission and even though it seemed like a slow build up every scene was used correctly to develop the plot and/or the characters.  Just watch, relax and enjoy!
Had to turn away a few time interesting for a western

A very unique movie. I've never seen anything like it.
A western that is also a horror film, yet believable. The violence is some of the most extreme that I've seen, but was integral to the plot. It sets up the overwhelming fear and apprehension that the viewer feels while watching.
What is this that they are dealing with? Are they human? Obviously they are pure evil, but as horrible as they are, they actually are not any more evil than the extremist jihadists we deal with in this day and time. So then this level of evil can be believable, since we see similar atrocities facing us in the news every day by similar blood thirsty savages such as Isis.
Much of the acting, especially that of Kurt Russell's is extremely good.
The movie is gripping, shocking, yet believable, but if you have a problem with the violence, which is very well staged, you may want to pass by this one.
I came into this movie not knowing what to expect, and all I can say is that its most definitely worth a watch. Be prepared for some brutal scenes but overall the movie was well done.

Great setup for a movie. Great acting from all four of the cowboys. But horrifically violent. The first two thirds of the movie are great and set the plot for a decent western. Then comes the last act which is just stupid. Really goes out to the left field with stupid unrealistic antagonist. The third act of the movie made me think this became a Predator movie rip off. So much promise and mystery giving the first two acts just to be thoroughly disappointed and baffled by horrific Gore the third act. Amazing how just a few scenes can ruin an entire movie. I was seriously looking for signs of predator drawings in their cave at the end haha.

I would probably give it 4.5 but you can't choose a half star.
Anyway, it surprised me how much I was pulled into the story. I didn't really read or watch anything on this movie, so I only watched it because I saw it while browsing for a movie. So I started it with the intent to stop it if I found it to be boring, over the top, etc... but that never happened. I was into it immediately. I thought all the acting was pretty good (esp. Kurt Russell) as well.
But, above all else, I have to give it a great rating simply because it is such a unique movie... I now view it as a western/thriller/borderline horror movie. And really, the horror part only comes from scenes where you will probably grimace and start to look away... so yes, a little graphic in some areas but that doesn't diminish the movie in any way unless you just can't handle that kind of thing. I am not a horror movie fan so don't let that deter you.

Summation: If you like westerns OR if you like thrillers and you don't mind a mix of the two, then you will really enjoy. I enjoyed the movie and was thoroughly surprised at how good it was (like, why didn't I hear about this movie?). It might become some cult classic... donno, it is hard to predict such things.
A good western. There aren't many these days. And Sid Haig is in it! What's not to love about that? Good stuff!
Great movie,  I've been wanting to see a western for a while.  Actors were great.
Kurt Russell is a movie god!
Quite pathetic. This movie has absolutely no appeal, and it's apparent that very little effort went into making it.
A simple stage show western... Not so good!
this movie was hardcore action. the violence, while believable as part of the plot, was over the top for me.

A fantastic hybrid of Western and Horror brought together almost flawlessly. The cast and dialogue are superbly written as well. Every actor in the film does a fantastic job of portraying a realistic and believable character, with Richard Jenkins as Chicory standing out exceptionally in my opinion.
I have to laugh at these 1 star reviews who somehow seem shocked by the violence in the movie when it's apparent from the description and trailer that it is exactly what you should be in store for, they are going after cave dwelling cannibals after all. That being said, one scene in particular is rather gruesome. As someone who has grown up on gore and horror movies all my life even I was a little surprised with how far it goes, but it only serves to build up how menacing the tribe is and how helpless the protagonists are in that particular scene.
Overall, it's a completely original idea which is exceedingly rare in today's Hollywood and the character writing (especially in the 2nd act) and suspense are pulled off flawlessly. I cannot recommend this enough, especially since it is free with Prime.
Horrible!!graphic and scary movie! I do not recommend. Very disappointing. All excellent actors in movie and everyone was ok with filming this?? Too bad.

It started out good and I thought I was in for a great movie, like Young Guns or Unforgiven. Not so. I don't understand the need nowadays to show such blatant gore (and the sex scene)... whatever happened to leaving it to the imagination? This movie gave me nightmares. The acting was good, don't get me wrong, but the enemy turned out to be so disgustingly vile & atrocious, and the things they did to humans... my God why did they have to show everything?  I'm not kidding when I say I had nightmares for three days afterwards. You might like this movie as the story is interesting, but I feel they executed it all wrong.

Love Kurt Russell! The opening is ominous with good character actors. With all due respect...then everything fall apart. Slow pace, no sense of foreboding supported by spooky music or suggestive half glimpses of scary things. Endless scenes of actors preparing to go after the baddies. Oh, and a mid-20th century coffee table in an early scene of a movie that seems otherwise to be set well before the 1950's. Oh well.

"Bone Tomahawk" is great! This is how the story goes: Four men set out in the Wild West to rescue a group of captives from cannibalistic cave dwellers.

The cast led by Kurt Russell (as Sheriff Hunt), Patrick Wilson (as Arthur), Matthew Fox (as Brooder) & Richard Jenkins (as Chicory) is great. The directing, story & screenplay by S. Craig Zahler (who also did the music, as well, too) is great.

The music by Zahler & Jeff Herriott is great. The cinematography by Benji Bakshi is great. The film editing by Fred Raskin & Greg D'Auria is great. The casting by Matthew Maisto is great. The production design by Freddy Waff is great. The art direction & set decoration by Laura Evans, set dressings by Raul Contreras, Aaron Kanik & Austin Randolph is great. The costume design by Chantal Filson is great. The special effects coordinated by Erich Martin Hicks are great. The visual effects supervised by Pete Sussi is great. The stunts coordinated by Chris Carnel & Darrell Davis is great. The special make-up effects by Trason Fernandes, Susan Laprelle & Lorraine Martin is great.

This is a great and interesting film that does a superb job blending genres together. Kurt Russell (solid as usual as Sheriff Hunt) leads a solid cast that includes Patrick Wilson, Matthew Fox and Richard Jenkins, all three giving solid performances, as well, too. S. Craig Zahler has made a great film that is well-done, well-crafted and entertaining. This is a western / horror film that is a rare beast of a movie.
Wow!.....I never leave reviews...A disturbing but great movie....wow!

Not near as much action as I thought there would be. But the blood, guts and gore were DEFINITELY there. ;-)
  I know and love all 4 of the main actors, that's the biggest reason I watched this. Strictly speaking, for me, I'm glad I have Amazon Prime when I watched this otherwise I may have not have rented or bought this.
  Not Oscar material, maybe Golden Globe or SAG....MAYBE People's Choice but doubtful :-P
  It was pretty good, I liked it.
Lots of good stuff in this film. Interesting dialog stylized to sound like 19th-century talk. Individual characters who change in the course of the film. Unusual bogeymen. Just plain good.

This is a good movie! The only issues I would have edited were some of the slow dialogue parts with the "assistant Deputy Chickory" who slows the movie down and adds about 10 unnecessary minutes to the film. Subtract some of his slow soliloquies and responses and the movie would be right at the sub 2-hr. point which is perfect for most audiences' attention spans.

In addition, the violence perpetrated upon the "second-assistant Deputy" in the cave by the Troglodytes was gratuitous and unnecessary. It was a bit too much and begins to look like a "Saw" movie or "Hostel-type" scenario. If you are a fan of horror you will understand these references as over-the- top scenes exploitative of human suffering.

Otherwise, this is a creative,  suspenseful, well-acted movie. The authentic period dialogue is great also!

Great movie, it shows how a so to say B horror movie made with great acting can turn into a great movie!
A better version of the Hills have Eyes based in late 1800's with great acting.

Disturbing at times, but it held my interest and kept me thinking long after the movie ended. I had forgotten what a powerful screen presence Kurt Russell is; it was great to see him again. In fact, all the main characters were well performed. Definitely worth watching.

Perhaps it is just me but I found the premise of the movie intesting but the execution of
the story boring and predictable.

Not a bad movie but not a good movie. Decent time killer.

Interesting idea and I liked the characters, but incredibly graphic. I don't see the reason for such gratuitous violence.

Very captivating and although not original it had that "original" feel that some great movies have.  The acting was well done.  Plot was a little slow but that's necessary to tell some stories.  Everyone who rated it 1 star is clearly a buffoon who either quotes this is a sci-fi(which is ridiculous) or they're just angry because their stomach is weak.  I didn't blink once the entire time.

Sloooow! The last 45 minutes are gross, extremely horrifying, you'll probably end up having nightmares and the cowboy doesn't ride away at the end.
Worth watching. Wife hated it.

Since we all free to express opinions, and free to disagree with others,  I think Bone Tomahawk will be well received by Westerns fans.  Once the harshness of actually being in the west in the 19th century is realized, this film's pace, characters, and scenery is superb.  Yes,  there are difficult scenes that sensually shock 21st century comfort levels; however, the old west of cowboys and Indians was a rough place.  Great acting and realism.
I Loved it
As Described
Great Movie!!
Good plot and story telling by the screenwriter. Great special effects.
Something different.  A western horror film with cannibalistic cave dwellers.  What's not to like!
Kurt Russell's next(maybe last) cult movie.

I don't know if I'd watch it again, because it does drag (very little) in the middle, but I'd recommend viewing it at least once.

I rented this movie from the redbox.  The acting is good but the story sucks. A very stupid story line.  It drags and drags.  Very little action until near the end.  I wouldn't recommend it unless you have nothing better to do.

Loved everything about his movie! Saw a few mistakes (David Arquette's teeth were clean in one scene and gross/green in another.) but that's just small stuff. This movie starts off great, then does a slow burn to build the quirky character's and story, and then finishes with a bang!

No not a traditional classic style western we're used to seeing. Many of us remember and loved Kurt Russell in Tombstone. Well his performance is just as great in this movie but, this is NOT a western in the traditional style that tombstone was and many other westerns of the 80's or 90s. This western has grit. It's straight forward style, in your face dialogue and action. Some have called it "SHOCK" tactics, but I don't think so.
***This movie is NOT for the weak stomachs*** When I say this is not a traditional style western, I mean this is shot in a manner that you could be fly on the wall observing. There are no Cliched quotes, there is no over the top dramatic musical score when some dramatic is said or done. That being said, you don need one. When something profound is said or done, you do feel it.
All actors are at they're best. You might ask, how can a western not be for the people with weak stomachs. Well as I said this film has GRIT. Grit when said, in my mind is a life like representation of the scene or situation. Basically I mean many movies will dress up a scene nice and pretty how Hollywood wants you to see it. This movie does not, An example here ***SPOILER ALERT HERE*****. For example; when an Indian would scalp someone in a traditional western, it not likely you will see the actual act. In this movie you will see a scalping and by golly it looks real....well to those of us that have never seen a scalping, you see the entire scene although it lasts all of about 45 seconds.
SPOILER OVER*** Some people are saying the movie carry's blood and gore tactics to get your attention. I don't agree, I see it as realistic entertainment, they are pulling you in the moment.
This movie is clearly not for everyone and that's ok, some here have judged Kurt Russel & Mathew Fox for making such a movie, there is and audience for these type westerns, and I for one enjoyed it.
On a last note, the did have again, straight forward dialogue, nothing profound, but realistic to what conversations might have been like 100 years ago in the west since most people barely had a grammar school education. The movie is 2 hours and 40 minutes long. The first hour you will start wondering if the movie is going anywhere, it is a bit of druggery.... but sit tight, it will take off, and it will hit you hard.
Some didn't like the ending, I liked it as I cant see any other way it could have gone.

Kurt just gets better with age...like a fine wine he continues to develop his acting flavor.  This movie really kept me on the edge of my seat.  It was also gross and scary so is not a good movie for the faint of heart!  Sit back and get ready for a good ride!  I'm definitely going to buy the DVD for my collection.
Loved the story. Loved the acting

I am a Kurt Russell fan.  It is  a different type of western.  All actors were good.  Richard Jenkins is the shine in this movie; loved him.  Plot developed slowly, just wish the conclusion was achieved a little faster.

Really watchable movie.  Good character development.  Horrible ending with a less than exciting climax.  The old man throws the rock after hearing 3 gun shots, assuming Kurt Russel's character finished off the final three cannibal Indians.  I was actually hoping for a bit more, with a face off of at least one more, leaving that old man to rethink his judgement.  Obviously, the cripple has a very long voyage, certainly not going to make it back home without a deadly infection.  His wife could have acted a bit more malnourished and less energized on the walk away from her captives.  So disappointing.

The script is awesome, and scenes are really well-made. The grizzly twist is one of the scariest I've watched. By the climax, you'll be gripping onto something for goodness sake. Dudes who like modern western movies, like 3:10 to Yuma, then you'll like this for sure. If you're into thrillers or horror movies as well, double like. I'm only deducting a star because it scared me like nothing else. So be prepared!
Ridiculous waste of time. Meaningless dialogue. Drudgery with an exclamation of violence for pure shock value. I feel violated. Really. What a waste of talent.
Fantastic with lots of humour

This was one of the most disturbing movies ever!!!  I cannot believe Kurt Russell would participate in this movie.  I always enjoyed the movies he chose to be in, therefore thought this movie would be a great western.
WRONG!!!
The rating was/in NR for what reason I have NO idea! They're was brief nude scenes, various language, but first & foremost the most DISTURBING scenes of blood & gore!
Stripping a man down naked, scalping him (screaming), then shoving his scalp into his mouth, (more screaming) pounding into his throat with an instrument of some sort. THEN hanging him upside down and pounding tools in his genitals (more screaming), kept going with that until he split in half & the men tore him in half, before eating him.
EXTREMELY DISTURBING. These men were cannibals, and had two women for impregnating purposes only. These women had eyes gouged out with sticks of some sort and limbs had been severed.
Kurt Russell himself (character) was taken and stretched out, cut with a bone hatchet from the navel to the liver & a hot flask shoved in the area.
One, if not the Worst, Most Disturbing movies I have seen.
It sticks with you for a few days after seeing it. (ONE of THOSE).
I made sure to see the writers name & will never watch another movie by him again.
The story line was slow, and it has a western theme, I kept thinking it will pick up. You are three-quarters through the movie before all of the above mentioned, takes place.
Shame on you Kurt Russell, Matthew Fox, Patrick Wilson and Richard Jenkins for lowering yourselves to not even a "B" movie!!!!
Great movie! Just watch it.
Disturbing movie!  Move not rated. Kurt Russell is a great actor, but this movie is gross.  Definitely not what I expected.
Almost a Sci Fi Very gripping story, Constantly stirred emotions of one kind or another. Man versus beast, decent acting. My rating is my opinion only see it to believe it.
Great "girls night out" film, splendid "chick flick".  Splitting humor.  Gather 'round the little ones.  The best part about this movie is Kurt Russell.

I'm very surprised at the number of negative reviews on this film. Most are upset about one of the gory scenes in particular. One guy complained that his young daughter was disturbed by it. It's an R-rated movie folks - not for kids. But if you are effeminate, squeamish, prudish, or just have a low tolerance for gore then you should probably move along to the Disney section because this film is not for you.

I thought this was an authentic western. But is certainly has a twist. From start to finish the cast keeps you engaged and wondering what could come next. What eventually comes next is cannibals. If cannibals doesn't clue you in to what is coming then you are slow on the uptake. Kurt Russel plays the tough sheriff as well as you would expect. But the "backup deputy" steals the show. I thought the dialog was wonderful funny and exactly as you'd expect from the period.

All in all, an enjoyable flick. I think what disturbs people is that they don't expect this kind of gore in a Kurt Russel film. Get over it. It is a good story and well acted. I recommend it - but not while the kids are up.
Boring
Very bad horror story meets the cliche old west with a few overly gross and violent scenes thrown in.  Perhaps it was supposed to be a parody, if so, it failed.

This was ridiculous. I pray the writer/director has found the correct dosage of his medication because only the seriously deranged could have thought of something like this. The plot line was strange and the ending was TERRIBLE. Also, do not try to watch this movie as you eat, I wish someone would have informed me of such.

Much better than I expected given the 3 1/2 stars, really should be 4 - 4 1/2 stars. I gave it 5 to bump it up. Dialogue and character development was excellent. Very gory at the end and the existence of these troglodyte cannibals is a little hard for me to believe, yet it was thoroughly entertaining none the less.

I'm a fan of Kurt Russell but this movie is garbage.  It's a science fiction movie set in the old west and pits four of the people from a small town against a tribe of howling troglodytes.  Yes, TROGLODYTES!  I wish that had been made clear in the description because I would never have bought it.  I feel like I was screwed out of fifteen bucks.  I feel cheated by having to give it one star because it's not worthy of any stars.  Stay away from this movie.
great film!
excellent
I really enjoyed that. This movie really surprised me . Maybe because I had not heard of it. It had an interesting twist . Well acted .And it's a western with Kurt Russell .

I'm sorry i sat through this mediocre, monotonous movie, only to have a horrible gory image planted, that i didn't want, and i can't delete. It has always concerned me that some people enjoy watching others be abused.

Horrible movie. I had nightmares for a week and I'm 75. I thought I'd seen everything but it takes a sick mind to think up something like this. I love Kurt Russell but he should have passed on this movie.
Great script, great acting, great pacing, great film!  It should be up for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Editing, Best Screenplay, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor, for sure!

Totally unexpected good movie.  Almost hard to describe.  Focus on the dialogue that is not filled with F-bombs throughout and is unique in itself.  Let yourself enjoy that fact alone.  The polite dialogue exchanges between the characters is obviously intended to contrast what you usually hear in movies such as this and is pretty darn funny.  Cast is stellar, especially the "backup Deputy".  This has some gruesome scenes...particularly towards end. Even I had to look away....but it is the cast, dialogue, and interspersed humor that catches you off guard.  I will watch this again just to focus on the dialogue between the characters.

As a western, it actually isn't too bad.  I have to concur with the opinions here, Jenkins steals the show, but I would say Wilson a close second.  The rest of the acting is sub-par at best to just downright horrible for the other 75% of the cast.  Fox's part is a caricature of poor acting, but he did well with what he was given.  I enjoyed the realism of the first 3/4, but the gratuitous scenes of the last were really unneeded and horribly choreographed.  I honestly wouldn't bother recommending this to anyone that has an affinity for westerns in the slightest.
Pleasantly surprised.  Gruesome at times, but a western movie worth watching

This moves extremely slow with many pointless drawn out parts. It failed to build much heart for the characters in it, making it hard to care what happened to them. I have to give to stars just because of Russells epic mustache beard combo!

GREAT MOVIE! Not sure why anybody would try to compare this movie to any other, just based on cast members! It's rated R, it's definitely not a "princess" movie. There's a wide-release movie that opened Jan 8, 2016, depicting events in the early 19th century west, getting rave reviews, that seemed to me to be as much  or more graphically bloody than Bone Tomahawk.
I really wanted to like this movie since Kurt russel is the man! But wow it was extremely boring and dumb.

Great entertainment. Of course it helps if you like the western genre, overall it was a very good movie. The acting was great and the story was, for the most part, something that you would believe could happen in the "wild west". There was one character that seemed mis-cast for the movie, aside from that one the entire cast was perfect.

THIS IS YOUR MOVIE

Hadn't heard anything about this until seeing it on Amazon, but decided to give it a try.  Very interesting story, kept me engaged, and great performances.

Fantastic! I appreciate the filmmakers putting only one scene of brutality in there. Great character portrayals also, each one had a good sense of integrity about them, for the most part. Thanks again you guys! I would definitely purchase it to own!
This movie is like a breath of fresh air. I do not recall ever watching a Western thriller/horror film before this one.
Fantastic film

I'm picky about my westerns.  I hate the ones which have the people acting with the same values and attitudes as those of the people in the 21st century.  A little authenticity goes a long way with me.  You get better ratings if the screenwriting were closer to the writings of  Louis L'Amour in their authenticity.

This was well done. Some GREAT performances. Plot was kinda wonky, and I still don't know what happened to the horses, but it was entertaining. The ending fell kinda flat too. Not perfect, but a fun and entertaining flick.

First "Horror-western" I've seen. Very good show and a slow burner of a plot. There's some serious gore, so you'd better be ready for that. Certainly an 'R' rating. Anyway, great acting all around. Kurt Russel is very good here and so are the rest of the group. An interesting story, and well told. Doesn't rely on the typical clich stuff. I give it 4/5 because 5/5 is reserved for stuff like Unforgiven and just stone cold classics like that. It's well worth your time to watch.
This is beyond psychopathically horrifying.  I wish with every fiber of my being that I had never watched this.  It takes very, very sick people to make a movie like this.  Very sick.

This is for die-hard horror-slasher fans who can take the silly dialogue and tongue-in-cheek acting and effects as all part of the "fun." Seems like Kurt Russell and a couple of friends didn't have anything better to do so decided it might be kinda fun to ride horses around and do some cheesy campfire scenes and make a little money. It's a genre-bending experiment that mostly moves too slow and falls too flat. It's main draw is that it's creepily different... cowboys vs. cannibals. It rates VERY low on the art-sophistication scale so only bother with it if you have an affinity with the weird-B-horror genre.

This is one of the MOST DISTURBING movies I've ever seen, and as an avid movie buff @ 51 yrs old, I've seen more than my share of movies.  The torture scene toward the end, is one of those RARE scenes in a very rare film, WHERE YOU WISH YOU COULD UN-SEE IT!!!  The brutality and depravity of it is off the charts, and the camera doesn't flinch or blink, so almost before you can avert your eyes, the horror is already through your eyeballs and in your brain.  It is the kind of scene that probably inspires sick and mentally unstable people to copy.

As for the movie, itself, it is  V-E-R-Y  S-L-O-W.  The budget must have been very low, as it has VERY FEW "extras" in the town, to make it even look like a real town.  The dialogue is awful and much of it has absolutely no purpose for being in the movie, and the enunciation of their lines is so "proper" that you know it would NEVER be spoken in these situations.  Spoiler alert------I mean, the movie is a Western, set in the 1800's, yet some of the language used by the characters are so "advanced education level" that you know they would NEVER have been spoken by those characters and in that setting.  And how is it even plausible to think that after the characters have WALKED for miles and miles through the hot, barren land, and finally made camp---but can only sleep for 4 hours---that their clothes are not very dirty, and NOBODY is stiff, grunting, complaining, or even looking tired.  Then 2 men lie down to sleep and end up talking about how to READ A BOOK IN THE BATHTUB, without getting it wet???  To add to the lack of reality, no such tribe of people ever existed in the US.  And after the torture scene, the female character--looking totally non-plussed--goes into a "political-type" diatribe, implying that it is NOT this tribe's fault for the way they are victimizing people, but is the fault of the victims, who are just stupid idiots, who don't understand that they shouldn't BOTHER these people, or some such non-sense.

Sorry, but I turned the thing off, after that, so I can't say how it ended, or whether the ending made any of it seem more plausible.  So, I will just end by saying, it was over an hour of my time, that I will NEVER get back, and placed an awful visual image and mental disturbance in my brain, that i can never UN-SEE.  Sorry, Kurt Russell, but I really am shocked, that an actor of his caliber would stoop to this low-level movie.
