A very different and somewhat fanciful Western perhaps.........
When two citizens and a prisoner go missing in the small town of Bright Hope 'Sheriff Franklin Hunt' (Kurt Russell) immediately suspects
them to have been taken by Indians.........however as a Indian who resides in the town tells him those responsible for the abduction are
unlike any native he'd ever encountered before it's a group known as The Troglodyte's' who are cannibalistic cave dwellers.
Well. the Sheriff rounds up a small posse to rescue those taken including 'Arthur' (Patrick Wilson) who's wife 'Samantha' (Lilli Simmons)
is among those taken...he despite being crippled by a leg injury is determined to at least try to get his wife back....gunfighter 'Brooder'
(Mathew Fox) and elderly deputy Sheriff 'Chicory' (Richard Jenkins)
A few nights into the journey the horses are taken while they slept they will now have to continue on foot which for partially crippled 'Arthur'
will be an additional ordeal.
The task now ten times more difficult the quest continues however when they do come face to face with the abductors they will find them to
be a fearless and formidable opponent.
Can the posse overcome the odds and save those that have been taken or is it quite simply too late ??
The film can feel a little slow-moving at times however there is a certain amount of tension along the way coupled with some action sequences
and scenes of visually brutal and graphic moments.
There are also a couple of sequences of an adult nature and nudity.

Basically all you will be talking about after watching it is how a man literally gets scalped and split in two with an axe while alive-- screaming all the while. I love Kurt Russell, but the plot was dragging in certain parts. And, I agree with other reviewers-- I hate when the plausibility is removed. Like it took them forever to get to where the cannibals were-- but then they just start walking home at the end? The woman and her fellow prisoners aren't screaming their heads off in sheer horror as their friend is being horrifically cut open and split? The 2 pregnant blind cannibal chicks are just left and not shot? As they went on the journey to get back the kidnapped characters the plot got more exciting....it was pretty good until the splitting scene-- then you just feel a hot wave of disgust wash over you as you wonder why things like that are permitted in films. I agree with another reviewer who said it's funny when people rate this a 5 star movie because 5 star movies you would want to watch over and over again. This film, despite any other good qualities it had-- was certainly not one you would ever want to watch over and over again unless you were mentally pretty ill and/or love watching others feel pain.

I saw the low/average star rating and thought based on the trailer that there had to be some sort of disconnect. Most seem to either love or hate this film. After having watched it, I think most people's issues were the gratuitous violent scenes, which I didn't have a problem with, although my wife saw one scene and was completely turned off. The other issues many people had was the slow burn, but I felt that it made the journey feel more realistic even if it padded the film a bit. When the action picks up, it is pretty incredible and non-conventional. I was genuinely terrified for the main roster of characters. Great performances from entire cast. This movie isn't Tombstone, nor does it try to be. No shootouts, whistle themes, or humor whatsoever. This is a dark tale, but one worth watching.

Two killers wander into a burial ground, disturbing the remains. This sets off a chain of events that leads to a rescue mission across the abandoned desert: a sheriff, his aging deputy, an Indian killer, and a bereaved and crippled husband fighting bandits, the terrain, and each other. But what is waiting for them at the end of their journey is a kind of primal horror they have never before witnessed.

Sometimes, a movie is more than just a movie; sometimes, it's an experience. BONE TOMAHAWK is such a film. It's unflinching; that's the best word for it. Yes, that means there is graphic violence; but more to the point, the violence is presented honestly and clearly, with no stylization and little grandiose music. It is what it is. And, guess what: violence ain't pretty.

The film is more than a violent head-trip, though. It's anchored by a solid script, cinematography, and direction. And perhaps best of all, the acting is on-point. The three leads, if you will--Kurt Russell, Richard Jenkins, and Matthew Fox--are absolutely stellar. The supporting cast--roles of varying sizes from Patrick Wilson, Sid Haig, Lili Simons, and David Arquette--help round things out. The realistic performances make the movie even harder to watch at times. And yes, it is hard to watch. In the good way; it's an uncomfortable film, but a very good one. Maybe not a classic, per say, but perhaps bound to be a cult classic before all is said and done.
Another Kurt Russel great performance.  It is definitely the best film I have viewed this year.  One of the few movies I would watch again.

A great story about paleoaborriginal clan living on human prey and raiding wanderers and sometimes settlements!  A gore-fest with a great story to boot, and it don't get any better than this with Kurt Russell playing a tough lawman who always gets his man!  Wunderbar!

Such a fantastic movie. I wouldn't really consider it "horror," though it is violent and almost oppressively bleak at times. One scene, in particular, ranks up there among the more stomach-churning ever put to film. Superb in all phases - script, acting, direction, photography.

If gore is central to the plot of a story well told then so be it, not every entertainment worthy of your time and attention should be a refined period drama suitable for a PBS fundraiser. However, when gore is transformed into sadism as a substitute for deficiencies in scripting and direction then all you really  have left is the bloody distraction of a film cheapened by grotesque voyeurism - Bone Tomahawk is such a film and one that richly deserves its direct-to-video pedigree.

While some reviewers seem enamored by the sparse dialogue and the sometimes interesting first-person character sketches in this late period Western drama, the narrative is overwhelmed by scenes that are so graphic and disturbing that dynamic storytelling is clearly beside the point. To Kurt Russell, all I have to say is, why? And to the Washington Redskins, you have my permission to keep the name.

Just finished watching this and all I can say is...wow!  What a great western/horror film.  I had never heard of it before and it was recommended by a friend of mine.  Kurt Russell and the rest of the cast were just great in this film.  It's pretty intense and it slowly builds to a crazy climax that just has you on the edge of your seat.  There were several scenes that are just shocking and you can hardly stand to watch it but you'll find yourself glued to the screen and you can't turn away.  Without giving away any spoilers, I'll just say that the story revolves around a search and rescue mission with Russell, who plays the sheriff, leading an unlikely team to get the job done.  What they encounter is both mysterious and shocking.

The film runs about 2 hours and 12 minutes and I enjoyed it immensely.  Well written, great cast, and plenty of nail bitting moments throughout.  I love that they combined two of my favorite genres (westerns and horror) into a very entertaining story.  Richard Jenkins, who plays the part of the deputy named Chicory, did an amazing job with his performance.  His character's ramblings and strange conversations really helped to break up the tension of the story and added a great dynamic to the cast of characters.  I really enjoyed Matthew Fox's performance as well and Kurt Russell is just awesome in this film.  You definitely have to check this out!

This one nearly snuck by me.  Russell was great, as was the rest of the cast.  It kept me on edge for 2 hours.  Some of the dialog is influenced by the Cohens (referring to the mouth of a guy who won't shut up as an "aperture.")  Not sure anyone ever really talked like that and I don't care.

Surprisingly good. I watched this film not expecting very much. It looked like something Russell did because he still had Western style mutton-chops after Hateful 8 and wanted to get as much mileage out of them as possible. But it was fairly well acted, decently written, and had a number of interesting and sympathetic characters. It actually would have still worked quite well without the fantastical elements, which, I think, did not really add or detract that much from the movie. Not something I would want to spend 15 bucks to see, but not a bad time killer on a slow Sunday afternoon.

The only reason I gave one star is because it's impossible to give negative five stars, in spite of some good acting.  I have seen some truly over the top grotesque and sadistic movies made for no other reason than to shock the viewer and push the limits of what marginal taste and appetites an increasingly voyeuristic/thrill seeking public will tolerate, but not in a long time.  I felt like I needed to take a bath or go to confession after watching this.  Some reviewers have compared this film to one of the best "westerns" they have seen in a while. What have they been smoking - or do they work for the studio?  I guess I have gotten old enough and wise enough to recognize crap for what it is.  Some forces in Hollywood do not have your best interests in mind.  Over time messages like this shapes culture - and not in a good way.

On the plus side, the acting was really good, after you get into the show and realize the Director is purposely making this a bit of a melodrama and encouraging overacting.  At first, it felt like a B movie.  I think those who like gratuitous violence and click on the 'horror' button often will really love this. On the minus side, if you prefer a good story, but like to feel good when it is over, avoid this one.  Nothing feel good about it.  I have to be a little amused by people who give it 5 stars, because in my book a 5 star movie can be watched over and over and over again. 4 stars may be generous... but this is a solid, slow-burn Western-come-horror movie. As another reviewer noted, it's all about the Russel. Let's take a closer look...

Set in a nondescript Western town, the story arc follows the emergence of a savage, and very primitive tribe that is responsible for the disappearance of several locals. You do not get a sense until well into the movie as to why these people are taken. In always singular form, Kurt Russel forms the backbone of this story with his largely leading role, although there are fine performances from most of the cast -- the deputy Sheriff really grows on you thru out the movie, as does [to some degree] the preening local "Indian killer". The pacing and general story-form reminds me of Depp's "Dead Man". Certainly an unusual and original one, if you are tired of the typical gunslinger reels, revenge movies, or "authentic to the point of paint drying watch-a-bility", give this one a go with your favorite XXXtra butter popcorn, and you may find that 3.5 stars just doesn't quite sit right with you in the current ratings.

It was really well done. It is hard to believe it was made for just $1.8 million. A great script and cast goes a long way.

It is gruesome and violent, and not recommended for younger viewers, but it was well worth the time to watch.

I have no idea how this movie is rated so high (on Amazon or Rotten Tomatoes). Positive reviews cite the unique blend of western and horror. It certainly had potential, but it ultimately fell flat. This movie was uninspired, slow, boring and overall very poor execution. The acting was terrible. There was little atmosphere to it at all and pretty much no musical score to support it.

On the other hand, I can't help but laugh at the negative reviews complaining about the gore or "twisted" and "sadistic" story. Did you read the description of the movie or watch the trailer? Cannibal savages doesn't give you any indication? If you did read the description and were still offended or expected a classic western, you either don't really watch horror films or you have poor reading comprehension skills or both.

As an avid horror movie fan, I've seen FAR worse in terms of gore. And by the way, gore is not essential to a good horror film. Some of my favorite (and most terrifying) are actually not gory at all and some of the goriest are tongue-in-cheek campy to the point of actually being funny. But I'm not giving Bone Tomahawk 1 star for the gore or being over-the-top in any way; it's anything but. It was a terribly boring and poorly executed flop that should have been rated more appropriately as such. Thankfully the movie was included in my Prime and I didn't spend extra money to rent it. My only hope is that my review saves someone from wasting the time I did on watching this piece of garbage.

A really singular Western/Horror slow-burning movie, that has also something of drama and more than a touch of comedy. A re-imagination of the Western that is, at the same time, true to the origins of the genre (that is, life at the border of "civilization"). However, in this contemporary Western the "villains" are not Native people, but something else linked to the remotest past of the specie, almost pre-human. In this sense, it has several points in common with movies like "The 13th Warrior" or "The Descent". And since the barbaric primitives are enemies of all humans, regardless of race, I believe the creation of those imaginary adversaries is a clever way to avoid the racism behind so many Western movies. It serves more like a metaphor of how primitive appetites that lurk in the shadows of our specie can menace the "bright hope" of civilization, no matter the ethnic origin of its inhabitants. Not in vain, we meet two white criminals at the opening of the movie that are not better (or less barbaric) than the cave-dweller enemies.
A warning: there is a particularly gory torture scene toward the middle of the movie that can be too graphic for many viewers ("The Hills Have Eyes" or "Hostel" kind of violence). This is most probably not a movie that you want to watch with your children.
Terrible movie. Waste of time from my perspective.

Bone Tomahawk, directed by S. Craig Zahler, is what I consider to be a slow burn to a very dramatic ending with intense violence and bloodshed.  In some ways this reminded me of Clint Eastwoods The Unforgiven, though with a different story line, a different cast, a first-time director, and a really small budget.  If this film had had a larger budget and Clint's name as the Director, I can almost guarantee that it would be up for all kinds of awards, including an Oscar.

Some viewers, because of the films slow beginning, aren't going to like the movie.  Thats okay with me.  I loved it, and how the film took the time to introduce the main characters with their strengths and weaknesses.  It also helped that the posse was led by Kurt Russell (aka Wyatt Earp).  He somehow managed to keep the film in balance between over-acting and the comedy elements interjected at different points in the film.  Richard Jenkins (Deputy Chicory) brings in the humor with his wit and comedic tales.  In fact, Jenkins nearly steals the movie right out from under everybody else.

This is the story of a few citizens of Bright Hope being kidnapped by cannibalistic savages that dwell in the mountainous caves about five days from the small town.  One of the people kidnapped is the beautiful Dr. ODwyer (Lili Simmons).  Her husband is determined to get her back alive with or without the help of the town.  Kurt Russell plays Sheriff Franklin Hunt, who gathers four men (not nearly enough for a posse) to go after the Indians and their captives on a rescue mission.  Joining the posse are Deputy Chicory (Richard Jenkins), Arthur ODwyer (Patrick Wilson), and gunslinger and Indian killer, John Brooder (Edward Fox).  I really liked the character of John Brooder.  He was a no-nonsense kind of man who would just as soon shoot you as argue.

As the posse goes after the Indians, you begin to learn about the crippled Arthur ODwyer and his determination to save his wife.  Though you hate the character of John Brooder at first, you come to appreciate his knowledge of killers and the West, and to understand what happened in his past to make him the way he is.  Deputy Chicory, who had to fight to get the Sheriff to let him come along, offers the comedic relief for the movies intense moments, giving the audience his insights into whats happening with his funny one-liners and also the tale of the flea circus that he once saw.

Now the Indians, or Troglodytes, are fearful savages out of your worst nightmare.  Theyre huge and tall, and eagerly fight to the death.  You don't want to be one of their prisoners because these Indians are cannibals and have unique, but violent ways of killing their captives and later eating them.

When the posse finally confronts the Troglodytes, the battle that ensues is not what you expect; nor, is the ending.  This is an in-your-face kill or be killed fight with no holds barred.  What happens will literally take your breath away in horrific shock and maybe even give you a nightmare or two.

Bone Tomahawk never showed in the theater I frequent.  So, I had to wait for the DVD to come out in order to see the movie.  There are certainly things that viewers and critics might not like about the film.  Theres very little music in the background, which I believe is due to the low budget.  The movie is a long one with most of the action at the end.  The ending is definitely not what a viewer would expect.  And, the cutting and editing of the film is clearly by a first-time director, though the actual editor helped the director to put together the best movie possible;.

Now, given all of that, I still loved the film.  This was a movie that was made from the passion of its director and cast and crew.  Nobody made any money off of this.  Still, this is type of film that will eventually become a cult classic in a big way.  I certainly enjoyed the actors in each role and thought they did a magnificent job in bringing their characters to life.  All of them played a vital part in the movie.  Though Kurt Russell is the star and does a tremendous job of playing the low keyed, man-of-few-words hero, all of the other actors certainly brought their A-List performances to the making of this film.  The director clearly did an excellent job when you consider the fact that there wasn't much of a budget for him to work with, or to pay the cast and crew.

This was definitely a Western film in the biggest sense of the term.  Word of mouth will soon spread about this excellent, low budget movie, and people will be buying the DVD or seeing it on Netflix.  Keep in mind that some will not like it, but those that do will rave about it to others.  Bone Tomahawk is going to be one of those films that develop a life of its own on DVD much like Ed Harris Appaloosa has and John Carpenters The Thing.  This movie is not for the squeamish.  Make no mistake about that.  The ending will stay with you long after the film is over.

Oh, and the DVD has nearly an hour of Behind-the-Scenes information on the making of the movie, along with questions and answers from the cast and crew.

For me, this is the best type of picture to seeone that makes you ponder and think and question.

Highly recommended!

Western-horror mashups are a genre I need more of in my life, and Bone Tomahawk delivers on its premise of cowboys versus cannibals in spades.

As Sheriff Hunt, Kurt Russel leads a four-man squad into the hills to rescue the abducted wife of cowboy Arthur O'Dwyer (Patrick Wilson). Joined by O'Dwyer, his Back Up Deputy, and sharpshooter John Brooder (Matthew Fox), the group is beset by O'Dwyer's broken leg and a group of Mexican bandits who make off with their horses.

The violence comes in quick, rapid-fire bursts and provides enough shock to keep this viewer glued to the screen. In between are quiet interludes, oftentimes filled with witty banter that really help to personalize each of these characters. Russel, as expected, continues to be at the top of his game, but it was Matthew Fox that most surprised me here. Brooder is an interesting sort, his keen intellect setting him apart from, and in his own mind oftentimes above, the others. He's smarter than everyone else and damn well knows it, and he's quick with a rifle. When we first meet him he convinces the sheriff his place on the group on account of the high number of Indians he has killed. When chided for boasting about such a thing, he deflects - it wasn't a boast, merely a fact. He's coldly analytical and consistently interesting when on screen.

The cannibal savages provide bookends to the narrative, but their presence in the finale catapults this western into the truly savage, reminding viewers that this is a horror story cast in a Wild West mold. There's gore aplenty, and the violent climax provides several scenes that are brutally wince-inducing.

Bone Tomahawk works as both a terrific western and as a haunting horror flick, with a top-notch cast that brings screenwriter and director S. Craig Zahler's vision to life perfectly.

The online debate is this a Western or Horror movie? A Horror movie or a Western? The debate is going on in lots of the geeky movie sites. The  debate certainly caught my interest. The warnings have to do with the whole end climax of the movie. I watched the film twice over the weekend, I AM A WESTERN movie fan, I am NOT a horror movie fan. I am a huge Kurt Russell fan (he being one of the geek-gods, Snake Plisskan and Jake Burton, Elvis etc.) and it was great to see him in fine form as the hero, after skipping many of recent Tarintino films that he has been in. All the 4 main actors are absolutely terrific in the movie, Matthew Fox, Rickard Jenkins and Patrick Wilson- all wonderful. The writing is also a highlight as it somewhat like a weird John Ford film in that characters from this film remind me of some of eccentric characters from "The Searchers" Richard Jenkin's "Chickory" is in that mold. As to the shocking visuals in the climax, and yes it is, I felt this was where Mr. Zahler somewhat got his story confused and thus his audience. If you have read only a little about the founding of our West, you know atrocities were committed by all sides in the battle for the old West. I remember seeing a photo in an old Time/Life collection on the Frontier of a settler whose body was brutally abused by Indians. So is it a Western or a horror movie? its a very good WESTERN. The horror is that Mr. Zahler chose to depict at the end a very gruesome (but probably a true depiction or variation) of what might have happened in savage lands of the Old West. And yes its a little spooky, which is fun, but if you're a Western fan give it a look. No children and keep the remote ready to pause THOSE scenes at the end. It sure was good to see Mr. Russell as Sheriff Hunt back in the type of movie he moves to a higher level with his participation. Oh, and best movie title of the year.
Thrilling and highs lows and in between.

It's difficult to rate this movie, which has a ridiculous plot, and yet has very good settings, costumes, characters, acting, etc.

Without lacing this little review with spoilers, suffice to say that in the Old West of approximately 1900, it would be next to impossible for these "forces" to remain at play.  "Bad guys" such as these would have been exterminated by the native Indians long before White Europeans ever arrived here.

But, perhaps borrowing something from the deliciously slow-paced "atmosphere" and visually stunning settings of other Westerns that have emerged in American cinema for the past 20 years, the director has crafted a very believable background and "milieu" for what is, unfortunately, a very unbelievable plot line.

And that's the enigma I face in reviewing this movie... because ALL the actors are very, very good, and to add to my dilemma, the directing is also top-drawer.  I should have probably given the movie a higher rating, because, after all, it's supposed to be entertainment -- not a "docu-drama".  Still, if the story is just not based in any kind of reality germane to the place or time it's supposed to occur in, then the whole thing is built on a flawed foundation.

Suggestion: if you like the "atmosphere" created in this Western movie, you may enjoy movies like "Appaloosa", or "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" more.
I love this movie.  The acting was great.  Kurt Russell is awesome.  The Native Americans are scary.

Like so many other people have said, this movie was really messed up by one very terriblly graphic scene that can never be unseen. That, and it just kept going on forever. We get it, their journey was really, really, really hard. It did have some good actors in it and I did enjoy some of the dialogue. But seriously, the few violent scenes there were, were way over the top.
I enjoyed this film and I think that many people will as well. It's not the best western movie but  keeps you actively engaged. Some scenes are very graphic and violent but overall is a good movie.

It was a great Western, one of the best horrors, and I honestly wasn't bored for a second of it. It does contain one or two of the goriest movie scenes I've ever seen, but it really helped to amp up the tension at the end. When they do this in SAW or Hostel it's pointless, but in a movie like this with well acted characters it serves a greater purpose. It's always hit or miss when a movie uses long tedious travel scenes across barren landscapes to convey just how long and tiresome a journey is. I can understand those that found the use of such scenes in the movie a tad boring, but I love Westerns and so I can't really get enough of the scenery. Add in actors and characters that I really like and the mystery of what they're heading toward and I thing they did it very well this time.

The bad guys of the film were pretty damn scary. The brute force and speed of them, the way they'd make their footsteps thud, and especially their horns. I know we've seen all this before, but by keeping them off the screen most of the movie (especially when they were kidnapping people from the town at the beginning and then later all the way up until the end instead of jumping back and forth from them to the protagonists) they made them much more terrifying.

The best thing about the movie though, and of course many have already commented on it, is that the dialogue and the characters feel very real. It's hard enough finding that in most movies but it's almost impossible finding it in Horror movies (or partial-horror anyway).

As another reviewer said... 'Because Kurt Russell'... if you are a Kurt Russell fan, just rent it!  Right now!  I really didn't know what to expect from this, and so I just watched it and it unfolded in unexpected ways.  First of all, with most modern day westerns, you are used to more rough and tumble action scenes, but those always seemed to me, to not be normal.  Is that how real people in a real outpost town would react?  I really loved how this movie showed how real people, living in that time and place, probably would have acted.  They were formal, they apologized when they were out of line... not what you see in Hollywood Westerns, but likely what was true for the day.  But as the story wears on, it begins to be familiar... where have I heard this story before?  Ahh... one of the oldest stories on the planet... Beowulf!  Aptly done, and I've never seen it done as a Western, so, props all around!

Top notch acting, finely written dialogue that matches the era, and an inventive plot. Don't be swayed by the ridiculous negative reviews, this is a unique film that delivers the goods. Set in the 1890s west, the rescue party must get there before it's too late.

Some folks here are put off by the slow build in the first part of the movie, but it pays off. Other folks are put off by the graphic scenes, but there's no gratuitous violence, it all fits with the story. Every performance is rock solid, of course Kurt Russell is in top form, but Patrick Wilson and Matthew Fox  also do a fine job and fill out a great cast.  The dialogue and the manner of speaking is just as one would imagine from 1890's America, and it's delivered with authenticity and it's fascinating to hear.  The director, S. Craig Zahler, has taken his small budget film and put it all on the screen without any seeming compromise. He has great camera work and the technical aspects are well done.

Be warned, this is not your daddy's John Wayne western, but if you want to see a cowboy and indian movie like you've never seen before, it's worth a try.

Interesting blend of Western and Horror genre.  The plot follows a typical Western, a bad event happens and the posse must save the day.  Good cast and the acting is well done. In spite of my normal feelings about westerns, I enjoyed this one.

Original, totally engrossing, serious acting. I watched this with my wife who does not like gross out horror movies, but despite the movie's explicit violence she could not tear herself away. I highly recommend the movie.

At first a slow-moving, below-average grind which turns into a preposterous, then gut-wrenching horror/western.  I am absolutely shocked at the lack of reaction in the reviews I read to the scenes of physical mutilation in this film.  Obviously that's what the writer/director was after:  something that would make his mark--no matter if it entered the grisly territory of Tarantino Grind-House flicks.  Here's what I'm talking about:  a guy is graphically scalped alive, has his scalp stuffed down his throat, driven in with a spike, and then is held by both legs, splayed upside down, and cleaved in two starting at his genitals.  I don't think Tarantino has managed that trick yet.  Obviously there is a whole clan of people who dig this puke, judging by the reviews.  Some of these people even weigh in on the dialogue, pronouncing it really good.  The dialogue is alternately meandering, pointless, facile and just plain crappy (I'm a screenwriter).  There are all sorts of technical things wrong with this film that brand it an average film-school project.  And let me say one thing about Richard Jenkins, who I don't dislike.  His character is about the most irritating since Jar-Jar Binks--and that's saying something (I was hoping like hell he would get whacked).

There is some tension as we get closer to finding out who the grisly, mute, mystery men are, but its soon lost in really stupid things our protagonists do (like walking down a really narrow passageway right into the hands of the mutes).  The heroine in the film even blames them to their faces: "that's the problem in the West, stupid men like you!"--and she's on their side.

I wish I would have read a review that came down on this film before I gave in to the free movie deal from Prime--I never would have watched it.  There are certain lines that films can cross which make them unviewable for a variety of reasons:  boring, amateurish, not believable, outrageous to one's sensibilities.  This one ticks more than a few boxes.
Great film. Was gritty and dramatic. Very tense story line.

This is a western. The acting is great Kurt Russell is in his element he is truly one of the. Last old school actors from old Hollywood it is worth it the violence is not overdone. Not for anyone under 17 , a very good film:
Best western I've seen in a good while.
this is a very very good western an kurt is at his best they don't make good movies like this anymore. just a little slow but good1!

The movie was good and entertaining once it got to the action part and you started to understand exactly what they were up against. However, it did take a long time for the movie to develop to that point. It would have been good to get more insight into the monster tribe other than just seeing them attack and kill, but it was decent.

I'm a big fan of Kurt Russell's which is why I gave this movie a chance.  I'm glad I did.  It will surprise you with the outcome.  Good actors and actresses.  It moved at a good pace.  It had you rooting for the good guys.  Men who never meant to be a posse go to the rescue of one man's wife, a murderer and a deputy.  There is guts and blood but not over done.  I recommend it.
I enjoyed this movie. Kurt Russel did an outstanding job. Definitely recommend.

Dear Lord what a CRAPPY movie!  So glad I didn't rent it and instead waited for it to show up on prime.  For the realistic sets and dialogue and Kurt Russell's performance I give it two stars.  Unfortunately, KR can't save this turd.  Story is stupid and the ending leading up to is just friggin gross.  I wanted to watch a good western.  What I got was the hills have eyes cowboys and indians style.  No thanks.  What a waste of two hours.

I was excited to see a western with Kurt Russell and Matthew Fox but... the level of violence by showing a man being stripped naked and butchered alive by cannibal natives with  a leader with horns coming out of his face was way over the top and was frankly insulting.  S. Craig Zahler tries to mimic Quintin Tarantino but misses the mark by delivering a slow, and needlessly horrific knockoff.
Great to see Kurt and Sean Young back in action.

I never thought I would live to see the day that a Great Actor like Kurt Russell would stoop So Low as to be part of a disgusting piece of Garbage like this.
This is in no way shape or form entertainment,  and has to be one of the #1 worst movies I have ever seen,  Kurt's father Bing Russell who worked with some of the best actors in Hollywood which included John Wayne and the Great director John Ford would be ashamed that his Son participated in a piece of Rubbish like this.
As for the people who are giving this anything less the one star, alls I can say is they must be investors in this fiasco,  I only wish I could ave giving it NO STAR.
I love Kurt Russell but most of the movie was tedious to watch.  Too slow to tell the story just a poor script.
Good movie, really enjoyed it, a little gruesome toward the end, but so far really good
sick movie

My hubby and I loved this movie.  It's odd, but very compelling.  Kurt Russell was born in the wrong century.  He's fabulous in gunslinger movies.  The cast is richly woven and characters are deep.  There is a lot of humor juxtaposed with gruesome gore.  It's not a fast paced movie until the end, but it's a but well written story.  Watched this on New Year's Day, and really enjoyed the film.  Not a film for kids, though.  Without giving away the plot, I'll say only 3 words to whet your appetite:  kidnapping, troglodytes and cannibalism.  Yikes!
Fantastic movie! A western with great characters and a horrifying edge.
Love Westerns? Then you'll love this film. I did!

Whoa! Was I hallucinating, or was this film indeed the bastard child of "UNFORGIVEN" and THE HILLS HAVE EYES?"  I actually liked this horror-western mash-up, but be warned: it's a bit of a sleeper with the antagonist(s) not making a full appearance until 1:28 into the film. Horror fans may be a bit put off by the meticulously slow build-up, but true fans of westerns will most likely enjoy this 1880's 'road-trip,' where the bulk of the film follows an unlikely posse as they set out to rescue kidnapped members of their town. The last 30 minutes of this production definitely produce enough bite for your buck as to be worth the slow-burn wait. This film is not a stellar classic, but it's definitely worth seeing. If you are fans of either or both of the two films I mentioned in my first sentence, then there will be something here for you.

Starts classic western with small posse looking for savages who kidnapped a few town folk. Then....uuh im sure I never woulda seen the twists coming...almost becomes a horror...then  dark comedy.. I enjoyed the movie immensely.  Like nothing ive seen or heard of. Acting by 4 male leads were perfect. One violent seen will be difficult to watch for many but its relatively short. Definately a very engaging original plot.
I rarely/never write reviews, but this movie sucked so bad, I just had to log on just to click on 1 star.

I'd never heard of this movie til previewing trailers on amazon. It's good to see Kurt Russell in another western. The film starts out fast and never slows down with new twists and turns that keep the watcher intrigued and wonder. Very good film!
a little slow but worth it,deputy was the best
This was a disaster of a western. .would be better as horror movie. Gives westerns a bad name.
Interesting film with good characters and plot. Disturbing and fascinating at the same time. Well worth the the time to watch.
THE weirdest western/horror movie I have ever seen . . .
All I can say is Wow!

CLASSIC WESTERN requires suspension of belief and embracing the many branched DARWINIAN tree.  EVERY actor gives an outstanding performance in this vid.  KURT RUSSELL a consummate life long pro who has been knocking the cover off the ball since his DISNEY youth.
WHAT stands out  is the self sacrifice and quiet heroics displayed by the entire possee.  These are the role models for american heroes.

This movie requires suspension of belief.  But, it aint much of a stretch to imagine a stone age tribe has an evolutionary adaptive communication mechanism.  Charles Darwin  would get a kick out of this flick.

Best flick i have seen lately.  GORE SPOILER ALERT & HU :  Peeps squeamish about vivisection best avoid.

POST SCRIPT 1 DAY LATER: DESTINED to become a CULT CLASSIC- WESTERN/HORROR/ANTHROPOLOGY GENRE

POST POST SCRIPT:  HU sociological issues with " TROGOLODYTE BREEDERS "  : a doctoral thesis  could be written on  this subject.  the horror, grotesqueness, originality gives this cinema  great depth.  No shlock here. This is scripted cinema with real crews and A-LIST ACTORS.  SCI-FI WESTERN HORROR ANTHROPOLOGY ...gotta love it.

P.P.P.S. fans of the LAW-OF THE SEA-CUSTOM OF THE SEA-CANNIBALS OF BORNEO-DONNER PARTY

this flick explores CANNIBALISM WITHIN  HOMEO SAPIENS

FINAL THOUGHTS...in a word..
lastly,  these pre-hisotic stone age cave dwelling troglodytes look like ALPHA  FOOD CHAIN PREDATORS...they are large,jacked,fierce and frightening.  Their make-up camo could be real.  Their butchering of human  live captives  is so real it is nauseating, frightening and grotesquely  true to life.  You have to see it.  Not for the squeamish.
Yup partner it's that good. Great twist on classic western.
Terrific film.  This is a slow burn of a Western with an outstanding cast, terrific cinematography and slow, subtle direction.  This is a film for those who love film.  A great movie.

I don't think this movie was slow-paced, it spent time building suspense. I was sitting on the edge of my seat wondering when the group of men would run into the cannibals. The dialog was excellent, and the pacing perfect. Some viewers apparently thought the female physician should have been screaming her head off or something along those lines when they found her in the cavern. I think her part was written perfectly.
Wish I saw these reviews before I watched. I thought it would great to see Kurt Russell in a Western but the nonsensical story was horrible.
Holy carp, what a boring disgusting pos.  If I was Kurt Russell I would make them take my name off this piece of garbage.
Methodical, chilling, and shocking. Gonna be a cult favorite.
Definitely a different movie, but overall it was a good western style movie.  I recommend.

Reviews for the most part depend on the time the movie is seen and in this case what I saw before this movie. I saw The Hateful 8 the day before I saw this one. 8 was a brutal and violent movie, or so I thought until I saw this one. Bone Tomahawk is a sneaky film. It starts out slowly introducing characters who aren't that interesting to begin with. Next it has a woman kidnapped and a pose goes to get her back. There are two clues that are given in the first part of movie to peak the viewer's interest. For the first time in Western history the word[please excuse my spelling]Troggaladyke is used. What a prehistoric creature in a Western?  The movie then takes its time with the pose going after the woman, so much so, it begins to drag. However when the pose meets the Troggs things go bloody and violent quickly. While 8 was gun shot violent, the violence here goes into the  horror stomach churning variety.  So much so that you find yourself averting your eyes, or in my 25 year old son's case rewinding to see if he saw what he thought he saw. The word rough doesn't even come close to describing the ending violence. It is fair to say  strange or bizarre  are words that come to mind while watching this movie. However the question is; "Is movie worth the time it takes to watch it?"
Well that is a hard one. It boils down to a matter of taste. While Hateful 8 messes with the Western genre,  Bone Tomahawk takes Westerns to very dark and bloody area that it has never been.
Don't waste your money 1hr 1/4  of guys walking in the  wilderness

Not your typical western. Good acting and unusual story line makes very interesting story. Violence
and brutality at end, Not suitable for minors.
It's about resillant character, not the cannibals.  Most amazing female movie role and realistic, flawed but noble males.  Slow paced like good literature.

Bone Tomahawk is a well done Western Horror flick. A bit slow going, but got very brutal toward the end. Great cast and nice scenery too. I like the fact that they used practical effects and no crappy computer effects! Really makes a big difference. If you have Amazon Prime, its currently on there. I would highly recommend. 4/5
We enjoyed this, hadn't seen Kurt Russell in some time. Unusual story line but good. All in all I say if you like westerns you should like this. And has a little mystery to it as well.

If I could give a NEGATIVE 5 stars I would!!!  This is BEYOND A DREADFUL MOVIE.  I have talked to several normal people (non horror film ghouls) who were shocked and disgusted when this film went from western to horror.
My family watched this film thinking it was a Kurt Russell western (My husband is an Oklahoma cowboy who grew up in the western culture) even though it started pretty slow with boring dialog and superfluous scenes we were enduring it.  Then it became so grotesque and perverted that my daughter screamed and left the room.  Now she is haunted with nightmares.  There was no warning that this was a horror film - if there had been a warning we would not have given $8 to support such disgusting iniquitous garbage.  We do not watch horror film that glorify murder as entertaining.

Definitely appreciated the style of this western. It was gory at points, but I'm not sure why people were claiming to run off and throw up in the bathroom etc. Great acting and a pretty decent (original) story. Please keep making stuff like this instead of rebooting/remaking movies I've already seen!

Incredibly sickening and gory cannibal movie....the movie was way too long and boring and then it got to the idiot troglodytes butchering the deputy while he was alive was absolutely sadistic, disgusting, and overboard graphic butchery,...my wife went to vomit in the bathroom and I turned off the movie...Kurt Russell could not save this movie...it went from boring to becoming a graphic splatter film.... I took the dvd and threw it into the trash can afterwards....
I saw Kurt in it, thought I would check it out.  Horrible is the only ' Decent ' thing I can say about it. Sorry Kurt big fan, you should have passed on this........did I say Horrible & Boring.

Original storyline, good acting, great dialogue, and suspenseful. Warning: it is gruesome in parts and you'll probably cover your eyes from time to time. If you're a fan of Kurt Russell, you'll like it.
Kurt Russell in a Western with a mind blowing plot... 5 stars! So authentic, I was covered in dirt and bloold after watching.

OK.... so... this was a western, but not a typical western.  It was somewhat slow paced..... however, it also kept me on the edge of my seat almost the entire movie.  There was at least one scene which I will never be able to erase from my mind.... VERY gruesome.  I'm fairly sure that this is one of those movies which I will see only the one time since it is a disturbing movie.  The acting was very good by all.  I love Kurt Russell and westerns.  Since he was in Tombstone (one of my favorite westerns of all time) I knew he'd be great in another western.  I wasn't disappointed.  I would definitely recommend the movie, but you might want to walk out of the room or fast forward for one scene.... it absolutely turned my stomach....  You have to wonder what kind of demented minds come up with some of this stuff.  In reality, there really could be no rhyme or reason for that particular scene other than to gross people out...  and it did!

Just what the world needs: THE SEARCHERS meets THE HILL HAVE EYES!  A gritty and dark story that builds to a gory, violent climax. Powered by the performances of Kurt Russell, Matthew Fox, Patrick Wilson and Richard Jenkins.  This one won't be for all tastes.  This movie is, I truly believe, destined to be a cult classic.

How is there no feeding frenzy or buzz over this film? It's phenomenal. Everything about it is done perfectly- the acting, the sets, the clothes, costumes, the filming, the sound, the saddlery, guns, makeup, it's all done accurately for the period and persuasively. From start to finish it's one unexpected and gripping scene after another. I super enjoyed this movie after renting it from Red Box. Never heard of it, but seeing Kurt Russell in authentic cowboy get-up on the cover enticed me. Everything about this movie is exceptionally creative and well thought out, and I found it exceptionally entertaining. Who ever heard of the director /writer, Zahner? Why haven't we heard more from this guy? He's very talented. I'd hate to think that creative talent like his is suppressed in Hollywood. Anyhow, five stars, ten out of ten, A+ great movie. Wish I could have seen it on a big screen.

This is got to be the worst western I have ever watched.  Poor story line and crap from outer space.  If you're  a western fan this movie will disappoint you.  Come on.....please someone do a old time western! This is my very first review on anything...thats how much I wish I could get a refund and maybe save you a little cash and time.

Entire waste of time and $5. SLOW and BORING. I have no idea who these people are that rated so highly. I would be inclined to believe they were paid to rate and write such nice reviews. I think it is a scam honesty.
I like Kurt Russell movies.

Great actors, great setting, but a  lack luster premise, weak directing, and a limp script that plods along, begging to be out of its misery. This film relies on gore to make up for its too many shortcomings, but there's not enough blood in the world to wash them away ! I expected much better from Kurt Russel. I guess he's at that age where he has to accept whatever is thrown his way, good, bad, or even ugly.

Extremely bizarre, odd, unique.  Not much of a sound track as emphasis were placed on real sounds like hungry men eating and smacking on their feed.  Deliberately slow moving to create an extremely eerie ambiance. Don't expect a usual Hollywood movie.  The characters are not the usual Hollywood western characters.  They were odd with weird idiosyncrasies which would be what people were really like out in wilderness towns. The cannibal barbarians were a particularly brutal and amoral bunch.  They were sneaky and quiet and suddenly blood and extremities flew.  The end was horrid, which i believe was created to make one imagine the unspeakable cultural devices and brutality in barbarian societies that had once roamed the earth.  SPOILER:  One of the barbarians had an unnatural scream which seemed silly, but then we discover he had sliced his neck to place a sort of instrument and let the flesh grow back over it to make it a permanent part of his body.  Then the monstrous scream made sense.  SPOILER CONTINUED:  The tribe had two females which were baby makers.  They were pregnant, animal tusks had been shoved into their eyes sockets and left their for the flesh to grow over them.  Their legs were amputated to keep them immobilized.  Purely made for procreation for the tribe and their lives were likely very short.
Western Horror?!? Whats not to like? Well written, directed and acted. Spoiler*: Has one of the most brutal scenes of almost any movie.
Very dark original story!

Some of the most false-sounding dialogue you'll ever hear. Unbearable. I give the film--quite generously--one star; and I give myself fifteen stars--one for every minute I suffered through before turning this high-school drama class-level  production off.
Hated it.  Not much else to say about stupid western sci-fi.
Great movie. Came outta nowhere, but wow this was fast, gory, well acted and just plain awesome. Horro and Western movies mixed together - LOVED THIS.

The acting, writing and cinematography of this film is truly outstanding and beautiful.  Kurt Russell and Richard Jenkins have such a natural flow in their scenes.  In fact, the entire cast was exceptional.  Some of the scenes may have seemed slow and drawn out to some, but I found them to be crucial and brilliant in developing the characters.  (ie:  Patrick Wilson slowly peeling his boots off -- I could almost feel his pain!)  However, I do wish the later canibbal scene was not permanently etched in my mind.  It is seriously disturbing, and I didn't think the horrific detail added to the film.  Also, the final scene was rushed and disappointing, although I was so emotionally drained by that point I was relieved it was over.
Truly one of the worst films I've seen. Stopped watching about mid-way. The Hills Have Eyes gone western..only The Hills Have Eyes has merit as a cult classic..kind of.
Kurt Russell I liked but the movie was bloody as all get out

It's hard to describe exactly what genre this movie is. I downloaded one day when I was off work just to have something to watch and now one of the favorite movies I've seen in a while. I recommended it to a friend and then he's recommended it to several people. So far everyone has loved it. I guess it's a "small" independent film but packs a punch. I don't want to give away the plot but it is extremely action packed and suspenseful throughout. Can't recommend highly enough. I downloaded watched it twice back to back which I never do, then downloaded again when I had company. I'll probably download or buy it is so good.

A must watch. Tomahawk is the second best horror movie of the year and the best western of the year. I never believed those two genres would co-habituate so effectively. Kurt Russell leaves a lasting impression with his amazing performance as a die hard western sheriff. The Dialogue is witty and the action has a brutal realistic tone. I would recommend this film to anyone who is okay with graphic content and frightening atmospheric story telling.
Not too action-packed, but very tense movie. It's full of suffering, pain, fear and heroism which are well conveyed to the viewer.
one of the better done movies in years; just hard to watch at times.
Not your usual kind of Western, but I thought it was quite good. Especially the cinematography and dialogue.

Not bad for a low budget film.  Have to wonder how they paid such a great cast.  Even had Shanzee the Indian from Fargo season 2 although a small part.

Just don't watch it before your Christmas dinner.  If you do, you'll  probably not want to pull that leg or thigh off the Turkey.  Watch it and you'll understand.

This is one of those times when I think I must have watched a different movie than most of the critics did. I think writer-director Zahler was going for a clever, grotesquely satirical horror-Western like "Ravenous." But I don't think he got all the way. It's not quite clever or satirical enough, and when it starts to get really grotesque about two-thirds of the way in -- after a rather slow and tedious sag in the middle --  it felt gratuitous and a little desperate to me. It looks great, and you can't fault the actors, who play it all very straight and convincingly. Richard Jenkins is especially fine in a different kind of role for him. I just think the material let them down a bit. It's good, and worth seeing if you're into cult horror and can stomach some gross doings and some ridiculous ones, but it's not as good as I was led to believe
very weird movie, First Kurt Russel movie I did not love. Not his fault he acted great, very strange story line.
This movie is a bad dream you'd have after eating a bad piece of meat at a Chuck Wagon themed restaurant then eating magic mushrooms and watching "True Grit".
Unique. A must see. Western classic. Great actors. Great gift. Action, violence, warning.

Western-Horror, sort of like a Zombie-Comedy in the bizarre genre of films.  Aside from that, I felt it was ok and these were top actors in their day, but it seemed like they did it for some extra retirement coin and the story was too predictable and the ending was a little vague, not to mention you the Native American Professor who could have possibly got help from local tribes, as he did not seem to be a gentleman for tracking, etc. I do recall another strapping young man that was concerned only for his horses, his butt should have gone along too!! Too many flaws in the film, too much graphic gore and blood, pushing the shock value instead of better storyline.  I'm not a director, nor should I be, as only I would like my films!!  I think this had great potential to be a very good film, but fell short somewhere in between the beginning and the end. oh, and the dynamite, what about the dynamite? why did they leave that out? That would have been a great ending, blow up the cave, kill off all of those animals, plus I would have put a couple bullets in the pregnant ones on the way out, just to be sure and for spite!!

It is really good to see Kurt Russell's return to solid filmmaking with not one - but two big western movies! I look forward to seeing The Hateful Eight this Christmas, but until then, I satiated my western hunger with Bone tomahawk. A surprisingly solid scripted western with a twist of horror. With a solid cast, Bone tomahawk could have been easily forgotten in cheesy B-movie history.
  But writer/director made an interesting quest movie that even the likes of Edgar Rice Burroughs would have written back in the day.
interesting movie!

Not for the faint of heart. As many have said, I watched this movie because it was a western with Kurt Russel cast as the protagonist. It did not disappoint. This movie really boils down to honorable men doing what they are supposed to do when things go bump in the night. The dialogue, character development and acting was top notch. Everyone brought their "A" game.

This movie received my highest possible rating for this type of show. I reserve my 5 star rating for movies I can watch comfortably with my parents, like Legends of the Fall or Last of the Mohicans. This movie had some uncomfortable moments. If you are parent I  urge you to watch this alone prior to exposing children, of any age, to it.
Western gone weird

Brutal being the key word.

Well done all the way round. Beautiful photography, and some scenes WILL be hard to take, but the authenticity bleeds throughout this work.

Fantastic!

There is no "genre" that defines this film, and that makes it all the more delicious.

Mostly, though, it isn't a film to "take seriously."  It was made to be fun, ridiculous, over-the-top.  In one way it seems to move slowly, until you realize that each step is like a fine meal, to be leisurely enjoyed.

When you finish the film, don't turn it off without going through the credits.  And listening.

This film cost little to make, and it shows that there is still a lot of creative genius out there.

..but this movie is surely one of the worst I know. The plot follows, friendly speaking, "conventional lines": cannibalistic "savages" kill more or less innocent settlers, a husband on his literally last leg tries to save his wife and succeeds, in the end all bad people are dead.
And don't get me started about the very nasty "tasty human meat" scene near the end - you really don't want your children to see that, neither is it the funny "Quentin Tarantino" type of killing.
While there're indeed not many good westerns today - stay away.
It was okay.
I really enjoyed this movie. Superb casting.

Creepy and riveting. Russell nailed his role (as usual) in this great film. Entire cast melted into the characters they played, and the cinematography drove the rest for me. Darker than most "cowboy" films, and well worth the watch.

Watched it because of Kurt Russell.  Disappointed by how long and drawn out the film was in addition to the hokey communication method of the cannibals.  I give it three stars...two of which for Kurt, one for the interesting and original kills.  Would not recommend unless you just skip to about the last 35 or so minutes.

I'll watch about anything and it doesn't take much for me to call it entertaining - probably why I don't write reviews.  This movie was horrible.  So much so that I wish i could erase it from my memory and get the time back i spent watching it.  The gore scenes were over-the-top and completely unnecessary. They didn't add anything to the plot - mainly because there wasn't a plot.  I watched mainly because of Kurt Russell but sorry Kurt, should have stayed away from this one.  Don't waste your time.
If you are tired of clichs then this is the movie for you. It is mature and steady.
Not your typical western. The acting was great, the suspense was intense the story was pretty straight forward but very well told. I loved it.
Good action Western movie.

Pretty good! Not a bad script, and the acting is acceptable. A mix of Treasure of the Sierra Madres with a touch of Pale Rider. There was only one small scene that pulled "C'mon" outta me, but other than that. Spend the time watching this one.
It was okay since it has been a long time since Kurt Russell made a Western. Guess I hoped for more. Not many westerns come along so at least it was nice to have something.
Not your average western. Slow at times and surprisingly gruesome scenes. Kept me up at night.
Ok

Great film, but you have got to be kidding me with this TERRIBLE streaming you've got here. It plays for about three minutes and then has to buffer. I have 30 mbps and Netflix, Hulu, and HBOGO all run without a hitch or buffering. So why, when I pay money to watch a film streaming from your site does this happen? Get it together.

Great characters. Great performances. Great direction. Simple but compelling story.
If you enjoy a good classic western (with the addition of one particularly gruesome scene), this is in your wheelhouse.
Wow, wasn't ready for that. Good movie, a but slow at times but stick with it. And the ending gets a bit dark so not for children.
Good movie.

A decent movie with potential. Nothing too over the top too often, but not much in terms of building characters that I care too much about. the only guy with any general sense of interest was Brooder. He spoke as flat as paper but was the only guy who really had any sense for the mission they had to embark on. Kurt Russell's character just made a lot of bad decisions for a sheriff, and the old man was too caught in tradition for right and wrong.

*POTENTIAL SPOILERS*

They just made too many little mistakes, no alternating shifts when sleeping, no one is ever watching their surroundings during exchanges, and the one thing they do take from their enemy was somehow taken before deciding to take their weapon? It just didn't sit well with me.

I suppose the natives were still being learned about so they tried too much to match western culture politics with native guerrilla savagery and it just really didn't work out too well.

It had the potential to be really good, just marred by really in character decisions.
Different kind of movie western. A little modern horror flick type stuff thrown into the mix. Kurt Russell makes a great cowboy actor and personality.
Dumb, Dumb, Dumb. What was Kurt Russell thinking??
This movie sucks. It's basically about them walking around in the desert. And the one scene is horrible.

This is a Western fantasy, not quite horror, although it involves situations very close to it.  Don't expect to be scared at any time watching it, though: indeed, you may be bored.  The film is very slow with a lightweight plot and some ridiculous dialogue and situations, but what saves it is the lead acting, especially from Kurt Russell.  For fans of Westerns, or Horror, I would recommend avoid, and because the film is so insubstantial, I would advise even Russell fans to miss it, unfortunately.

This is a great little movie. It's slow, but character driven, we stayed engaged all the way through the trek, then the violence starts, and wow, it gets lovingly fast and brutal quickly. While I think more time could have been spent developing the lore of the tribe, especially given the Carpenter-esque feel to them, it was oddly fitting you know so little about them. They kept to themselves, no one knew who or what they were, then they were provoked, there was hell to pay, then it was over. Feels very much like an actual life event in that way.
Got to like cowboy stuff....not realistic

This movie took forever to even get anywhere and once it did it was very graphic and I almost threw up! Kinda disappointed I wasted my money on this movie. That is what I get for letting my boyfriend pick it out.
Just weird

I liked it! A bit weird for a western, but I enjoyed it because is was a nontraditional story of cannibal Indians in the west. More like caveman slash mother-earth kind of throwback mixed into a western.
This is one different kind of western!
This was a good movie, but we did not care for the graphic torture scene in the cave in this movie. The movie could have been a 5 star movie, but this part ruined that for me.

This was not really what I expected. It is mostly a long desperate struggle between characters. I love westerns, but this one is quite unusual. At first it is slow, and then it gets slower. I do like the backup deputy, and his ramblings are somewhat entertaining. You can tell that trouble is coming, but in this movie it drags a bit until it gets there. This is probably more true to form as to what the west was really like before civilization moved in, but its brutality is unmistakable.

If you love westerns and horror you are gonna love this movie! Haven't seen a movie this good, ground breaking, and different in a long time!  Can't wait to own this. Acting was great. Kurt Russell, as always plays a great badass! Great performances all around, Patrick Wilson, and Richard Jenkins.
Gross, disturbing, and boring
Good
A really surprising movie. It feels like a campy B horror movie a gritty western mashed together. Some how it works well. Definitely worth a watch.

Hubby and I love westerns and were intrigued with the description of this movie. It starts out slow as the saga develops - then it just gets weird, very weird, sci-fi weird and then very graphic and very gross. Definitely not your typical western. I'd give it one star but I did like where the movie was heading until it became ridiculous.
Over the top with graphic scenes. Very disturbing
Slow movie with weird dialog but at times suspenseful / just really slow to watch and then a very grotesque scene with Cannibals -a one time movie or pass on it unless you just have to see it.

I kept passing this gem up until my son watched it with me.
Reminds me of "The Missing"  ( the scary snake man ) meets " Hills have eyes" .
Very creative & very enjoyable & gets very tense.
It's now on my "to own" list. Enjoy.

I'm a fan of a good western tale. This movie delivers that in spades. The cast was perfect; apparently someone was doing their homework here. The writing and direction - superb. Some reviewers here say the pacing was slow? Does every movie need to be packed frame by frame with wall to wall action. If you look at the broader strokes done here, you'll appreciate it more. It's beautifully shot. That guy deserves an award. The snappy dialogue and comraderie here with this killer ensemble cast is where it shines.

Now folks say here it's a "horror" movie. I disagree. Think "dark thriller". It's violent the way war is violent, but I think in the context of the story it's more of an accent piece. Disturbing and pulpy at moments, It's not for the squeamish. Keep an open mind. This isn't Rio Lobo, but man is it absorbing.

Would love to see the 4 main actors in more quality westerns. Here's to hoping the director makes more films!

"We're here for a rescue, not a massacre." Arthur O'Dwyer is trying to make a living in a small western town with his wife. When a stranger comes into town something seems off, and when Arthur's wife is kidnapped there is only one suspect. He enlists the help of Sheriff Franklin Hunt (Russell) and they set off, but when the truth of the identity of the captors comes out things become more dangerous then imagined. The western genre lately has taken a dive. What was once the pinnacle with stars like John Wayne has turned into cheesy B-rate made for TV garbage that is hard to watch. This movie is an exception. This is one of the better westerns in a long time, and it does have some little horror aspects thrown in to spice it up. The movie is really just another hunt and chase film but it had something extra that made it seem exciting and kept me watching all the way to the end wanting to see what happens next. The only real downside of this movie is that it is a little slow moving, but the deliberate pacing actually adds to the tension and helps the movie out. Overall, one of the best westerns in many years, and Kurt Russell is back to form in this one. I give it a B.

One of the more intense movies I've seen this year, Bone Tomahawk delivers in storytelling, acting, cinematography and gore. I've always been a fan of stories pitting main characters in thrilling situations, especially when the characters are ones I care for. In this film, I quickly became attached to our four main heroes. The actors portrayed them very well. While all four performances standout, I have to give credit to Matthew Fox.

His character is probably the most mysterious of the four, and receives the least amount of screen time, but Fox delivered one helluva performance.

All in all, Bone Tomahawk was a thrilling ride, and probably delivers one of the more gruesome death scenes I've ever seen.

I have been a fan of horror movies my entire life and I have never seen one with a death scene like the one in Bone Tomahawk. The acting of the leading men is fantastic, especially Matthew Fox. I didn't even realize that was him until near the end. Although it's a bit slow in places, it more than makes up for it once the action comes. I'm on board to see any Western with Kurt Russell (and his mustache) in it and he didn't disappoint in this. If you're into Westerns I think you'll enjoy it. Just be warned it is graphically violent and not a typical Western. I'd say it is more realistic than anything, which for the time meant brutality. My boyfriend and I both liked it a lot, but it's not for everyone.
Wow! I don't want to give anything away, but I loved this mixing of genres. Worth seeing just to watch Russell in another great western.

Doesn't matter if you love it or hate it, you won't forget it anytime soon. I'm on the love it side of the isle. Original dialogue, direction and perfect casting featuring Russell and Jenkins at the top of their game. The monsters in this western horror film will not leave your memory for quite some time. NOT for the squeamish.

I have never been a huge fan of westerns but I am certainly warming up to them. I do however love horror movies. This was one of the best I've seen. It's also now my second favorite Kurt Russel movie (John Carpenter's The Thing being first). Bone Tomahawk is a revenge tale about four guys going out after Patrick Wilson's character's wife who has been kidnapped by a cannibalistic tribe of indians. The acting is superb across the board, with Richard Jenkins standing out as a doctor missing a few bolts. He's great comic relief. This movie is equal parts western and horror with enough humor to make it campy. It has some sparse but extremely gruesome violence to please horror fans and stays true enough to the time period in which it takes place to please western fans as well. It is a slow burn but watching all four main actors perform so admirably makes the wait for the bloodletting worth every second. I loved it.

Bone Tomahawk is a hybrid western and horror film. The story is about a Sheriff, his "second" deputy, a doctor, and a gentleman/Indian killer who track down the doctor's wife, a deputy, and a jailed murderer - who were kidnapped by cannibals who live in a remote part of the west. The story is interesting but very slow moving at parts. There is a lot of gruesome violence so this movie is not for the faint of heart. This movie does make you think. The cannibal tribe is extremely odd, but certainly possible given the diversity of human behavior. The acting is terrific and in my opinion the "second deputy" steals the show, but Kurt Russell and all the other actors deliver solid performances. If you like movies like this you might try Johnny Depp's "Dead Man", which is another very dark Western.

This is an old-fashioned movie. Its slow, patient and careful. The writing and plot is simple but elegant. The performances are restrained and subtle, yet cool and powerful too. The entire affair is always marching towards the big finish with skillfully built tension and mystery. Impatient viewers of modern films  especially those expecting a wild action-horror film  will be sorely disappointed with this film. But fans of traditional westerns who can appreciate a slow-burning build will definitely enjoy. Every actor in this film is often underrated and underappreciated elsewhere, but they all turn in sterling performances here.

The action is expertly framed with a clear sense of space and direction. The arrows can always be clearly seen as they are fired all the way to where they land, a very simple but novel trick compared to modern FX-heavy films. The violence and gore are very limited, but its explosive bursts are all very well done. There is one gruesome sequence that is arguably one of the most extreme acts ever recorded on film, yet it is still handled with class and services the overall plot.

But if a viewer can settle in for the ride, enjoys their time with the colorful heroes, they will take a hard and strange journey to a fun and frightening conclusion.

I do not write a lot of reviews but I had to put in a good word for this little western gem.  Bone Tomahawk is an adult, spooky, violent western type horror movie that really takes me back to when movies were enjoyable.  It has a simple set up: lady gets abducted - posse sets out to find her, but what makes this movie so great is the small things.  Richard Jenkins is absolutely outstanding (seriously...academy), Russell is always great, and Patrick Wilson and Matthew Fox deliver fantastic supporting roles.  The screenwriting is witty and true and you never feel like you are left outside of the loop.  In a world where superhero movies seem to kill all the enjoyment out of film this movie will take you back.  It's constantly violent, original, and vivid in its storytelling.  Nothing suits this movie more than a bucket of popcorn and your couch.  Whatever Amazon is charging to rent this film you should happily pay the price and enjoy a night in...a...story instead of CGI wonderment-battle-earth-is-going-to-die-again crap that seems to just take over the film industry these days.  If you want a great story, great acting, great writing, and great cinematography go ahead and look to the top right of the page and click the link that allows you to purchase/rent this wonderful film.  This movie will be on my dvd shelf right next to Tombstone, Unforgiving, and Open Range.  If you love westerns, for whatever reason, this is going to be at the top of a very short list.  Tell the kids to go to bed early and enjoy being an adult in a world of PG13 crap.  Enjoy!
Awesome movie!

I'm old enough to have seen True Grit at the drive-in, recalling the excited anticipation as the trio of Rooster Cogburn, Ranger La Boeuf and Mattie Ross trot into the wilds of the Indian territories to track dangerous killers. The unlikely 2015 western/horror film "Bone Tomahawk" has a similar expedition, as a quartet of mismatched men reluctantly travel into mysterious worlds to rescue family and friends. But where these men travel is far more nightmarish than anything imagined in the beloved John Wayne epic. For me, "Bone Tomahawk" is a demented, brilliant film with "Cult" written all over it. If John Carpenter ever made that western he had talked about for so many years, I would like to think it would have been something like this. Critics have made comparisons to John Ford's The Searchers [Blu-ray]. I saw nods to Howard Hawks' Rio Bravo [Blu-ray] and El Dorado (1966) (BD) [Blu-ray] myself, with a less-than-intimidating quartet facing frightening odds. Richard Jenkins is a wonder as usual in the Walter Brennan-like role of Chicory. Kurt Russell, as Sheriff Franklin Hunt, is of course the sturdy Wayne. Patrick Wilson is perhaps the handicapped, love-struck characters played by Dean Martin or Robert Mitchum? And Matthew Fox gives the best performance of his career as the well-groomed gunfighter. Surprisingly, this is a character-driven story with the dialogue poetic and the pace gentle. I loved camping with these men, and I would not cut a single minute from this two-plus hour journey so reliant on mood. I'm convinced we should not take "Bone Tomahawk" at face value. As we see from a glimpse of a tombstone, it takes place in 1891, and for anyone who knows their history such Native American threats as displayed in this film had long ago come to an end. "Bone Tomahawk" has a quirky, supernatural aura as these men travel into unknown worlds with an uncomfortable sense of doom. I wasn't sure what the ending would be as they stumbled towards this Valley of Death. These four men are riding to the rescue of souls kidnapped from their small town by an unknown tribe of demonic, cannibalistic, cave-dwelling Indians. There's a nasty scene, more violent than anything in The Walking Dead: Season 1, that almost capsizes the work. But I think it added to the surprise of the conclusion. "Bone Tomahawk," is the debut of writer/director S. Craig Zahler, an author (Wraiths of the Broken Land) and musician with a mesmerizing ability with dialogue. There are lines so fiercely original as to be euphoric. Zahler has given us an inspired combination of western/horror, and what a joy to discover such a creative work. Not only do I have a new favorite director, but I have seen one of the best films of 2015.
Awesome film!! Kurt Russell is a western badass!!

The Western is arguably the most American of all genres. It's where we get our definition of a "tough guy hero" from one; we imagine John Wayne's swagger and quick hand on the trigger. While the genre has gone through some lean periods, the last couple of years have seen a revival of sorts. In 2015 alone there have been multiple films taking audiences to the dangerous, dusty Old West. Later this year Quentin Tarantino will follow up his Django Unchained with another Western, The Hateful Eight, but his star Kurt Russell has saddled up for the equally violent and awesomely-titled Bone Tomahawk, which is also worth checking out despite a few pacing issues.

Directed by author S. Craig Zahler, Bone Tomhawk isn't your typical Western, although it sticks to the straight-line structure most of those films have. As the name suggests it's very much a horror, too, and one that goes for maximum gore factor rather than scares. Russell stars as small-town Sheriff Franklin Hunt who gathers up a posse to locate missing doctor Samantha O'Dwyer (Lili Simmons) and a petty outlaw (David Arquette) after they've been kidnapped by cannibalistic "troglodytes". Along for the journey is a motley crew that includes Samantha's injured husband Arthur (Patrick Wilson), old deputy Chicory (Richard Jenkins, a scene-stealer), and brash gunslinger John Brooker (Matthew Fox).

So there's quite the tremendous cast here, and Zahler gets the best from them all, giving them space to acclimate to the gradual rhythms of the genre.  There isn't a ton of violence but when it happens it's brutal, stomach-churning stuff involving arrows and hatchets and things that tear people limb from limb. One especially nasty mutilation later may be the grossest kill anyone will see on screen this year. To describe it would be to spoil it, and audiences deserve to discover that queasy moment for themselves. What's most interesting is how easily the film explores male identity and masculinity, trademark themes of the Old West, while successfully embracing horror elements. Zahler mixes in a good deal of dark gallows humor, usually told by the great Richard Jenkins, and the dialogue has a surprisingly theatrical, Shakespearean flair that is always engaging.

The deliberate pacing becomes an issue with the 2-hour plus runtime, and the drab, dust-covered locale doesn't help. There's also the sense that more could have been done with Russell's character, who is basically a one-note rawhide cowboy with little else to offer. Other than Jenkins it's Wilson who fares the best, once again playing the guy who is masculine in appearance but lacking in intestinal fortitude. It's what he does and he's good at it. Bone Tomahawk may be too much of a slow burn, overall, but there's a very specific audience out there who are going to love the way it combines Westerns and horror while respecting them both.
