"Bone Tomahawk" director/writer S. Craig Zahler takes a no nonsense approach to his western horror story. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't. The writing is taunt with solid dialog while the direction is languid allowing the tension to arise, not out of rapid editing, but the characters and their mission which they know will likely end one way.

The major issues with the film has to do with pacing and the low budget of the film. While he's pulled together a stellar cast, the town is woefully under populated for a film set in the old west. There's a lot of good here including terrific performances which elevates the film even through some poorly staging by first time (well he did direct a short before but this is S. Craig Zahler's first major motion picture).

I can see why the script circulated and was considered one of the best unproduced screenplays but the film could use stronger direction. Those looking for a wham bam horror flick will be disappointed. Those looking for a strong traditional western will also be disappointed.

SPOILERS:

After robbers stumble on the hidden and sacred burial ground of a tribe of Indians, they are followed back to a small town fierce cannibal Indians--a lost tribe--and they kidnap the locals. The town sheriff (Kurt Russell) takes a posse including his deputy (Richard Jenkins) the doctor's husband ( Patrick Wilson) and athe town dandy (Matthew Fox), who is much more than he appears to be, to retrieve kidnapped locals including the town doctor (Lilli Simmons) before they are eaten.

END OF SPOILERS

One of the most successful aspects of the film is the brilliant casting. Everyone works well in their roles bringing an authentic feel to their characters. Keep in mind this is a movie that build slowly but when it does reach its explosive conclusion it is an effective payoff. Genre blending has become a common way to revive genres exhausted by over exploitation. "B" movies have been given "A" budgets and become blockbusters. I'm not against that mind you as long as they are creative, interesting and there's still room for smaller dramas. "Now Tomahawk" does all three surprising well. The smaller dramatic moments happens as our rescue party tracks the cannibal Indians but don't expect an action packed big budget horror movie. "Bone" works best in its quieter and intense moments. This westhorror (yep I made up a silly word for this genre mishmash) has a sense of dread as an undercurrent feeling throughout the film but doesn't always work due to some slack direction and uncertain pacing from a first time director.

The Blu-ray looks quite nice with a solid transfer. Detail is extremely good here. Audio is also quite strong with a nice 5.1 mix that adds atmosphere to the film.

The special features are skimpy at best. I was hoping and expecting a commentary from the director and the cast. We don't get it. We do get a Q&A session with the director and cast from Fantastic Fest where the film was presented to strong praise. We also get a single deleted scenescene, a making of featurette and image gallery. It's very disappointing considering WHAT could have been done here. It would have been nice to also see a featurette focusing on how the film got bounced with high praise from script readers and studios but production stalling.

Is "Bone Tomahawk" a great movie? Nope. It is, however, a good hybrid feature film with terrific casting, strong writing but the film could have used a stronger editor and director.

This movie is sometimes hilariously bad. It is too bad because the trailer and premise looked like it could have been really good. It looked like it could have been a gritty, realistic, yet poetic movie about the Old West. I was hoping that it would update and innovate the Western the way that "Unforgiven" did in the early '90s. However, what is left out of the trailer is the fact that this is a sometimes absurd horror movie infused with a Western. It also took that surreal twist of being a slasher flick/comedy. I've never really understood why, but many horror films punctuate their slasher gore-fest with weird and surprising moments of comedy. I've never really gotten that, as the two emotions don't really seem to mix. Like we're laughing along, and all of a sudden someone gets their leg chopped off. It's like "Uh......ok." I never understood the tone shift, and can't understand how anyone else would either.

I'm not sure this movie is worth the ink, but for what it's worth, I'll explain it: A mysterious tribe of pre-Native American people live in the wilderness beyond the edge of civilization in the wild west. A couple of vagabond bandits wander into their territory, disrespecting their burial grounds. One is killed. The other survives, and treks back to a small, unsuspecting Western town. Living a life of robbing people and moving on, he is found out by the sheriff. He tries to escape, but is shot. A female doctor attends to his wounded leg, but in the night, she, the bandit, and a deputy are tracked by the hostile tribe, abducted, and brought back to their primitive village. The sheriff, his assistant, the doctor's husband, and a local townsman who is assisting them take off into the desert to try to track and find the natives and their victims.

The bottom line is this: if millions of dollars are being thrown around, and people are taking movies so seriously, they need to be way better than this. I get the strong feeling that the writer/director Crag Zahler was really just having fun, but at the end of the day, this movie feels like a friend just pulling a stupid prank on you. He's the only one laughing at the end of the day. The audience is not. That is just to explain the tone shifts, the gore, and overall premise. To be honest, there were actually a few scenes in there that got me laughing. The piece de resistance had to be the old man's soliloquy at the end about the flea circus. What is really odd is that writer-director Craig Zahler really seems like an intelligent guy who really researched the 1800s and its dialogue thoroughly, and got the historical aspects just right. All to throw it away on a zany slasher flick. The cast was also reasonably talented: Patrick Wilson can be awesome, as he was in "The A-Team," and Matthew Fox was surprisingly good as a somber cowboy. There are also a sprinkling of good acting jobs throughout, but it was all crumpled up and thrown away on a ridiculously stupid plot.

At the end of the day, I'm not really mad at this movie, I see that writer-director Craig Zahler was just having fun. It's just that the movie is mostly four guys trudging through the desert for way too long, punctuated by moments of brainless gore and the occasional "pretty funny" joke. The funny jokes take up about 20% of this movie, though, and the rest is a throwaway. Like I said, it's like a friend pulling a stupid stunt on you, and you're standing there smiling because he's laughing, but you're not laughing yourself. Overall, I sort of smile at this movie because I see the author's intent, but I really kind of wish I had my money and my two hours back.

Ambitious but only halfway successful western about a posse that is formed to try and save a several people who were abducted from town by a cannibalistic tribe of cave dwellers referred to as "troglodytes" by the town's lone Indian who insists who insists the perpetrators aren't Indians at all (they have no name or language) and that the white men wouldn't be able to distinguish them from Indians (he's wrong there--they look more like the tribe from Cannibal Holocaust than anything you would normally see in a western).

This starts off promisingly with a creepy opening scene featuring Sid Haig and David Arquette as violent bushwhackers who cut men's throats while they sleep and steal anything of value.  Unfortunately for them while running from the sounds of what might be a pursuing posse they wander into something a whole lot worse.

Early on the intelligent dialogue and smart characters make Bone Tomahawk unusually pleasing but writer/director S Craig Zahler has no idea how to generate any tension in the middle section of the film as his (mostly) doomed possess travel closer and closer to their ultimate destination.  Bone Tomahawk ultimately becomes a bit of a drag until the cowboys finally meet up with the cannibalistic tribe, with reasonably unpredictable but predictably violent results.

While the last section of the film is no Cannibal Holocaust in terms of graphic violence it still might be a bit much for some viewers more accustomed to what you might see in old-fashioned westerns, so consider yourself warned.

The cast is very good.  Kurt Russell is already a veteran of the genre so it's not exactly a surprise that he fits in so well, but Patrick Wilson, Richard Jenkins, Matthew Fox and David Arquette all provide memorable turns.  Bone Tomahawk is also unusually handsome for a non-theatrical release western.  While low budget westerns were a staple of old Hollywood right up until the peak of the spaghetti western the latest crop of straight-to-video westerns simply don't look right since they are clearly shot on digital video, giving them an overly crisp "modern" look that feels completely wrong for the genre.  Bone Tomahawk looks like a real western and even features the kind of song over the end credits that would have played at the beginning in an earlier era when the western was king.

But Bone Tomahawk is ultimately more of a nice try than an actual success, attempting to mix some smart Deadwood style banter and a dollop of modern violence into what frequently feels like an homage to classic westerns from the 1950's, with Kurt Russell in the John Wayne role and Patrick Wilson in the Jimmy Stewart part.  It should please fans of the genre who don't mind a little violence but isn't likely to make people who don't like westerns much change their minds.  It also doesn't transcend the genre like Wesley Snipe's underrated Gallowwalkers (2012), which more effectively blended horror and western into something different.  Bone Tomahawk never quite seems willing to push its horror elements far enough to make much of an impression, which is too bad because a creepier Bone Tomahawk likely would have been a lot more interesting.
Wonderful movie. Writing was terrific. It's a little intense, and gory. But the story is compelling, as are the characters.

I enjoyed this movie. I've seen it categorized as a horror and it runs at just over 2 hours, but don't expect 2 hours of the supernatural or blood and gore throughout. The opening of the movie sets the tone for what's to come, so the viewer is aware of what level of gore to expect. The second act contains mostly the journey of the four protagonists full of dialogue and dynamic sound. I found most of the suspense to come from anticipation of encountering the "monsters." Some people have found this movie to be slow, but I believe that feeling came from the director's choice for the actors to take their time which evokes more realism.
Kurt Russell! Movie was good and i enjoyed it!

I can appreciate the real to life portrayal of the old west and hard times captured in this movie.  Really incredible cinematography. I believe that the cannibal characters were a bit off mark, I was expecting some ritualistic native americans that were on the war path and less org like.  Perhaps it's due to the fact that I watch too many zombies movies. Great to see Kurt Russell back at his gift. He's a bit softer now and as handsome as ever. If your looking for more on tim he's featured in this months Cowboys and Indians magazine.
Love Kurt Russell but the movie was very B rated.

This is one of the worst western movies Ive ever seen because of the following reasons:

Many scenes look like they are not connected with each other.  For example, during the first five minutes, something deadly happens to one of the two robbers. The next 40 minutes show 2 scenes. One is a man with a broken leg and his wife in his home. The other is the sheriff talking to a man in his office and then to people in a bar. I see no connection between these scenes for approximately 45 minutes!

The film is 2 hours and 12 minutes long (imdb.com). No wonder its dragging and dragging. For instance, from my comment above, from the 6th minute to the 45th minute, the characters just talk and talk. There is no suspense or action during this time. According to imdb dot com, its estimated budget is 1.8 million dollars and it shows.

I love Kurt Russell in many other pictures but he can't save this one.

Every actor in this movie was amazing. The arguably slow build up to the climax of the movie was actually the most entertaining part. Four completely different men with nothing to lose take an ominous journey to find and rescue several people from, quite possibly, the most deranged and terrifying group of savage cannibals ever portrayed in movie history. Had me jumping and on the edge of my seat the whole time. Also had me nearly vomiting and in-shock during one scene. All the same though, great flick.

P.S. the girl was definitely worth the the watch alone, what a babe.

The story is interesting and engaging. The acting was excellent. The sets, props and locations were appropriate for the setting and authentic looking. The action sequences were terrific. Editing was a little rough, but the film worked. The story became ever more interesting and fraught with danger, then the last fifteen minutes, or so, were very badly done. It ruined the movie.
Without being too much of a spoiler, once the remains of the posse arrive at the location where the hostages are being held, the whole thing falls apart. Where the antagonists have been portrayed as an interesting and possibly frightening mix of diabolically evil people, primitive to the point of being cave dwelling troglodytes, at the end, the characters, sets, props, and situation become more silly than an old Tarzan serial movie.

If anything, I actually would have enjoyed a bit more character building along the characters' journey to  their foreboding destination. Although the cannibals served as a vague but ever-approaching menace for most of the movie, when they did get more screen time they were both terrifying and grotesque. I certainly feel that the positive reviews I read about this movie were spot-on and well-warranted.

Yes, before you read this, I know this was a "fairy tale" of western lore but... Seriously?! What a dichotomy of talent and artfulness... first of all, the set design, costuming, dialogue and delivery of same, along with the characters' interactions were all top-notch. So, why only two stars? The troglodytes!!! They are describes by the native American who knows the word troglodytes but claims they are just inbred cannibals who rape and butcher and eat their mothers and live in a remote cave that, as we find out, is so far off the beaten path that heretofore, no one has known of their existence and, yet, they have plenty of unwilling victims to fall prey to their cannibalistic ways.

As to the representation of the trogs themselves... they are very healthy in appearance having an abundance of body fat, not obese but well-rounded. Ever see a human that has lived primarily if not solely on meat? They ain't fat! (Ain't used for emphasis) and, as to being inbred that's a bit hard to do when you eat your own mothers! Obviously the pregnant women we see are young, well-nourished, and, if they are "sisters" then we are at the end of the trail for this little clan of cannibalistic misfits.

Second of all, the rescuers rely on a string with tin cans to "guard their camp" and then ALL of them trundle off to beddie-bye? What a load of crap! I have horse packed in the Wyoming mountains for thirty years and, if in grizzly country, I damn sure make certain that one of us two-legged critters is awake at all times. So much for the "raid"!

Mr. Russell must have been really hard up for some cash is all I can imagine!

It was an amazingly well done movie.  It bent over backwards to try to be authentic in look and feel and detail, and use the language of the times.  For that reason it sometimes felt like a play or even reading a period piece.  The actors where fantastic.  The dialogue clever--although the women's roles were the least well written.  It did slow down a bit at the end, but I was not ready for it to be over.  I cared about the characters.  Everyone associated with the film should be proud.  I'll watch it again.

Wow.  What a terrific old-fashioned Western romp!  It's like Deadwood meets Walking Dead, with Kurt Russell as the cool-headed, wizened sheriff.  Acting and directing were excellent, script was crisp and intelligent.  Plot is about as wild as "Cowboys & Aliens", except much more realistic and plausible.  Gave me lots of thrills and shudders.  Like I said, a good ol' fashioned Western with a previously unexplored angle.  It works!  Get some popcorn and get ready for fun!

I thought for a time over a three or four star rating and finally settled on three. Here's why: The story is good. The move is well done and the acting superb, but to many sensibilities (and to a certain extent my own) the gore toward the end is most of what the viewer will remember. That will be the big take-away from the movie. Please don't have any children around when you watch it and I would not suggest eating lasagna toward the end of the movie. A very solid western with some really scary dudes! I had not seen a western in awhile and this one was very satisfying. The premise of cannibalistic Indians caused a chill up my spine but I thought the plot of a wife being kidnapped and a four man posse pursuing the bad guys might be a bit idealistic. Why not a bigger posse I kept saying to myself! But it worked fine and there was a touch of dry humor thrown in. Some might think it was a bit long but for me it really built suspense in wondering what was at the end of the journey! All in all a very good flick!
Excellent Movie. Total Surprise

I have seen reviews who criticize the pace, but it moved at a reasonable canter when many might have expected a sprint or at least a gallop. The violence is realistic...in that wounds are inflicted at close range. No unrealistic sharp shooting or knife throwing. And that is what makes it a bit unbearable when the level of violence ratchets up to gory heights. The brutality I suppose, is what heightens the fear and tension as to the enemy the group faces. But be forewarned, it is incredibly graphic. A one shot watch for me. A good movie as far as the dialog and acting by an impressive cast. No frills. Just a bare bones encounter with a malevolent force whose imagination is limited to how many ways they can torture and dismember. Not for everyone.

This movie was good right up until the last 30 minutes when it devolved into a jaw-droppingly cheesy, cheap, 1970-ish TV clunker. Seriously, I thought I was watching Land of the Lost at the end--complete with Sleestaks. It's like they ran out of money or something. I'd swear the set for the climatic scene actually WAS from Land of the Lost. Don't invest two hours of your time on this one.

Fantastic acting and great, fully-baked script. But wow, that's a lot of brutality and gore. The cast is uniformly good. I was surprised how much I enjoyed Matthew Fox's performance, but Richard Jenkins stole the show - his small character was very well written and performed. The plot was very straightforward and moved a wee bit slow. The brutality of the native people was pretty over the top. Bone Tomahawk movie reminded me quite a bit of Ravenous, a 1999 Guy Pierce movie about cannibal frontiersman. It's well-acted and super-grisly, but the plot moves at a much crisper pace. If Bone Tomahawk is your thing, you might appreciate Ravenous.

I'm a horror fan and a western fan, so when I heard this western/horror hybrid movie was coming out, I was beyond excited.  I had high hopes and 99% of the time when I go into a movie with high hopes, it doesn't live up to my expectations.  This one totally did!  It is everything I hoped it to be and more.

The movie begins with a bang and let's you in on what's in store.  The bulk of the movie is a slow delicious burn.  Amazing tension.  Since I watch a lot of horror movies, it's become harder and harder for me to feel scared or tense during a movie.  This movie left me with a tight feeling in my stomach throughout  because I cared for the characters and you just know things aren't going to go well for them.  The dialogue was funny at times, thoughtful and very human.

I'm scratching my head at the one-star reviews that this movie is "boring" or that you should skip straight to the end.  If you need non-stop action (or a very short attention span), then yeah, this isn't the movie for you.  If you care for quality filmmaking, good storytelling, and three-dimensional characters - where the journey is just as important as the destination - then this is the movie for you.

I should add that there is a very violent scene near the end that may be unsettling for some viewers.  I don't think that's a spoiler since the whole movie is building up to it.  The scene is not what you normally see in mainstream movies, and it even took me - a rabid horror fan - by surprise.  But I hope the violence doesn't keep you away from enjoying this well-done movie - may I suggest covering your eyes?  You kinda can guess when the "event" is about to happen anyway.

This film tells a brilliant story about the old West. It may very well owe some of its techniques to the Coen brothers, who always make seemingly banal dialogue fascinating and full of meaning. But whether or not the writer/director Zahler learned his techniques from the Coen brothers, this is a wonderfully original film. The character development is flawless, the dialogue is wonderfully realistic and often humorous in its authenticity, the horror is brief and quite frightening. I would just say to the folks who were grossed out by the violence and rated the film negatively: IT'S JUST A MOVIE!!! Don't forget that. If the violence upsets you that much, then something other than the movie itself is bothering you.

Some reviewers complain about the middle third dragging, but I didn't find this movie boring at any point. All of the characters were very interesting and I don't think there was any padding. It's all about character development and plot complications.

This is undoubtedly one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time.  I watched this movie at my sister's house through Amazon Streaming Video, and she is also in agreement with my assessment. I have read other reviews and I can't believe this movie received a 88 % rating on Rotten Tomatoes. The plot is easy to follow -  people being abducted by a band of cave dwelling ancient Indians called Troglodytes in a western setting. A small band of misfits, a poor excuse for a posse, trails them to return their abductees, and leash Hades on the cave dwellers. What struck as the most destructive element of this movie was the poor use of the camera. It reminded me of the movie, Cloverfield, when people actually got sick (motion sickness) from the jerky motion of the camera. The director's inexperience clearly came through on these amateurish scenes.  The dialogue was choppy and hard to follow, and the transitions between scenes was also choppy and completely annoying and hard to follow. There was also no outstanding character, outside of Kurt Russell, the reluctant leader, who does not have a presence like John Wayne in a classic John Ford western. The tone of the movie is a jumbled collection of personal emotions that mix like water and oil, from the awkward love scene, to the violent death of the captives by the weird Indians.  And I get the fact that the posse consists of older men, and a wounded man with a bad leg, misfits to say the least, on a mission to save the world, only to get captured, and then saved by the wounded man.  A classic case of the underdog overcoming all obstacles to win the day.  My overall assessment is for people in the movie industry to stop taking drugs and trying to make movies. This movie is the end result of a generation of social media, underachievers with no advanced life skills and a poor work ethic, with emotional problems, thinking they can rely on said media, to propel this movies into a position it can never attain in the rating world, no matter how many times your friends post how good the movie is on social media.  Kurt Russell could not save this movie, and I think he realizes he made a mistake starring in the movie. Overall, the imagery was poor, the music was poor, and I get it that the Indians had some form of tracheotomy to make weird sounds, but it did come off to save the movie. My advice to people, save your money and watch a classic move like, Invasion of the The Body Snatchers, with Kevin McCarthy, and then watch one of the best westerns ever made, The Searchers, with John Wayne. Then you'll get your fix of horror with a western, with a perfect mix of genres.

Save yourself two half-asleep hours and SKIP IT.

Bone Tomahawk is a film that understands pacing perfectly. The first act of the film introduces us to all our characters, the second chronicles their journey, and the third is about the end to that journey. I can't stress enough how much Richard Jenkins disappears into his role, phenomenal acting from him and the entire crew. The final act of this film is a little bit of a mess, with graphic violence taking the place of slow horror. One scene in particular is a rough watch, and seems a little out place in the film. I couldn't recommend this movie more for anyone who has even the most remote interest in it!

A surprisingly good film. I rented it expecting something well within the margin of error for $6.99 worth of entertainment. I was pleasantly surprised. It essentially takes a standard Western trope - kidnapped by Indians - and tweaks it into something fresh and compelling. Infusing a Western with horror elements is not as novel as it might seem, but it works well. The last 30-40 minutes of the film are brutally grim, filled with stretches of well-crafted tension.

That said, the pace of the film is very deliberate. I thought there was plenty going on throughout the whole thing to keep things interesting, but I'm sure some people would disagree. Those looking for a film packed with action and classic Western shootouts should look elsewhere. Those looking for an interesting, well-crafted film - open to an experience that might deviate somewhat from expectations - will probably be pleased.
Good movie
This movie was great! But, I am partial to westerns!

I think the potential viewer should be warned about the obscene violence included in this movie. Although the violence is not completely gratuitous, I found it unnerving well beyond the limits of how a film should affect a viewer. II am not particularly squeamish about this sort of thing, but I felt as though good direction, acting, and camera work had dragged me willingly into something that turn out to be something I was unwilling to witness.

Kurt Russell's performance was griping!  The entire cast showed belief in their roles that is rarely seen in any type of film.  The genre stayed true to form in the way men and women behaved in that time in our history.  The honesty of their life's purposes was unmistakable.  The savages could not have been more savage, but their actions were on par with their intellect and ritualistic behavior.  Every scene in this movie deserves its own Oscar and so does each actor and each savage.  This movie brings back memories of "Quest for Fire" and is so believable that it will scare you.  Watch this movie.  It is far more than mere entertainment.

Excellent Western, with a bit of horror involved. The movie is about a sheriff and a small group of men that set out to reclaim 3 people that have been kidnapped by Indians. The twist is that these Indians are not "normal" in any way that either the characters or the viewer will recognize.

I had wondered what had happened to Kurt Russell as of late, and here he puts in a very good job of portraying the honorable sheriff. Another thing to consider with this is it develops its characters very well, to where all of them make you care about what happens to them. The point that any prospective viewer should get is that they should definitely watch this movie, and also hope that more like it are made in the future.

Kurt Russel doesn't disappoint. Matthew Fox and Patrick Wilson are amazing as always. The story is tense and gritty and builds to an "edge of your seat" finale. There are some killer lines as well, like: "Did you train it in bigotry?"

Highly recommended...especially to my fellow Deadlands Roleplaying Game fans.

Genre mash-ups so rarely work but thankfully, Bone Tomahawk is the exception. A combination of western and horror, Bone Tomahawk provides a harrowing journey into the darkest parts of the old west where ordinary men meet up with disturbed cannibal savages. The conclusion is particularly harrowing as the film turns from a strong western into straight-up horror film with great results. Think a toned down version of Blood Meridian and you have a pretty good idea of what this film is going for.

This was good. A little slow building and the end wasn't that great but it was worth watching. Excellent acting and some funny moments. One of the murder scenes was one of the grossest things I've ever seen in a movie so watch out if you are sensitive to that kind of stuff.
Classic Kurt with a little taste of Jarmusch. Worth every minute.
Longest overland travel scene in the history of westerns...followed by the most brutal killing in modern movies.
Very disappointed in this movie.
Wish they could've delved a little more into the Indians but overall I liked it
Brace yourself, because the first hour contains horrible acting. I think I could read lines better. It picks up at the end, but not sure it's worth enduring the first part of the movie.
Good watch

This movie was slow and forget and dull.  The characters were lifeless and no really storey was told.  Kurt was ok - but the rest just dragged this horrible horrible movie into the grave.  When it was over I wanted 2 hours of my life back
Very good western with mild horror elements, highly recommend.
intense

This is not a good film, it has 1-absolutely horrific scene, you'll know it when you see it. I can honestly say it's new to me, and I've seen a lot of violent movies.  However, this is a Red Box rental at best, or wait for cable. Noting to see here, plot is quite slow & unrealistic in so many ways.
Amazing! S. Craig Zahler is a major talent. All four leads are sensational and the story and its execution are completely original it its own way.
Very low end movie and very boring
Great indie. Performances were all top notch. A lot of people say it's slow. I didn't feel that at all. I was on the edge of my seat throughout.

I don't know what all the bad reviews are about; I enjoyed the film as a somewhat new and a refreshing take on the Old West.  I've read that some of the old Anastasi tribes were cave dwelling, primitive and very violent.  I don't recall anything about cannibalism, except in the times when these Native Americans came in contact with the Spanish explorers.  Worth a watch.

I really liked this. I'm upset to see so many negative reviews. I found the dialogue alone worth the price of "admission". Richard Jenkins was the standout. The soup and music stand scenes were the best but practically everything he said was a gem. I went in knowing that it had some dark twists and even watching the preview you could tell there would be some things that might be hard to watch. It is definitely NOT an old school western. It's quirky and violent and talky but I found the long journey the posse had to take, and the bonding they went through on it, to be enjoyable. All of the acting was good. Even David Arquette in basically a cameo was good. I feel that if you know that the word cannibal is attached to anything that you can expect some pretty gnarly material and BT definitely has it. It's a slow build up to something terrible but you can sense it coming from the journey if you're paying attention. I have even purchased one of the director's novels because I enjoyed the movie so much. Highly recommended but not for the faint of heart. I'm going to give it five stars just to bump up the ratings to the four where it belongs. Haha.

What was Kurt Russel thinking? Gruesome scene of a naked dude being hacked in two with a Bone Tomahawk by a mud man, just wasn't enough. Movie felt painful to watch like the audience was annoyingly chained to the dude with broken leg, that just dredged on and on and on.
Great movie. Fantastic dialogue and story. Bizarre ending.

This movie is a blend of two very good movies....The Searchers (1956) and The Missing (2003).... I grew up on Westerns and liked the movie. Always nice to watch movies with actors that are well trained classical actors. Nobody phoned it in.

Saw this movie at the Gateway Theater in Columbus, OH as it is currently in limited release. Huge fan of Kurt Russell and thought this would be a nice segue into "The Hateful Eight", his major movie scheduled for release on Christmas day. The poster looks like a cool, little western; doesn't give away much. Boy, was I in for a surprise! It starts out like a traditional Western: some townsfolk are kidnapped by a mysterious band of renegades, and a posse made up of the sheriff, his old deputy, an arrogant, indian-hating aristocratic gunslinger and the husband of the kidnapped woman set out on a rescue mission. Admittedly, the middle 1/3 was a bit slow, but never dragged, using the time to really develop the characters. The dialog was interesting, original and had a rhythm all its own. The 4 main actors were awesome, but Richard Jenkins as the "back-up" deputy steals the show, not an easy feat with Kurt Russell at the top of his acting game. And when the rescue party (or what's left of them) finally reaches the caves...well, hang on to your barf bag, cause it'll kick you in the gut. This is the kind of movie rarely seen in American theaters anymore. Well worth seeking out.

I have always loved westerns due to watching them as a kid.  I thought this would be really good with Kurt Russell, I wish some of the reviews had been a little more detailed in the gruesome horrible last 15-20 minutes of the movie.  I am not a fan of horror movies and I find this to be more toward a horror movie.  As several people said, beware.  Guess I'm old fashioned and like the old western where there's a true hero saving the woman and riding off into the sunset.

Amazon fails to include "horror" among genres for this film.  Kurt Russell is spectacular.  The first two thirds of the film play out like a good classic western tracker.  Act three introduces such brutally violent acts that the viewer would benefit from some advance notice.  Some of these things happened historically, but they're rarely shown so graphically in film- probably for good reason.
really good western, if you can call it a western. its in its own genre i suppose....i loved it, but i will say it's not for everyone. Definitely worth watching.
True Grit meets Cannibal Holocaust. Nice steady western with a gruesome final act. Solid performances by all but Richard Jenkins stands out.

I liked it. The characters had depth, the set was very well done. The plot isn't spoon fed to you.  It seemed to fit the time period in which it took place.  I really like how everything was not over explained. And you knew as much as the main characters did about plot. The death for a supporting character,near the climax, was very predictable. Overall, it did what a decent story is supposed to. - take you away to another world for a brief period.

I found "Bone Tomahawk" fun and different.  The dialogue and character development are both great.  It took a bit of a dive when the uber violence commenced in the last 1/4 or so.  Implausible natives at best, especially the women.  Still, worth a watch.
Worst movie  seen in years. Kurt Russell is bottom  feeding.

I don't quite know how to rate this film but I feel it deserves comment.  Up until a certain scene toward the end, I would've given it 5 stars.  Make that 4 since I feel it's in desperate need of a good musical score.  The story, the characters, the dialogue, the casting, the acting, all excellent in my opinion, outstanding in places.  I felt there was a lot of potential for a great film.

But then... that awful scene.  I'm not particularly squeamish and I knew what the story was about.  But this was too over-the-top even for this story, bizarrely intrusive like it didn't fit the tone of the rest of the film.  The ickiness took me out of the story and there was no going back.
I would have expected a better film with Kurt Russell.
Worst Kurt Russell movie ever!!!!!!!!

A Western with a horrific take. The cast and writing was outstanding and made for a genuine western period piece. I felt the direction for first timer S. Craig Zahler was pretty descent. The movie definitely had no budget, but made up for it in the Acting and dialogue between characters. As far as the Horror aspect of the movie, it was a little bit of a slow burn, which I don't have a problem with especially when it pays off, which it did. Some of the scenes were cringe worthy and gruesome. I love westerns and I love horror movies. I would recommend this if your a fan of genre.

Should have waited for this movie to be free on Prime. I'm a boomer wanting to see western's the way they used to be. This seemed more like a western produced by Freddy Krueger on a cheap budget. Kurt Russell did the best he could with a crazy slow going story line.
Weirdest western I've ever watched.
Great indie genre mashup.

Great writing, characters and performances. Matthew Fox and Richard Jenkins achieve epic, memorable characterizations and vanish into their roles. Loved these guys especially. The Troglodyte cave scenes feel a little low budget / cheesy, but great, unique take on Western-meets-horror genre. Loved it.

Shocking, different, realistic, movie that is not the run of the mill. Good acting, keeps your attention from start to finish. Some might think it is gross but it's mild compared to the run of the mill horror film.
This film apparently went direct to video, but it's not bad. Anything with Kurt Russell, cowboys, and cannibals in the same film is worth watching. Not for the squeamish though.
Excellent!! Not a horror tho...just a really good western
Awesome!
Potential was there but it was not a good movie.
Fantastic!

Very cool idea to mix terrifying horror with a western.  Some town folk get kidnapped by some cannibal cave dwellers.  Kurt and his gang of four go and try to rescue them.  The movie starts up with a taste of action and violence but then goes for a long time with lots of talk to set up character and plot.  Then the climax happens and it is brutal to watch.  For the sensitive crowds...Be Warned!!!!  If you can't handle The Walking Dead type of gore, this movie is not for you!!!  Excellent acting and suspense make this movie worth a watch for us gore hounds.  I still think they could've cut 20 minutes out of it to move it a tad bit faster, but this is an Indy film.

If you would like to enjoy this masterpiece to its fullest invest in these characters and do not be in a hurry for their journey to end, for they stand almost no chance against these predators.
After a second viewing I now see the directors genius. Every scene, every cut, every word was well crafted and percise. I believe I was manipulated to feel what the director wanted me to feel: what the characters felt.
What's negative about this film? It is not for everyone.

Just awful. I expected much more from this cast but this is a poor excuse for a movie. Bad plot, bad acting, very repetitive action, and one amazingly over the top gratuitous violent scene. Really one of the worst movies I've seen in years.

Here is a hard-to-resist ideaKurt Russell plays a taciturn Old West lawman leading a small group into the wild to reclaim an abducted woman from a tribe of cave-inhabiting cannibalsundermined to a certain extent by uneven execution.  At two hours and 10 minutes, it is far too long.  The first half is downright cumbersome.  Scenes overstay their welcome, often because the script is enamored to a fault with its own "adorable," self-aware, Tarantino-lite dialogue.  The artificiality of the cyclical, verbose yes-sir-no-ma'am-yield-yer-repeater-and-rest-yer-hide banter slides the film toward camp, though a fine cast (Matthew Fox stands out as a dandy with a violent, Indian-hunting past) and a handsome aesthetic push in another, saltier, more grounded direction.  The film becomes considerably more involving and satisfying in the second half as the characters focus and draw closer to a direct confrontation with the antagonists, who are truly menacing and mysterious.

People who say Kurt must be desperate are retarded.  This is easily the best movie he has been in as one of the lead roles since Breakdown in 1997.  He has been in a long list of stinkers since then aside from small supporting roles.

Not what I expected at all, but really delivers.  Acting, directing, and storytelling are all top notch.  A bit of a slow burner, but keeps you going.  Definitely has a flavor of the old westerns from the 60's.  Also, if you liked the original The Thing from the early 80's, I highly recommend this.
Downright brilliant. Original, energetic and unforgettable

very good indie movie. The price will come down but i am glad i watched it.  Thought provoking - i spent an hour or so afterwards researching elements of the script for veracity ... in particular the pueblo cultures of america, early and 17 and 18 century.  Long movie but i never fast forwarded as i am won't to do.  Great acting.  Long movie. Not a horror movie but is very vivid. Scary only in the sense of verisimilitude!  And not a western movie ... but a movie of survival in frontier america.
Liked the plot different from other westerns. I won't classify as typical horror, but the one graphic albeit gratuitous violent scene i skipped and felt took away from the movie, IHMO.
great movie

The worst movie I ever watched. I couldn't believe that Kurt Russell agreed to do this.
It was so gruesome I couldn't watch it to the end. I can't get those horrible images out of my mind. Unnecessary gore. I wish I've never watched this movie.

So many of the reviews on here seemed to be fixated on the notorious "scene in the cave." Either you loved it or loathed it -- there is definitely no in-between feeling regarding it. I happened to not only love it but as several reviewers have previously stated, thought it was necessary to show/see it. Just as the middle third of the film feels rather slow and a bit tedious, it is meant to put us, the viewer, in the proverbial shoes of the characters we are watching. The filmmakers want us to feel what Sheriff Franklin Hunt and the others are feeling. And boy, do we ever!

Kurt Russel was excellent. Richard Jenkins was charming.  The plot is basically "hillbilly cannibal family" with a Western genre twist...but not much of one. Standard redneck horror fare, nothing remarkable, not terrible, not great.

This film is absolutely fantastic. The four primary characters are somewhat trope' on the surface. That being said, the script and pacing allows these characters to fully flesh themselves out and the range of their humanity, personality type, etc. runs across the societal spectrum. All of these men have their strengths and faults, like the rest of us, and their decisions and actions along the way are believable and justifiable - even when they appear to be brutal. It's rare that films, especially in this day & age, avoid the trap of having binary-stereotypical characters, but Bone Tomahawk avoids that common pratfall. This movie is intelligent and contains important undertones regarding morality & tribalism throughout. I should also mention that the questions of 'morality' are not done in the typically heavy handed or politically ponderous manner. So refreshing.

This film is as much a character study as it is 'horror' and it's all done under the unrelenting back drop of an excellent 'Western' classic. The story arc for each character is compelling and at times heartbreaking and as others have mentioned,whilst the gore is most certainly horrific and visceral, it does NOT seem gratuitous as it's all presented in a very matter of fact, though completely chilling manner.

This is a "MUST SEE" for any fan of westerns, layered character studies, new takes on old genre's or simply want to watch an unforgettable film.  5 STARS.
Great dvd

I'm really glad I saw this mentioned on YouTube and had to take a look when I saw Kurt Russell's name in the credits on IMDb. Very fortunate that it's on Prime. Russell has a certain swagger about him that suits the western genre to a T. He owns every scene he is ever in much like McCready in The Thing. It has a very basic and well-trodden plot of breaking taboos, being punished for the intrusion, and the chase for revenge, which is a fine plot for any western, particularly with spooky overtones. The heroes form quite a cabal of misfit anti-heroes and paladins, just like any tabletop roleplaying game. If you get a chance and have a few hours to spare, most definitely check out this diamond in the rough.

This is a great movie, far above average for Amazon Prime Video. There is plenty of action, but it is all situated in the story and properly placed. Little bits of humor are spread throughout, in a dry and wry sense of casual Western humor. The horror seems mostly suggested at first but all things are revealed.

I used to enjoy films like this but as I  grow older I see that our society is deliberately being desensitized to insane, violent crap. Each generation now becomes less and less human and humane and more and more nonchalant about depravity, murder and death. That being said, this film was less about human survival and nobility and more about how much more depraved  can we make hollywood garbage? There is a tribe running the world and it isn't made up of the "indians" in this film. They are nonetheless just as much a bunch of sick, twisted, parasitic, cannibalistic monsters. We dare not name them for fear of being censored. Just look to the banks, the fascist state and hollywood for them. They made this piece of dung.
